“银行式”教育模式还经常被大多数保守派和自由派教育家用作避风港，他们将自己的唯物主义和消费主义教育观念掩盖在弗莱雷所说的“当前教育实践中十分常见的‘消化式’知识观念” 59 中——这种做法认为学生“营养不良”，结果导致教师不得不给学生一份不切实际的阅读清单，而这些阅读材料在课堂上从未真正涉及或讨论过，借口是学生“意识是‘空间化的’，必须‘填充’才能了解”。60这让我 想起一位教授，他给他的学生提供了一份长达 80 页的阅读清单的教学大纲，他非常清楚，在一个学期的课程中不可能严格讨论所有这些阅读材料，这种教学法无疑重数量轻质量。同一位教授要求学生写一篇 40 页的论文（为什么不是 25、35 或 38 页呢？）——他几乎不读这些页面，更不用说提供广泛而有见地的评论了。在一位学生修改后的 54 页论文中，教授提供了简短的评论，不超过 2 到 5 个字，例如“出色的工作”、“高雅文化与低俗文化”、“伟大”或“教学力量”。简而言之，整篇 54 页的论文总共收到了 43 个字的评论。这种“营养主义”教育方法遵循着“与让·保罗·萨特在批评‘知识就是吃’这一观念时所持的相同观念，他高呼：‘啊，营养哲学！’” 61—— 在这一过程中，“词语被转化为单纯的‘词汇储存库’（教师的词汇），即学生要‘吃’和‘消化’的精神食粮” 62； 教师的知识（即定义列表，但不了解知识的对象；方法作为一种工具包，脱离了对其使用如何影响某些意识形态的认识，特别是现在应用于新技术时；教师在教学过程中，一方面被迫接受大量的公式化文本（伪装成理论而轻视实践的公式化文本和大量的词汇表）。学生被不断地“灌输”信息，这些信息是毫无意义的，之后，他们又被要求在强制性的考试和测验中“吐出”这些信息。这些测验一方面是为了证实教师拥有卓越的知识/银行账户，另一方面是为了满足教师的自恋需求，而这正是大多数人道主义（而非人文主义）教育方法所固有的动机。最终，“营养银行”教育方法，即使是打着进步教育的幌子，其主要目标也是通过教师知识的“储存”来充实学生的大脑，因此，在这种教学模式下，学生吸收的理解“并非来自（他们自己的）……创造性努力……[作为]学习者”。63 这种教育关注的是事实的再现，而不是理解知识的对象以产生新知识，它必然会导致学习者的认识论好奇心和创造力的麻痹，因为教师强加的知识负担过重，“事实上……这几乎完全是异化和疏远的，与学生的社会文化现实几乎没有任何关系。” 64

The “banking” model of education is also often used as a safe haven for most conservative and many liberal educators who conceal their materialist and consumerist conception of education in what Freire calls a “‘digestive’ concept of knowledge, so common in current educational practice”59 —a practice that considers students to be “undernourished” and, as a result, leads the teacher to feel compelled to give students an unrealistic list of readings that are never really covered or discussed in class under the pretext that the students’ “consciousness is ‘spatialized,’ and must be ‘filled’ in order to know.”60 I am reminded of a professor who gave his student a syllabus containing a reading list totaling 80 pages, knowing all too well that it is impossible to rigorously discuss all of these readings in a one-semester course, a pedagogy that certainly celebrates quantity over quality. The same professor required students to write a 40-page paper (why not 25, 35, or 38?)—pages that he hardly read much less provided extensive and insightful comments. In a student’s corrected 54-page paper, the professor provided short comments that did not go beyond 2 to 5 words such as “excellent job,” “high vs. low culture,” “great,” or “pedagogical forces.” In short, an entire 54-page paper received a total of 43 words in comments. This “nutritionist” approach to education follows the “same conception [that] led Jean Paul Sartre, [when] criticizing the notion that ‘to know is to eat,’ to exclaim: ‘O philosophie alimentaire!’”61 —a process where “words are transformed into mere ‘deposit of vocabulary’ [the teacher’s vocabulary]—the bread of the spirit which the [students] are to ‘eat’ and ‘digest’”62 the teacher’s knowledge (i.e., definition lists without the apprehension of the object of knowledge; methods as a tool kit divorced from awareness of how their use inscribes certain ideologies, particularly now as applied to new technologies; formulaic texts masquerading as theory that belittles practice; and ample glossaries). Incessantly “fed” information as unthinking receptacles, students are later asked to “vomit” it back in the mandated ex ams and tests designed, on the one hand, to confirm the teacher’s superior knowledge/bank-account and, on the other, to feed his or her narcissistic needs, a motive inherent in most humanitarian (not humanist) approaches to education. In the end, the “nutritionist banking” approach to education, even when offered under the guise of progressive education, has as its major goal the fattening of the student’s brain through the “deposits” of the teacher’s knowledge and thus, under this pedagogical model, students absorb understandings “not born of [their own] . . . creative efforts . . . [as] learners.”63 This kind of education, concerned with the reproduction of facts rather than apprehending the object of knowledge in order to produce new knowledge, invariably results in the paralysis of the learner’s epistemological curiosity and creativity due to the overload of the teacher’s imposed knowledge, “which in fact [is] . . . almost completely alienating and alienated, having so little, if anything, to do with the student’s socio-cultural reality.”64

本质上，在《被压迫者教育学》中，弗莱雷为我们提供了基于实践的革命性变革的意识形态路线图，其中“没有二分法可以将这种实践分为反思的前阶段和后续阶段。行动和反思同时发生。” 65 简而言之，弗莱雷挑战我们所有人开发批判性反思工具，以使我们不会忘记危险的记忆，这些记忆以严酷的经济不平等、残酷的暴力和非人性化为标志——这种非人性化需要受到谴责。必须谴责人类的苦难，以便我们能够保护所需的思想连贯性，以帮助其他人理解作为人类学游客研究饥饿与亲身经历饥饿之间的关键区别、谴责​​暴力与幸存之间的关键区别、以及“发声”的虚假仁慈与被压迫者之间的关键区别。制度上迫使他们失去发言权。因此，那些宣称需要“给予”有色人种或女性发言权的伪批判教育者未能意识到发言权不是一种天赋。这是一种民主权利。这是一项人权。

In essence, in Pedagogy of the Oppressed, Freire offers us an ideological road map for revolutionary transformations based on praxis where there is “no dichotomy by which this praxis could be divided into a prior stage of reflection and a subsequent stage. Action and reflection occur simultaneously.”65 Simply put, Freire challenges all of us to develop critical reflective tools that will keep us from forgetting dangerous memories which are marked by draconian economic inequality, cruel violence, and dehumanization—a dehumanization that needs to be denounced. This condemnation of human suffering must happen so that we can protect the intellectual coherence needed in order to help others comprehend the critical difference between studying hunger as anthropological tourists and experiencing it, between deploring violence and surviving it, and between the false benevolence of “giving voice” and being institutionally forced into voicelessness. Thus, the pseudo-critical educators who proclaim the need to “give” people of color or women a voice, fail to realize that voice is not a gift. It is a democratic right. It is a human right.

弗莱雷一直强调，解放斗争存在的理由就是重新获得这些权利，而没有自治就永远无法实现这一点。反过来，没有与我们一起为解放而斗争的人民真正的交流，就无法实现自治。换句话说，主流的批评语言仅仅通过书面的话语实践来谴责社会不公正，但缺乏与人民一起采取相应的行动，这代表了一种情境交流。这种情况通常发生在学者作为人类学游客，在为他们的研究项目收集数据等情况下与人民短暂交流，但不久之后就让这个苦苦挣扎的社区任其摆布。与被压迫者共融意味着一个人愿意进行阶级和种族自杀，这代表的意义远不止“从一个空间跨越到另一个地理空间，从压迫者跨越到被压迫者……阶级自杀是复活节的一种形式；它涉及将穿越文化和意识形态背景的通道问题化。重要的是对被压迫者有意义和持久的团结的承诺。” 66 正如弗莱雷简洁地说的那样，

Freire always emphasized that the raison d’etre of struggles for liberation is the reclamation of these rights, which can never be achieved without autonomy. In turn, autonomy cannot be achieved without a true communion with the people with whom we are engaged in a struggle for liberation. In other words, the dominant language of critique that denounces social injustices through written discursive practice only, but which lacks a corresponding action together with the people, represents a situational communion. This is often the case when academics, as anthropological tourists, enter into communion with the people for a brief time while, for example, collecting data for their research project, but leave the struggling community at its own mercy soon after. Communion with the oppressed means one’s willingness to commit class and race suicide which represents much more than "the mere crossing border from one space to another geographical crossing from oppressor to oppressed . . . . Class suicide is a form of Easter; it involves problematizing a passage through a cultural and ideological context. It is the commitment to meaningful and lasting solidarity with the oppressed that counts.”66 As Freire succinctly put it,

否认革命进程中的交流，以组织人民、加强革命力量或确保统一战线为借口避免与人民对话，这实际上是对自由的恐惧。这是对人民缺乏信心的恐惧……革命既不是由领导人为人民而进行的，也不是由人民为领导人而进行的，而是由双方共同行动，坚定不移地团结一致而进行的。只有当领导人以谦逊、充满爱心和勇敢的态度与人民接触时，这种团结才会诞生。并不是所有的男人和女人都有足够的勇气进行这种接触——但当他们避免接触时，他们就会变得僵化，对待他人他们不是在培育生命，而是在扼杀生命；他们不是在寻找生命，而是在逃避生命。这些都是压迫者的特征。67

denial of communion in the revolutionary process, avoidance of dialogue with people under the pretext of organizing them, of strengthening revolutionary power, or ensuring a united front, is really a fear of freedom. It is fear of lack of faith in the people . . . [t]he revolution is made neither by the leaders for the people, nor by the people for the leaders, but by both acting together in unshakable solidarity. This solidarity is born only when the leaders witness to it by their humble, loving, and courageous encounter with the people. Not all men and women have sufficient courage for this encounter—but when they avoid encounter they become inflexible and treat others as mere objects; instead of nurturing life, they kill life; instead of searching for life, they flee from it. And these are oppressor characteristics.67

前言

Preface

这些介绍被压迫者教育学的页面是我六年政治流亡期间的观察成果，这些观察丰富了我之前在巴西的教育活动所提供的观察。

These pages, which introduce Pedagogy of the Oppressed, result from my observations during six years of political exile, observations which have enriched those previously afforded by my educational activities in Brazil.

无论是在分析意识觉醒的作用的培训课程中，还是在真正解放教育的实际实验中，我都遇到了本书第一章中讨论的“对自由的恐惧”。培训课程的参与者经常以一种揭示他们自己对自由的恐惧的方式提请注意“意识觉醒的危险”。他们说，批判意识是无政府主义的。其他人补充说，批判意识可能会导致混乱。然而，有些人承认：为什么要否认呢？我害怕自由。我不再害怕了！

I have encountered, both in training courses which analyze the role of conscientização1 and in actual experimentation with a truly liberating education, the “fear of freedom” discussed in the first chapter of this book. Not infrequently, training course participants call attention to “the danger of conscientização” in a way that reveals their own fear of freedom. Critical consciousness, they say, is anarchic. Others add that critical consciousness may lead to disorder. Some, however, confess: Why deny it? I was afraid of freedom. I am no longer afraid!

在其中一次讨论中，小组正在辩论，男人和女人对特定不公正情况的觉醒是否会导致他们陷入“破坏性的狂热”或“感觉世界彻底崩溃”。在争论中，一位曾经做过多年工厂工人的人说道：“也许我是这里唯一一个工人阶级出身的人。我不能说我理解了你刚才所说的一切，但我可​​以说一件事——当我开始这门课程时，我很天真，当我发现自己有多天真时，我开始变得挑剔。但这一发现并没有让我成为一个狂热分子，我也没有感到任何崩溃。”

In one of these discussions, the group was debating whether the conscientização of men and women to a specific situation of injustice might not lead them to “destructive fanaticism” or to a “sensation of total collapse of their world.” In the midst of the argument, a ­person who previously had been a factory worker for many years spoke out: “Perhaps I am the only one here of working-class origin. I can’t say that I’ve understood everything you’ve said just now, but I can say one thing—when I began this course I was naïve, and when I found out how naïve I was, I started to get critical. But this discovery hasn’t made me a fanatic, and I don’t feel any collapse either.”

对良心化可能产生的影响的怀疑意味着一个怀疑者并不总是明确提出的前提：不公正的受害者最好不要承认自己是受害者。然而，事实上，良心化并不会导致人们陷入“破坏性的狂热”。相反，通过让人们能够作为负责任的主体参与历史进程，良心化2 使他们参与到自我肯定的探索中，从而避免了狂热。

Doubt regarding the possible effects of conscientização implies a premise which the doubter does not always make explicit: It is ­better for the victims of injustice not to recognize themselves as such. In fact, however, conscientização does not lead people to “destructive fanaticism.” On the contrary, by making it possible for people to enter the historical process as responsible Subjects,2 conscientização enrolls them in the search for self-affirmation and thus avoids fa-naticism.

批判意识的觉醒引领社会不满情绪的表达，正是因为这些不满情绪是压迫性局势的真实组成部分。3

The awakening of critical consciousness leads the way to the expression of social discontents precisely because these discontents are real components of an oppressive situation.3

对自由的恐惧（拥有自由的人不一定意识到这一点）使他看到了鬼魂。这样的人实际上是在寻求庇护，试图获得安全，他或她更喜欢安全而不是自由的风险。正如黑格尔所证实的：

Fear of freedom, of which its possessor is not necessarily aware, makes him see ghosts. Such an individual is actually taking refuge in an attempt to achieve security, which he or she prefers to the risks of liberty. As Hegel testifies:

只有冒着生命危险才能获得自由……没有冒生命危险的人无疑可以被承认为一个人；但他或她还没有获得作为独立自我意识的这种承认的真理。4

It is solely by risking life that freedom is obtained; . . . the ­individual who has not staked his or her life may, no doubt, be recognized as a Person; but he or she has not attained the truth of this recognition as an independent self-consciousness.4

然而，男人和女人很少公开承认他们对自由的恐惧，而是倾向于伪装它——有时是无意识的——把自己表现为自由的捍卫者。他们让自己的怀疑和疑虑显得非常清醒，就像自由的守护者一样。但他们把自由与维持现状混为一谈；因此，如果良心化威胁到现状，那么它似乎就构成了对自由本身的威胁。

Men and women rarely admit their fear of freedom openly, however, tending rather to camouflage it—sometimes unconsciously—by presenting themselves as defenders of freedom. They give their doubts and misgivings an air of profound sobriety, as befitting custodians of freedom. But they confuse freedom with the maintenance of the ­status quo; so that if conscientização threatens to place that status quo in question, it thereby seems to constitute a threat to freedom itself.

《被压迫者教育学》并非仅靠思考和研究就能写成；它植根于具体情况，描述了我在教育工作过程中直接或间接观察到的劳动者（农民或城市人）和中产阶级的反应。持续的观察将使我有机会在以后的研究中修改或证实这本导论中提出的观点。

Thought and study alone did not produce Pedagogy of the Op-pressed; it is rooted in concrete situations and describes the reac-tions of laborers (peasant or urban) and of middle-class persons whom I have observed directly or indirectly during the course of my educative work. Continued observation will afford me an opportunity to modify or to corroborate in later studies the points proposed in this introductory work.

这本书可能会引起一些读者的负面反应。有些人会认为我对人类解放问题的立场纯粹是理想主义的，甚至可能认为对本体论使命、爱、对话、希望、谦逊和同情的讨论是反动的“废话”。其他人不会（或不愿）接受我对满足压迫者的压迫状态的谴责。因此，这部诚然是尝试性的作品是为激进分子准备的。我确信，基督徒和马克思主义者，尽管他们可能部分或全部不同意我的观点，但会继续读到最后。但教条地假设封闭的“非理性”立场的读者将拒绝我希望这本书开启的对话。

This volume will probably arouse negative reactions in a ­number of readers. Some will regard my position vis-à-vis the problem of human liberation as purely idealistic, or may even consider discussion of ontological vocation, love, dialogue, hope, humility, and sym-pathy as so much reactionary “blah.” Others will not (or will not wish to) accept my denunciation of a state of oppression that ­gratifies the oppressors. Accordingly, this admittedly tentative work is for radicals. I am certain that Christians and Marxists, though they may disagree with me in part or in whole, will continue reading to the end. But the reader who dogmatically assumes closed, “irrational” positions will reject the dialogue I hope this book will open.

宗派主义以狂热为食，总是具有阉割性。激进主义以批判精神为食，总是具有创造性。宗派主义神话化，从而疏远；激进主义批判，从而解放。激进主义要求人们更加坚定地坚持自己选择的立场，从而更加努力地改变具体的客观现实。相反，宗派主义神话化、不合理，将现实变成了虚假的（因此是不可改变的）“现实”。

Sectarianism, fed by fanaticism, is always castrating. Radicaliza­tion, nourished by a critical spirit, is always creative. ­Sectarianism mythicizes and thereby alienates; radicalization criticizes and thereby liberates. Radicalization involves increased commitment to the position one has chosen, and thus ever greater engagement in the effort to transform concrete, objective reality. Conversely, sectar­ianism, because it is mythicizing and irrational, turns reality into a false (and therefore unchangeable) “reality.”

任何方面的宗派主义都是人类解放的障碍。不幸的是，右派宗派主义并不总是会引发其自然对应物：革命者的激进化。革命者在回应右派宗派主义的过程中，往往也会陷入宗派主义，从而成为反动派。然而，这种可能性不应导致激进分子成为精英阶层的温顺棋子。在解放过程中，他或她不能在压迫者的暴力面前保持被动。

Sectarianism in any quarter is an obstacle to the emancipation of mankind. The rightist version thereof does not always, unfortu­-nately, call forth its natural counterpart: radicalization of the revolu-tionary. Not infrequently, revolutionaries themselves become reactionary by falling into sectarianism in the process of responding to the sectarianism of the Right. This possibility, however, should not lead the radical to become a docile pawn of the elites. Engaged in the process of liberation, he or she cannot remain passive in the face of the oppressor’s violence.

另一方面，激进分子从来不是主观主义者。对于这个人来说，主观方面只存在于与客观方面（具体现实，即分析的对象）的关系中。因此，主观性和客观性结合成辩证统一体，在行动中产生知识，反之亦然。

On the other hand, the radical is never a subjectivist. For this ­individual the subjective aspect exists only in relation to the objective aspect (the concrete reality, which is the object of analysis). ­Subjectivity and objectivity thus join in a dialectical unity producing knowledge in solidarity with action, and vice versa.

就其本身而言，无论何种教派，宗派主义者都被非理性所蒙蔽，无法（或不能）感知现实的动态，或者曲解现实。如果这种人辩证地思考，那也是一种“驯化辩证法”。右翼宗派主义者（我以前称其为天生的宗派主义者5 ）希望放慢历史进程，将时间“驯化”，从而驯化男人和女人。当左翼宗派主义者试图辩证地解释现实和历史时，他或她就完全误入歧途，陷入本质上宿命论的立场。

For his or her part, the sectarian of whatever persuasion, blinded by irrationality, does not (or cannot) perceive the dynamic of reali-ty—or else misinterprets it. Should this person think dialectically, it is with a “domesticated dialectic.” The rightist sectarian (whom I have previously termed a born sectarian5 ) wants to slow down the historical process, to “domesticate” time and thus to domesticate men and women. The leftist-turned-sectarian goes totally astray when he or she attempts to interpret reality and history ­dialectically, and falls into essentially fatalistic positions.

右派宗派分子与左派宗派分子的区别在于，前者试图驯化现在，以便（他或她希望）未来能够重现这种驯化的现在，而后者认为未来是预先设定的——一种不可避免的命运、运气或命运。对于右派宗派分子来说，“今天”与过去相连，是既定的、不可改变的；对于左派宗派分子来说，“明天”是预先注定的，是不可抗拒的。这种右派分子和这种左派分子都是反动的，因为从他们各自错误的历史观出发，他们都发展出了否定自由的行动形式。一个人想象一个“表现良好”的现在，另一个人想象一个预先确定的未来，但这并不意味着他们就袖手旁观，成为旁观者（前者期待现在继续，后者等待已经“已知”的未来实现）。相反，这些人把自己封闭在无法逃脱的“确定性圈子”中，他们“创造”了自己的真理。这不是那些为建设未来而奋斗、冒着建设过程中的风险的男男女女的真理。也不是那些并肩作战、共同学习的男男女女的真理如何建设这个未来——这不是人民可以接受的东西，而是人民可以创造的东西。这两种宗派主义都以同样专有的方式对待历史，最终都失去了人民——这是反对他们的另一种方式。

The rightist sectarian differs from his or her leftist counterpart in that the former attempts to domesticate the present so that (he or she hopes) the future will reproduce this domesticated present, while the latter considers the future pre-established—a kind of in-evitable fate, fortune, or destiny. For the rightist sectarian, “today,” linked to the past, is something given and immutable; for the ­leftist sectarian, “tomorrow” is decreed beforehand, is inexorably preordained. This rightist and this leftist are both reactionary because, starting from their respectively false views of history, both develop forms of action that negate freedom. The fact that one person imag­ines a “well-behaved” present and the other a predetermined future does not mean that they therefore fold their arms and become spectators (the former expecting that the present will continue, the latter waiting for the already “known” future to come to pass). On the ­contrary, closing themselves into “circles of certainty” from which they cannot escape, these individuals “make” their own truth. It is not the truth of men and women who struggle to build the future, ­running the risks involved in this very construction. Nor is it the truth of men and women who fight side by side and learn together how to build this future—which is not something given to be re-ceived by people, but is rather something to be created by them. Both types of sectarian, treating history in an equally proprietary fashion, end up without the people—which is another way of being against them.

右翼宗派主义者把自己封闭在“他的”真理中，只不过是履行了自然角色而已，而左翼主义者则变得宗派主义和僵化，否定了他或她的本性。然而，当他们围绕“他的”真理而转时，如果真理受到质疑，他们都会感到威胁。因此，他们把任何不是“他的”真理的东西都视为谎言。正如记者马西奥·莫雷拉·阿尔维斯曾经告诉我的那样，“他们都缺乏怀疑。”

Whereas the rightist sectarian, closing himself in “his” truth, does no more than fulfill a natural role, the leftist who becomes sectarian and rigid negates his or her very nature. Each, however, as he re-volves about “his” truth, feels threatened if that truth is questioned. Thus, each considers anything that is not “his” truth a lie. As the journalist Marcio Moreira Alves once told me, “They both suffer from an absence of doubt.”

致力于人类解放的激进分子不会成为“确定性圈”的囚徒，现实也同样被囚禁在其中。相反，一个人越激进，就越能充分地融入现实，从而更好地了解现实，更好地改变现实。这个人不怕面对现实，不怕倾听，不怕看到不为人知的世界。这个人不怕与人民见面或与他们对话。6这个人不认为自己是历史或所有人的主人，也不认为自己是 被压迫者的解放者；但他或她确实致力于在历史中与他们并肩作战。

The radical, committed to human liberation, does not become the prisoner of a “circle of certainty within which reality is also imprisoned. On the contrary, the more radical the person is, the more fully he or she enters into reality so that, knowing it better, he or she can better transform it. This individual is not afraid to confront, to listen, to see the world unveiled. This person is not afraid to meet the people or to enter into dialogue with them.6 This person does not consider himself or herself the proprietor of history or of all people, or the liberator of the oppressed; but he or she does commit himself or herself, within history, to fight at their side.

被压迫者的教育学（其概述见下文）是激进分子的任务，而宗派主义者则无法完成。

The pedagogy of the oppressed, the introductory outlines of which are presented in the following pages, is a task for radicals; it cannot be carried out by sectarians.

如果本书的读者中有人具有足够的批判精神，能够纠正错误和误解，深化肯定，指出我没有察觉到的方面，我就满足了。有些人可能会质疑我讨论革命文化行动的权利，因为我对这个话题没有具体的经验。然而，我没有亲自参加革命行动这一事实并不否定我反思的可能性。这一主题。此外，在我作为一名教育工作者与人民打交道的经验中，我使用对话式和问题式的教育，积累了相当丰富的材料，这些材料挑战我去冒险做出这项工作中所包含的肯定。

I will be satisfied if among the readers of this work there are those sufficiently critical to correct mistakes and misunderstandings, to deepen affirmations and to point out aspects I have not perceived. It is possible that some may question my right to discuss ­revolutionary cultural action, a subject of which I have no concrete experience. The fact that I have not personally participated in revolutionary action, however, does not negate the possibility of my reflecting on this theme. Furthermore, in my experience as an educator with the people, using a dialogical and problem-posing education, I have accumulated a comparative wealth of material that challenged me to run the risk of making the affirmations contained in this work.

我希望，至少下列内容能够从这些文字中传承下去：我对人民的信任、对男人和女人的信念、以及对创造一个更容易去爱的世界的信念。

From these pages I hope at least the following will endure: my trust in the people, and my faith in men and women, and in the ­creation of a world in which it will be easier to love.

在此，我要感谢我的妻子和“第一位读者”埃尔扎，感谢她对我作品的理解和鼓励，这也是她的功劳。我还要感谢一群朋友对我手稿的评论。尽管可能遗漏了一些名字，但我必须提到 João da Veiga Coutinho、Richard Shaull、Jim Lamb、Myra 和 Jovelino Ramos、Paulo de Tarso、Almino Affonso、Plinio Sampaio、Ernani Maria Fiori、Marcela Gajardo、José Luis Fiori 和 João Zacarioti。当然，本文中做出的声明的责任完全由我承担。

Here I would like to express my gratitude to Elza, my wife and “first reader,” for the understanding and encouragement she has shown my work, which belongs to her as well. I would also like to extend my thanks to a group of friends for their comments on my manuscript. At the risk of omitting some names, I must mention João da Veiga Coutinho, Richard Shaull, Jim Lamb, Myra and Jovelino Ramos, Paulo de Tarso, Almino Affonso, Plinio Sampaio, Ernani Maria Fiori, Marcela Gajardo, José Luis Fiori, and João Zacarioti. The responsibility for the affirmations made herein is, of course, mine alone.

                                 保罗·弗莱雷

                                 PAULO FREIRE

笔记

Notes

1良心觉醒是指学会察觉社会、政治和经济矛盾，并采取行动对抗现实的压迫因素。见第 3 章。——译者注。

1 The term conscientização refers to learning to perceive social, political, and economic contradictions, and to take action against the oppressive elements of reality. See chapter 3.—Translator’s note.

2主体（Subjects）是指那些知道并采取行动的人，客体（object）则是指那些被知道并被采取行动的人。——译者注。

2 The term Subjects denotes those who know and act, in contrast to objects, which are known and acted upon.—Translator’s note.

3 Francisco Weffort，在 Paulo Freire 的序言中，Educação como Prática da Liberdade（里约热内卢，1967 年）。

3 Francisco Weffort, in the preface to Paulo Freire, Educação como Prática da ­Liberdade (Rio de Janeiro, 1967).

4格奥尔格·黑格尔，《心灵现象学》（纽约，1967 年），第 233 页。

4 Georg Hegel, The Phenomenology of Mind (New York, 1967), p. 233.

5自由教育。

5 In Educação como Prática da Liberdade.

6. “只要理论知识仍然为党内一小撮‘院士’所独享，党内就有误入歧途的危险。”罗莎·卢森堡，《改良还是革命》，引自C.赖特·米尔斯著《马克思主义者》（纽约，1963年）。

6. “As long as theoretic knowledge remains the privilege of a handful of ‘academicians in the Party, the latter will face the danger of going astray.” Rosa Luxembourg, Reform or Revolution, cited in C. Wright Mills, The Marxists (New York, 1963).

 

 

被压迫者教育学

Pedagogy of the Oppressed

章

CHAPTER

1

1

从价值论的角度来看，人性化问题一直是人类的核心问题，但现在它已变成一个不可避免的问题。1对 人性的关注立即导致人们认识到非人性化不仅是一种本体论可能性，而且是一种历史现实。当一个人意识到非人性的程度时，他或她可能会问人性化是否是一种可行的可能性。在历史中，在具体的客观背景下，人性化和非人性化对于一个意识到自己不完整的未完成生命的人来说都是可能的。

While the problem of humanization has always, from an axiological point of view, been humankind’s central problem, it now takes on the character of an inescapable concern.1 Concern for humanization leads at once to the recognition of dehumanization, not only as an ontological possibility but as an historical reality. And as an individual perceives the extent of dehumanization, he or she may ask if humanization is a viable possibility. Within history, in concrete, objective contexts, both humanization and dehumanization are possibilities for a person as an uncompleted being conscious of their incompletion.

但尽管人性化和非人性化都是现实的选择，但只有人性化才是人民的使命。这种使命不断被否定，但正是这种否定又肯定了它。被不公正、剥削、压迫和压迫者的暴力所挫败；被压迫者对自由和正义的渴望以及他们为恢复失去的人性而进行的斗争证实了这一点。

But while both humanization and dehumanization are real alter­-natives, only the first is the people’s vocation. This vocation is con­stantly negated, yet it is affirmed by that very negation. It is thwarted by injustice, exploitation, oppression, and the violence of the oppressors; it is affirmed by the yearning of the oppressed for ­freedom and justice, and by their struggle to recover their lost hu­-­manity.

非人化不仅标记了那些被剥夺了人性的人，也标记了那些（尽管方式不同）已经剥夺了人性的人，这是对成为更完整人性的使命的扭曲。这种扭曲在历史中发生过；但它不是历史使命。事实上，承认非人化是一种历史使命，要么会导致玩世不恭，要么会导致彻底的绝望。为人性化、为解放劳动、为克服异化、为肯定男人和女人作为人而进行的斗争将毫无意义。这场斗争之所以可能，只是因为非人化虽然是一个具体的历史事实，但它不是既定的命运，而是一种不公正秩序的结果，这种秩序导致压迫者施暴，反过来又使被压迫者失去人性。

Dehumanization, which marks not only those whose ­humanity has been stolen, but also (though in a different way) those who have stolen it, is a distortion of the vocation of becoming more fully human. This distortion occurs within history; but it is not an histori­cal vocation. Indeed, to admit of dehumanization as an historical vocation would lead either to cynicism or total despair. The struggle for humanization, for the emancipation of labor, for the ­overcoming of alienation, for the affirmation of men and women as persons would be meaningless. This struggle is possible only because dehumanization, although a concrete historical fact, is not a given ­destiny but the result of an unjust order that engenders violence in the oppressors, which in turn dehumanizes the oppressed.

因为它是对更完整的人性的扭曲，迟早，人性的丧失会导致被压迫者反抗那些让他们成为人的人。为了使这场斗争有意义，被压迫者在寻求恢复人性（这是创造人性的一种方式）时，不能反过来成为压迫者的压迫者，而是要恢复双方的人性。

Because it is a distortion of being more fully human, sooner or later being less human leads the oppressed to struggle against those who made them so. In order for this struggle to have meaning, the oppressed must not, in seeking to regain their humanity (which is a way to create it), become in turn oppressors of the oppressors, but rather restorers of the humanity of both.

因此，这就是被压迫者的伟大人文和历史任务：解放自己和压迫者。压迫者凭借权力压迫、剥削和强奸，无法从这种权力中找到解放被压迫者和自己的力量。只有从被压迫者的弱点中产生的力量才足以解放两者。任何为了尊重被压迫者的弱点而“软化”压迫者权力的企图几乎总是以虚假的慷慨的形式表现出来；事实上，这种企图从未超越这一点。为了继续有机会表达他们的“慷慨”，压迫者也必须延续不公正。不公正的社会秩序是这种“慷慨”的永久源泉，它由死亡、绝望和贫困滋养。这就是为什么虚假慷慨的传播者在其源头受到最轻微的威胁时会变得绝望的原因。

This, then, is the great humanistic and historical task of the op-pressed: to liberate themselves and their oppressors as well. The oppressors, who oppress, exploit, and rape by virtue of their power, cannot find in this power the strength to liberate either the op-pressed or themselves. Only power that springs from the weakness of the oppressed will be sufficiently strong to free both. Any attempt to “soften” the power of the oppressor in deference to the weakness of the oppressed almost always manifests itself in the form of false generosity; indeed, the attempt never goes beyond this. In order to have the continued opportunity to express their “generosity,” the oppressors must perpetuate injustice as well. An unjust social order is the permanent fount of this “generosity,” which is nourished by death, despair, and poverty. That is why the dispensers of false gen­erosity become desperate at the slightest threat to its source.

真正的慷慨恰恰在于努力摧毁滋生虚假慈善的根源。虚假慈善会迫使胆怯、屈服的人、“被生活抛弃的人”伸出颤抖的双手。真正的慷慨在于努力使这些双手——无论是个人还是整个民族——越来越少地需要伸出来祈求，以便它们越来越多地成为工作并改变世界的人类之手。

True generosity consists precisely in fighting to destroy the causes which nourish false charity. False charity constrains the fearful and subdued, the “rejects of life,” to extend their trembling hands. True generosity lies in striving so that these hands—whether of individuals or entire peoples—need be extended less and less in supplica­-tion, so that more and more they become human hands which work and, working, transform the world.

然而，这种教训和这种学识必须来自被压迫者自己和那些真正与他们团结一致的人。作为个人或民族，通过为恢复人性而斗争，他们将试图恢复真正的慷慨。谁比被压迫者更能理解压迫社会的可怕意义？谁比被压迫者遭受压迫的影响更大？谁能更好地理解解放的必要性？他们不会偶然获得这种解放，而是通过他们寻求解放的实践，通过他们认识到为之奋斗的必要性。而这场斗争，由于被压迫者赋予的目的，实际上将构成一种爱的行为，反对压迫者暴力的核心——无爱，即使披着虚假的慷慨，也是无爱。

This lesson and this apprenticeship must come, however, from the oppressed themselves and from those who are truly solidary with them. As individuals or as peoples, by fighting for the restoration of their humanity they will be attempting the restoration of true generosity. Who are better prepared than the oppressed to understand the terrible significance of an oppressive society? Who suffer the effects of oppression more than the oppressed? Who can ­better understand the necessity of liberation? They will not gain this liberation by chance but through the praxis of their quest for it, through their recognition of the necessity to fight for it. And this fight, be-cause of the purpose given it by the oppressed, will actually constitute an act of love opposing the lovelessness which lies at the heart of the oppressors’ violence, lovelessness even when clothed in false generosity.

但在斗争的初始阶段，被压迫者几乎总是倾向于成为压迫者或“次级压迫者”，而不是争取解放。他们思想的结构本身就受到塑造他们的具体生存环境的矛盾制约。他们的理想是成为人；但对他们来说，成为人就是成为压迫者。这是他们的人性模式。这种现象源于这样一个事实：被压迫者在生存体验的某一时刻对压迫者采取了“依附”的态度。在这种情况下，他们无法足够清楚地“考虑”压迫者，以客观化压迫者——在他们“之外”发现压迫者。这并不一定意味着被压迫者没有意识到他们被压迫了。但他们对自己被压迫的认识因他们沉浸在压迫的现实中而受到损害。在这个层面上，他们认为自己是压迫者的对立面，但这种认识还没有象征着参与克服矛盾的斗争；2 一极并不渴望解放，而是渴望与对立极的认同。

But almost always, during the initial stage of the struggle, the oppressed, instead of striving for liberation, tend themselves to be-come oppressors, or “sub-oppressors.” The very structure of their thought has been conditioned by the contradictions of the ­concrete, existential situation by which they were shaped. Their ideal is to be men; but for them, to be men is to be oppressors. This is their model of humanity. This phenomenon derives from the fact that the oppressed, at a certain moment of their existential experience, adopt an attitude of “adhesion” to the oppressor. Under these circum-stances they cannot “consider” him sufficiently clearly to objectivize him—to discover him “outside” themselves. This does not necessar-ily mean that the oppressed are unaware that they are ­downtrodden. But their perception of themselves as oppressed is impaired by their submersion in the reality of oppression. At this level, their ­perception of themselves as opposites of the oppressor does not yet signify engagement in a struggle to overcome the contradiction;2 the one pole aspires not to liberation, but to identification with its opposite pole.

在这种情况下，被压迫者并不认为“新人”是解决这一矛盾后诞生的人，因为压迫让位于解放。对他们来说，新人本身就是压迫者。他们对新人的看法是个人主义的；由于他们认同压迫者，他们没有意识到自己是人或被压迫阶级的成员。他们想要土地改革不是为了获得自由，而是为了获得土地，从而成为土地所有者——或者更确切地说，成为其他工人的老板。很少有农民在“晋升”为监工后，对他以前的同志不比主人更暴虐。这是因为农民所处境遇的背景，即压迫，没有改变。在这个例子中，监工为了确保自己的工作，必须像主人一样强硬——甚至更过分。这证明了我们先前的断言，在斗争的最初阶段，被压迫者在压迫者身上找到了“男子气概”的典范。

In this situation the oppressed do not see the “new man” as the ­person to be born from the resolution of this contradiction, as op-pression gives way to liberation. For them, the new man or woman themselves become oppressors. Their vision of the new man or woman is individualistic; because of their identification with the oppressor, they have no consciousness of themselves as persons or as members of an oppressed class. It is not to become free that they want agrarian reform, but in order to acquire land and t hus become landowners—or, more precisely, bosses over other workers. It is a rare peasant who, once “promoted” to overseer, does not become more of a tyrant towards his former comrades than the owner himself. This is because the context of the peasant’s situation, that is, oppression, remains unchanged. In this example, the overseer, in order to make sure of his job, must be as tough as the owner—and more so. Thus is illustrated our previous assertion that during the initial stage of their struggle the oppressed find in the oppressor their model of “manhood.”

即使是革命，通过建立解放进程来改变具体的压迫状况，也必须面对这一现象。许多直接或间接参与革命的被压迫者，在旧秩序神话的制约下，打算将其作为私人革命。他们以前的压迫者的阴影仍然笼罩着他们。

Even revolution, which transforms a concrete situation of oppression by establishing the process of liberation, must confront this phenomenon. Many of the oppressed who directly or indirectly participate in revolution intend—conditioned by the myths of the old order—to make it their private revolution. The shadow of their former oppressor is still cast over them.

被压迫者所遭受的“对自由的恐惧” 3 应该被审视，这种恐惧同样可能导致他们渴望扮演压迫者的角色，也可能使他们被束缚于被压迫者的角色。压迫者与被压迫者之间关系的基本要素之一是­处方。每一份处方都代表着一个人的选择强加于另一个人，将被处方者的意识转变为符合处方者意识的意识。因此，被压迫者的行为是一种规定的行为，因为它遵循压迫者的指导方针。

The “fear of freedom” which afflicts the oppressed,3 a fear which may equally well lead them to desire the role of oppressor or bind them to the role of oppressed, should be examined. One of the basic elements of the relationship between oppressor and oppressed is ­prescription. Every prescription represents the imposition of one individual’s choice upon another, transforming the ­consciousness of the person prescribed to into one that conforms with the pre­-scriber’s consciousness. Thus, the behavior of the oppressed is a ­prescribed behavior, following as it does the guidelines of the op-­pressor.

被压迫者内化了压迫者的形象并采纳了他的指导方针，因此他们害怕自由。自由要求他们抛弃这种形象，代之以自主和责任。自由是通过征服而不是礼物获得的。必须不断负责任地追求自由。自由不是人之外的理想；也不是神话。相反，它是追求人类完善的必不可少的条件。

The oppressed, having internalized the image of the oppressor and adopted his guidelines, are fearful of freedom. Freedom would require them to eject this image and replace it with autonomy and responsibility. Freedom is acquired by conquest, not by gift. It must be pursued constantly and responsibly. Freedom is not an ideal located outside of man; nor is it an idea which becomes myth. It is rather the indispensable condition for the quest for human com­pletion.

为了克服压迫的处境，人们首先必须批判地认识其原因，以便通过变革行动创造一种新的处境，使追求更完整的人性成为可能。但是，在改变处境的真正斗争中，成为更完整的人的斗争已经开始了。虽然压迫的处境是一个非人性化和非人性化的整体，影响着压迫者和被压迫者，但后者必须从其被压抑的人性出发，为实现更完整的人性而斗争；压迫者由于使他人非人化而自己被非人化，无法领导这场斗争。

To surmount the situation of oppression, people must first critically recognize its causes, so that through transforming action they can create a new situation, one which makes possible the pursuit of a fuller humanity. But the struggle to be more fully human has already begun in the authentic struggle to transform the situation. Although the situation of oppression is a dehumanized and dehumanizing totality affecting both the oppressors and those whom they oppress, it is the latter who must, from their stifled humanity, wage for both the struggle for a fuller humanity; the oppressor, who is himself dehumanized because he dehumanizes others, is unable to lead this struggle.

然而，被压迫者已经适应了他们所处的统治结构，并对其习以为常，只要他们感到无法承担必要的风险，他们就无法进行争取自由的斗争。此外，他们争取自由的斗争不仅威胁着压迫者，也威胁着他们自己被压迫的同志，因为后者害怕受到更大的压迫。当他们发现自己内心渴望自由时，他们意识到，只有当他们的同志们也怀有同样的渴望时，这种渴望才能变成现实。但是，当他们被对自由的恐惧所支配时，他们拒绝向其他人求助，他们宁愿选择群居，而不愿选择真正的友谊；他们宁愿选择与不自由状态相一致的安全感，而不愿选择自由所产生的创造性交流，甚至不愿选择对自由的追求。

However, the oppressed, who have adapted to the structure of domination in which they are immersed, and have become resigned to it, are inhibited from waging the struggle for freedom so long as they feel incapable of running the risks it requires. Moreover, their struggle for freedom threatens not only the oppressor, but also their own oppressed comrades who are fearful of still greater repression. When they discover within themselves the yearning to be free, they perceive that this yearning can be transformed into reality only when the same yearning is aroused in their comrades. But while dominated by the fear of freedom they refuse to appeal to others, or to listen to the appeals of others, or even to the appeals of their own conscience. They prefer gregariousness to authentic comradeship; they prefer the security of conformity with their state of unfreedom to the creative communion produced by freedom and even the very pursuit of freedom.

被压迫者遭受着内心深处的二元性。他们发现，没有自由，他们就无法真实地存在。然而，尽管他们渴望真实存在，但他们却害怕它。他们既是自己，又是他们内化了压迫者的意识。冲突在于选择完全做自己还是分裂自己；选择驱逐内心的压迫者还是不驱逐他们；选择人类团结还是疏远；选择遵循规定还是有选择；选择旁观者还是演员；选择行动还是幻想通过压迫者的行为行动；选择直言不讳还是保持沉默，他们被剥夺了创造和再创造的力量，被剥夺了改变世界的力量。这是被压迫者的悲剧性困境，他们的教育必须考虑到这一点。

The oppressed suffer from the duality which has established itself in their innermost being. They discover that without freedom they cannot exist authentically. Yet, although they desire authentic existence, they fear it. They are at one and the same time themselves and the oppressor whose consciousness they have internalized. The conflict lies in the choice between being wholly themselves or being divided; between ejecting the oppressor within or not ejecting them; between human solidarity or alienation; between following prescriptions or having choices; between being spectators or actors; between acting or having the illusion of acting through the action of the oppressors; between speaking out or being silent, castrated in their power to create and re-create, in their power to transform the world. This is the tragic dilemma of the oppressed which their education must take into account.

本书将介绍作者所称的被压迫者教育学的一些方面，这种教育学必须与被压迫者（无论是个人还是民族）一起在为恢复人性而进行的不懈斗争中形成，而不是为他们而形成。这种教育学使压迫及其原因成为被压迫者反思的对象，而这种反思将使他们必然参与争取解放的斗争。在斗争中，这种教育学将被形成和重塑。

This book will present some aspects of what the writer has termed the pedagogy of the oppressed, a pedagogy which must be forged with, not for, the oppressed (whether individuals or peoples) in the incessant struggle to regain their humanity. This pedagogy makes oppression and its causes objects of reflection by the oppressed, and from that reflection will come their necessary engagement in the struggle for their liberation. And in the struggle this pedagogy will be made and remade.

核心问题是：作为分裂的、不真实的存在，被压迫者如何参与发展他们的解放教育学？只有当他们发现自己是压迫者的“主人”时，他们才能为解放教育学的助产做出贡献。只要他们生活在二元对立中，即存在就是被压迫者，被压迫就是被压迫者，这种贡献就是不可能的。被压迫者的教育学是他们批判性地发现他们和压迫者都是非人性化表现的工具。

The central problem is this: How can the oppressed, as divided, unauthentic beings, participate in developing the pedagogy of their liberation? Only as they discover themselves to be “hosts” of the oppressor can they contribute to the midwifery of their ­liberating pedagogy. As long as they live in the duality in which to be is to be like, and to be like is to be like the oppressor, this contribution is ­impossible. The pedagogy of the oppressed is an instrument for their ­critical discovery that both they and their oppressors are manifestations of dehumanization.

因此，解放是一场分娩，而且是一场痛苦的分娩。诞生出的男人或女人都是一个新人，只有当压迫者与被压迫者的矛盾被所有人的人性化所取代时，他才有生命力。或者换句话说，这一矛盾的解决方案诞生于劳动中，劳动将这个新生命带到这个世界：不再是压迫者，也不再是被压迫者，而是在实现自由的过程中成为人。

Liberation is thus a childbirth, and a painful one. The man or woman who emerges is a new person, viable only as the oppressor-oppressed contradiction is superseded by the humanization of all people. Or to put it another way, the solution of this contradiction is born in the labor which brings into the world this new being: no longer oppressor nor longer oppressed, but human in the process of achieving freedom.

这一解决方案无法以理想主义的方式实现。为了使被压迫者能够为自己的解放而斗争，他们必须将压迫的现实视为一个封闭的、没有出口的世界，而将其视为一种他们可以改变的限制性情况。这种认识是解放的必要条件，但不是充分条件；它必须成为解放行动的动力。被压迫者发现他们与压迫者之间存在辩证关系，压迫者与压迫者是对立的——没有他们，压迫者就不可能存在4 ——这本身并不构成解放。只有当这种认识促使被压迫者参与解放自己的斗争时，他们才能克服陷入的矛盾。

This solution cannot be achieved in idealistic terms. In order for the oppressed to be able to wage the struggle for their liberation, they must perceive the reality of oppression not as a closed world from which there is no exit, but as a limiting situation which they can transform. This perception is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for liberation; it must become the motivating force for ­liberating action. Nor does the discovery by the oppressed that they exist in dialectical relationship to the oppressor, as his antithesis—that without them the oppressor could not exist4 —in itself constitute liberation. The oppressed can overcome the contradiction in which they are caught only when this perception enlists them in the struggle to free themselves.

对于个人压迫者而言，情况也是如此。发现自己是压迫者可能会带来相当大的痛苦，但这不一定会导致与被压迫者团结一致。通过对被压迫者采取家长式的对待来合理化他的罪责，同时让他们始终处于依赖地位，这是行不通的。团结要求一个人进入与自己团结一致的人的处境；这是一种激进的姿态。如果被压迫者的特征是他们对主人意识的服从，正如黑格尔所言，5 与被压迫者的真正团结意味着与他们并肩作战，改变使他们成为“他人的存在”的客观现实。压迫者只有当索尔不再把被压迫者视为一个抽象的范畴，而是把他们视为受到不公正对待、被剥夺发言权、在出卖劳动力时被欺骗的人时，当他不再做出虔诚、多愁善感和个人主义的姿态，而冒险做出爱的行为时，他才会与被压迫者团结一致。真正的团结只有在这种爱的行为的充实性、它的存在性和它的实践性中才能找到。断言男人和女人都是人，作为人应该是自由的，却没有采取任何切实的行动将这一断言变为现实，这是一场闹剧。

The same is true with re spect to the individual oppressor as a ­person. Discovering himself to be an oppressor may cause consider­able anguish, but it does not necessarily lead to solidarity with the oppressed. Rationalizing his guilt through paternalistic treatment of the oppressed, all the while holding them fast in a position of dependence, will not do. Solidarity requires that one enter into the situation of those with whom one is solidary; it is a radical posture. If what characterizes the oppressed is their subordination to the ­consciousness of the master, as Hegel affirms,5 true solidarity with the oppressed means fighting at their side to transform the ­objective reality which has made them these “beings for another.” The oppres­sor is solidary with the oppressed only when he stops regarding the oppressed as an abstract category and sees them as persons who have been unjustly dealt with, deprived of their voice, cheated in the sale of their labor—when he stops making pious, sentimental, and individualistic gestures and risks an act of love. True solidarity is found only in the plenitude of this act of love, in its ­existentiality, in its praxis. To affirm that men and women are persons and as ­persons should be free, and yet to do nothing tangible to make this affirmation a reality, is a farce.

压迫者与被压迫者之间的矛盾是建立在具体情境上的，因此，这一矛盾的解决必须得到客观验证。因此，对于发现自己是压迫者的个人和被压迫者而言，根本要求就是必须改变产生压迫的具体情境。

Since it is a concrete situation that the oppressor-oppressed contradiction is established, the resolution of this contradiction must be objectively verifiable. Hence, the radical requirement—both for the individual who discovers himself or herself to be an oppressor and for the oppressed—that the concrete situation which begets oppression must be transformed.

提出这一对现实进行客观改造的激进要求，与主观主义的僵化作斗争，这种僵化会将对压迫的认识转变为耐心等待压迫自行消失，这并不是在否认主观性在改变结构的斗争中的作用。相反，没有主观性，就不可能设想客观性。两者不能没有对方而存在，也不能二分。客观性与主观性的分离，在分析现实或对现实采取行动时否认后者，是客观主义。另一方面，在分析或行动中否认客观性，导致一种导致唯我论立场的主观主义，通过否认客观现实来否认行动本身。这里提出的既不是客观主义，也不是主观主义，也不是心理主义，而是主观性和客观性的不断辩证关系。

To present this radical demand for the objective ­transformation of reality, to combat subjectivist immobility which would divert the ­recognition of oppression into patient waiting for oppression to dis­­appear by itself, is not to dismiss the role of subjectivity in the ­struggle to change structures. On the contrary, one cannot ­conceive of objectivity without subjectivity. Neither can exist without the other, nor can they be dichotomized. The separation of ­objectivity from subjectivity, the denial of the latter when analyzing reality or acting upon it, is objectivism. On the other hand, the denial of ­objectivity in analysis or action, resulting in a subjectivism which leads to solipsistic positions, denies action itself by denying objec­tive reality. Neither objectivism nor subjectivism, nor yet psychologism is propounded here, but rather subjectivity and objectivity in constant dialectical relationship.

否认主观性在改造世界和历史过程中的重要性是幼稚和简单化的。这是承认不可能的事情：一个没有人的世界。这种客观主义立场与主观主义立场一样天真，后者假定没有人。世界和人类并不是彼此独立存在的，而是在不断的相互作用中存在的。马克思并不主张这种二分法，任何其他批判的、现实的思想家也没有。马克思批判的和科学地摧毁的不是主观性，而是主观主义和心理主义。正如客观社会现实不是偶然存在的，而是人类行动的产物，它也不是偶然改变的。如果人类创造了社会现实（在“实践的颠倒”中，社会现实反过来影响人类并制约人类），那么改变这种现实就是一项历史任务，是人类的任务。

To deny the importance of subjectivity in the process of transforming the world and history is naive and simplistic. It is to admit the impossible: a world without people. This objectivistic position is as ingenuous as that of subjectivism, which postulates people without a world. World and human beings do not exist apart from each other, they exist in constant interaction. Marx does not espouse such a dichotomy, nor does any other critical, realistic thinker. What Marx criticized and scientifically destroyed was not subjectivity, but subjectivism and psychologism. Just as objective social reality exists not by chance, but as the product of human action, so it is not ­transformed by chance. If humankind produce social reality (which in the “inversion of the praxis” turns back upon them and conditions them), then transforming that reality is an historical task, a task for humanity.

压迫性的现实导致了压迫者和被压迫者的对立。被压迫者的任务是与那些真正团结的人一起为自己的解放而斗争，他们必须通过斗争的实践获得对压迫的批判意识。实现解放的最大障碍之一是压迫性现实吸收了其中的人们，从而淹没了人类的意识。6从 功能上讲，压迫是驯服的。为了不再成为压迫力量的牺牲品，人们必须摆脱它并转向它。这只能通过实践来实现：反思和行动以改变世界。

Reality which becomes oppressive results in the ­contradistinction of men as oppressors and oppressed. The latter, whose task it is to struggle for their liberation together with those who show true solidarity, must acquire a critical awareness of oppression through the praxis of this struggle. One of the gravest obstacles to the ­achievement of liberation is that oppressive reality absorbs those within it and thereby acts to submerge human beings’ consiousness.6 Functionally, oppression is domesticating. To no longer be prey to its force, one must emerge from it and turn upon it. This can be done only by means of the praxis: reflection and action upon the world in order to transform it.

他是真正的压迫者，他是一个真正的压迫者，他与压迫者的友好关系是他的耻辱，是他的耻辱。7

Hay que hacer al opresión real todavía mas opresiva añadiendo a aquella la conciéncia de la opresión haciendo la infamia todavía mas infamante, al pregonarla.7

“通过增加压迫的实现，使现实压迫更加压迫”符合主观与客观的辩证关系。只有在这种相互依存中，真正的实践才有可能，没有这种相互依存，就不可能实现解决压迫者与被压迫者之间的矛盾。为了实现这一目标，被压迫者必须批判性地面对现实，同时客观化现实并根据现实采取行动。单纯的现实感知如果不经过批判性干预，不会导致客观现实的转变——恰恰因为它不是真正的感知。这是纯粹主观主义感知的情况，即某人抛弃客观现实并创造了虚假的替代品。

Making “real oppression more oppressive still by adding to it the realization of oppression” corresponds to the dialectical relation between the subjective and the objective. Only in this interdepen­dence is an authentic praxis possible, without which it is ­impossible to resolve the oppressor-oppressed contradiction. To achieve this goal, the oppressed must confront reality critically, simultaneously objectifying and acting upon that reality. A mere perception of real­-ity not followed by this critical intervention will not lead to a transformation of objective reality—precisely because it is not a true ­perception. This is the case of a purely subjectivist perception by someone who forsakes objective reality and creates a false substitute.

当客观现实的变化威胁到感知者的个人或阶级利益时，就会出现另一种类型的错误感知。在第一种情况下，现实中没有批判性干预，因为现实是虚构的；在第二种情况下，没有干预，因为干预会与感知者的阶级利益相矛盾。在后一种情况下，感知者倾向于“神经质地”行事。事实是存在的；但事实及其可能的结果都可能对人有害。因此，有必要不否认事实，而是“以不同的方式看待事实”。这种合理化作为一种​​防御机制，最终与主观主义相吻合。一个没有被否认但其真理被合理化的事实失去了客观基础。它不再是具体的，而是变成了为捍卫感知者的阶级而创造的神话。

A different type of false perception occurs when a change in objec­-tive reality would threaten the individual or class interests of the ­perceiver. In the first instance, there is no critical intervention in reality because that reality is fictitious; there is none in the second instance because intervention would contradict the class interests of the perceiver. In the latter case the tendency of the perceiver is to behave “neurotically.” The fact exists; but both the fact and what may result from it may be prejudicial to the person. Thus it becomes necessary, not precisely to deny the fact, but to “see it differently.” This rationalization as a defense mechanism coincides in the end with subjectivism. A fact which is not denied but whose truths are rationalized loses its objective base. It ceases to be concrete and becomes a myth created in defense of the class of the perceiver.

这正是禁止和设置障碍的原因之一（第 4 章将详细讨论），目的是劝阻人民不要对现实进行批判性干预。压迫者非常清楚，这种干预不符合他的利益。符合他的利益的是让人民继续处于淹没状态，在压迫性现实面前无能为力。卢卡奇对革命党的警告与此相关：

Herein lies one of the reasons for the prohibitions and the difficulties (to be discussed at length in Chapter 4) designed to dissuade the people from critical intervention in reality. The oppressor knows full well that this intervention would not be to his interest. What is to his interest is for the people to continue in a state of submersion, impotent in the face of oppressive reality. Of relevance here is Lu­-kács’ warning to the revolutionary party:

。 。 。在此，马克思的雇主们指出，群众的适当行动不能保证无产阶级革命经验的延续，也可以成为无产阶级革命经验发展的积极主动者。8

. . . il doit, pour employer les mots de Marx, expliquer aux masses leur propre action non seulement afin d’assurer la continuité des expériences révolutionnaires du prolétariat, mais aussi d’activer consciemment le développement ultérieur de ces expériences.8

在肯定这种必要性时，卢卡奇毫无疑问地提出了批判性干预的问题。“向群众解释他们自己的行动”就是要澄清和阐明这种行动，既要澄清和阐明它与促使它发生的客观事实的关系，也要澄清和阐明它的目的。人们越是揭露这种具有挑战性的现实，即他们变革行动的对象，他们就越批判地进入这种现实。这样，他们就“有意识地激活了他们经验的后续发展”。如果没有客观现实，就没有人类行动，没有世界成为人的“非我”并挑战他们；就像如果人类不是一个“项目”，如果他或她不能超越自己，如果一个人不能感知现实并理解现实以改变它，就不会有人类行动一样。

In affirming this necessity, Lukács is unquestionably posing the problem of critical intervention. “To explain to the masses their own action” is to clarify and illuminate that action, both regarding its ­relationship to the objective facts by which it was prompted, and regarding its purposes. The more the people unveil this ­challenging reality which is to be the object of their transforming action, the more critically they enter that reality. In this way they are “consciously activating the subsequent development of their experi­-ences.” There would be no human action if there were no objective reality, no world to be the “not I” of the person and to challenge them; just as there would be no human action if humankind were not a “project,” if he or she were not able to transcend himself or herself, if one were not able to perceive reality and understand it in order to transform it.

在辩证思维中，世界和行动是紧密依存的。但只有当行动不仅仅是一种职业，而且是一种专注时，即当它不与反思二分时，它才是人性的。反思是行动的本质，它隐含在卢卡奇“向群众解释他们自己的行动”的要求中，就像它隐含在他赋予这种解释的目的中一样：即“有意识地激活随后的经验发展”。

In dialectical thought, world and action are intimately interdepen­dent. But action is human only when it is not merely an ­occupation but also a preoccupation, that is, when it is not dichotomized from reflection. Reflection, which is essential to action, is implicit in Lu-kács’ requirement of “explaining to the masses their own action,” just as it is implicit in the purpose he attributes to this explanation: that of “consciously activating the subsequent development of experience.”

然而，对我们来说，要求不是向人民解释，而是与人民对话。无论如何，现实不会自我改变，9 卢卡奇赋予革命党“向群众解释自己的行动”的责任与我们肯定人民通过实践对现实进行批判性干预的必要性相一致。被压迫者的教育学，即为争取自身解放而斗争的人民的教育学，就源于此。那些认识或开始认识自己的人作为被压迫者，必须成为这种教育学的开发者之一。任何真正解放的教育学都不能通过把被压迫者视为不幸者，并从压迫者中为他们树立榜样来与他们保持距离。被压迫者在为救赎而斗争中必须成为自己的榜样。

For us, however, the requirement is seen not in terms of ex-plaining to, but rather dialoguing with the people about their ac-tions. In any event, no reality transforms itself,9 and the duty which Lukács ascribes to the revolutionary party of “explaining to the masses their own action” coincides with our affirmation of the need for the critical intervention of the people in reality through the praxis. The pedagogy of the oppressed, which is the pedagogy of people engaged in the fight for their own liberation, has its roots here. And those who recognize, or begin to recognize, themselves as oppressed must be among the developers of this pedagogy. No pedagogy which is truly liberating can remain distant from the op-pressed by treating them as unfortunates and by presenting for their emulation models from among the oppressors. The oppressed must be their own example in the struggle for their redemption.

被压迫者的教育学，以真正的、人文主义（而非人道主义）的慷慨为动力，表现为人类的教育学。教育学从压迫者的利己主义利益出发（一种披着家长式虚假慷慨外衣的利己主义），并将被压迫者作为人道主义的对象，它本身就维护和体现了压迫。它是一种非人性化的工具。这就是为什么，正如我们之前所肯定的，被压迫者的教育学不能由压迫者发展或实践。如果压迫者不仅捍卫而且实际上实施了解放教育，那将是一个矛盾的说法。

The pedagogy of the oppressed, animated by authentic, ­humanist (not humanitarian) generosity, presents itself as a pedagogy of humankind. Pedagogy which begins with the egoistic interests of the oppressors (an egoism cloaked in the false generosity of paternal­ism) and makes of the oppressed the objects of its ­humanitarianism, itself maintains and embodies oppression. It is an instrument of dehumanization. This is why, as we affirmed earlier, the pedagogy of the oppressed cannot be developed or practiced by the oppressors. It would be a contradiction in terms if the oppressors not only defended but actually implemented a liberating education.

但是，如果实施解放教育需要政治权力，而被压迫者却没有政治权力，那么在革命之前如何才能对被压迫者进行教育呢？这是一个非常重要的问题，对此的回答至少在第 4 章中进行了初步概述。答案的一个方面是区分系统教育和教育项目，前者只能通过政治权力来改变，后者应该在组织被压迫者的过程中与他们一起实施。

But if the implementation of a liberating education requires politi-cal power and the oppressed have none, how then is it possible to carry out the pedagogy of the oppressed prior to the revolution? This is a question of the greatest importance, the reply to which is at least tentatively outlined in Chapter 4. One aspect of the reply is to be found in the distinction between systematic education, which can only be changed by political power, and educational proj­ects, which should be carried out with the oppressed in the process of organizing them.

被压迫者教育学是一种人文主义和自由主义教育学，它有两个不同的阶段。在第一阶段，被压迫者揭露了压迫的世界，并通过实践致力于改造它。在第二阶段，压迫的现实已经改变，这种教育学不再属于被压迫者，而是成为永久解放过程中所有人的教育学。在这两个阶段，总是通过深入的行动来文化对抗统治文化。10在 第一阶段，这种对抗发生在被压迫者对压迫世界的看法发生改变；在第二阶段，通过驱逐旧秩序中创造和发展起来的神话，这些神话就像幽灵一样困扰着革命变革中出现的新结构。

The pedagogy of the oppressed, as a humanist and libertarian ­pedagogy, has two distinct stages. In the first, the oppressed unveil the world of oppression and through the praxis commit themselves to its transformation. In the second stage, in which the reality of oppression has already been transformed, this pedagogy ceases to belong to the oppressed and becomes a pedagogy of all people in the process of permanent liberation. In both stages, it is always through action in depth that the culture of domination is culturally confronted.10 In the first stage this confrontation occurs through the change in the way the oppressed perceive the world of ­oppression; in the second stage, through the expulsion of the myths created and developed in the old order, which like specters haunt the new structure emerging from the revolutionary transformation.

第一阶段的教育必须处理被压迫者意识和压迫者意识的问题，压迫者和遭受压迫的男女的问题。它必须考虑到他们的行为、他们的世界观和他们的道德观。一个特别的问题是被压迫者的二元性：他们是矛盾的、分裂的存在，由压迫和暴力的具体情况塑造并存在于其中。

The pedagogy of the first stage must deal with the problem of the oppressed consciousness and the oppressor consciousness, the problem of men and women who oppress and men and women who suffer oppression. It must take into account their behavior, their view of the world, and their ethics. A particular problem is the ­duality of the oppressed: they are contradictory, divided beings, shaped by and existing in a concrete situation of oppression and ­violence.

任何“A”客观上剥削“B”或阻碍他/她追求作为负责任的人的自我肯定的情况都是压迫。这种情况本身就构成了暴力，即使被虚假的慷慨所美化，因为它干扰了个人成为更完整的人性的本体论和历史使命。随着压迫关系的建立，暴力已经开始。历史上从未有暴力是由被压迫者发起的。如果他们自己就是暴力的结果，他们怎么会是发起者？他们怎么会成为某件事的赞助者，而这件事的客观发起者是他们被压迫的存在？如果没有先前的暴力情况来确立他们的奴役，就不会有被压迫者。

Any situation in which “A” objectively exploits “B” or hinders his and her pursuit of self-affirmation as a responsible person is one of oppression. Such a situation in itself constitutes violence, even when sweetened by false generosity, because it interferes with the individ­ual’s ontological and historical vocation to be more fully human. With the establishment of a relationship of oppression, violence has already begun. Never in history has violence been initiated by the oppressed. How could they be the initiators, if they themselves are the result of violence? How could they be the sponsors of ­something whose objective inauguration called forth their existence as op-pressed? There would be no oppressed had there been no prior ­situation of violence to establish their subjugation.

暴力是由压迫者、剥削者、不承认他人为人的人发起的，而不是由被压迫者、被剥削者和不被承认者发起的。发起不满的不是那些不被爱的人，而是那些因为只爱自己而不能爱的人。发起恐怖的不是无助的、受恐怖支配的人，而是暴力者，他们用自己的权力创造了导致“生命被抛弃者”的具体情况。发起专制的不是被压迫者，而是暴君。发起仇恨的不是被鄙视者，而是那些鄙视他人的人。否定人类的不是那些被剥夺了人性的人，而是那些否定人性（从而也否定了他们自己的人性）的人。使用武力的不是那些他们在强者的压迫下变得软弱，但强者却削弱了他们。

Violence is initiated by those who oppress, who exploit, who fail to recognize others as persons—not by those who are oppressed, exploited, and unrecognized. It is not the unloved who initiate disaf­fection, but those who cannot love because they love only them­-selves. It is not the helpless, subject to terror, who initiate terror, but the violent, who with their power create the concrete situation which begets the “rejects of life.” It is not the tyrannized who initiate despotism, but the tyrants. It is not the despised who initiate hatred, but those who despise. It is not those whose humanity is denied them who negate humankind, but those who denied that humanity (thus negating their own as well). Force is used not by those who have become weak under the preponderance of the strong, but by the strong who have emasculated them.

然而，对于压迫者来说，被压迫者（他们显然从不称其为“被压迫者”，而是——根据他们是否是同胞——称其为“那些人”或“盲目嫉妒的群众”或“野蛮人”或“土著人”或“颠覆分子”）总是心怀不满的，当他们对压迫者的暴力作出反应时，他们是“暴力的”、“野蛮的”、“邪恶的”或“凶猛的”。

For the oppressors, however, it is always the oppressed (whom they obviously never call “the oppressed” but—depending on whether they are fellow countrymen or not—“those people” or “the blind and envious masses” or “savages” or “natives” or ­“subversives”) who are disaffected, who are “violent,” “barbaric,” “wicked,” or “fe-rocious” when they react to the violence of the oppressors.

然而，尽管这看起来有些矛盾，但正是在被压迫者对压迫者暴力的反应中，我们可以看到爱的姿态。被压迫者的反抗行为（这种行为总是或几乎总是与压迫者最初的暴力一样暴力）可以自觉或不自觉地引发爱。压迫者的暴力使被压迫者无法成为完全的人，而后者对这种暴力的反应则基于追求做人权利的愿望。当压迫者将他人非人化并侵犯他们的权利时，他们自己也变得非人化了。当被压迫者为成为人而战，夺走了压迫者的统治和镇压权力时，他们恢复了压迫者在压迫中失去的人性。

Yet it is—paradoxical though it may seem—precisely in the re-sponse of the oppressed to the violence of their oppressors that a ­gesture of love may be found. Consciously or unconsciously, the act of rebellion by the oppressed (an act which is always, or nearly always, as violent as the initial violence of the oppressors) can initiate love. Whereas the violence of the oppressors prevents the oppressed from being fully human, the response of the latter to this violence is grounded in the desire to pursue the right to be human. As the oppressors dehumanize others and violate their rights, they themselves also become dehumanized. As the oppressed, fighting to be human, take away the oppressors’ power to dominate and suppress, they restore to the oppressors the humanity they had lost in the ­exercise of oppression.

只有被压迫者通过解放自己才能解放压迫者。压迫者作为一个压迫阶级，既不能解放他人也不能解放自己。因此，被压迫者必须进行斗争来解决他们所处的矛盾；矛盾将通过新人的出现而得到解决：既不是压迫者也不是被压迫者，而是处于解放过程中的人。如果被压迫者的目标是成为完全的人，那么他们不会仅仅通过逆转矛盾的条件、简单地改变两极来实现他们的目标。

It is only the oppressed who, by freeing themselves, can free their oppressors. The latter, as an oppressive class, can free neither ­others nor themselves. It is therefore essential that the oppressed wage the struggle to resolve the contradiction in which they are caught; and the contradiction will be resolved by the appearance of the new man: neither oppressor nor oppressed, but man in the process of ­liberation. If the goal of the oppressed is to become fully human, they will not achieve their goal by merely reversing the terms of the contradiction, by simply changing poles.

这似乎过于简单，但事实并非如此。压迫者与被压迫者矛盾的解决确实意味着压迫者作为统治阶级的消失。然而，前者被压迫者对压迫者施加的限制，使后者无法恢复其原有的地位，并不构成压迫。只有当它阻止人们成为更完整的人时，它才是压迫性的。因此，这些必要的限制本身并不意味着昨天的被压迫者已成为今天的压迫者。防止压迫政权复辟的行为不能与建立和维持压迫政权的行为相提并论，也不能与少数男女剥夺大多数人作为人的权利的行为相提并论。

This may seem simplistic; it is not. Resolution of the oppressor-oppressed contradiction indeed implies the disappearance of the oppressors as a dominant class. However, the restraints imposed by the former oppressed on their oppressors, so that the latter cannot reassume their former position, do not constitute oppression. An act is oppressive only when it prevents people from being more fully human. Accordingly, these necessary restraints do not in themselves signify that yesterday’s oppressed have become today’s oppressors. Acts which prevent the restoration of the oppressive regime ­cannot be compared with those which create and maintain it, cannot be compared with those by which a few men and women deny the majority their right to be human.

然而，一旦新政权固化为一个占统治地位的“官僚机构” 11， 斗争的人道主义维度就消失了，再也不可能谈论解放了。因此，我们坚持认为，压迫者与被压迫者矛盾的真正解决不在于仅仅颠倒立场，不在于从一极转向另一极。也不在于用新的压迫者取代以前的压迫者，而新的压迫者继续以解放的名义奴役被压迫者。

However, the moment the new regime hardens into a ­dominating “bureaucracy”11 the humanist dimension of the struggle is lost and it is no longer possible to speak of liberation. Hence our insistence that the authentic solution of the oppressor-oppressed ­contradiction does not lie in a mere reversal of position, in moving from one pole to the other. Nor does it lie in the replacement of the ­former oppressors with new ones who continue to subjugate the op-pressed—all in the name of their liberation.

但是，即使当被解放的劳动者建立起新的环境，矛盾得以真正解决时，昔日的压迫者也不会感到解放。相反，他们真正认为自己受到了压迫。在压迫他人的经历的制约下，任何不同于他们以前所处的环境对他们来说都像是压迫。以前，他们可以吃饭、穿衣服、穿鞋、接受教育、旅行和听贝多芬的音乐；而数百万人却没有吃饭、没有衣服或鞋子，既不学习也不旅行，更不用说听贝多芬的音乐了。以社区权利的名义对这种生活方式的任何限制，在昔日的压迫者看来都是对他们个人权利的严重侵犯——尽管他们并不尊重数百万因饥饿、痛苦、悲伤和绝望而受苦和死亡的人。对于压迫者来说，“人”仅指他们自己；其他人是“物”。对于压迫者来说，只有一项权利：他们有权和平地生活，而不是被压迫。被压迫者生存的权利，虽然并不总是被承认，但只是被承认而已。他们之所以做出这种让步，只是因为被压迫者的存在对他们自己的存在是必要的。

But even when the contradiction is resolved authentically by a new situation established by the liberated laborers, the former op-pressors do not feel liberated. On the contrary, they genuinely consider themselves to be oppressed. Conditioned by the experience of oppressing others, any situation other than their former seems to them like oppression. Formerly, they could eat, dress, wear shoes, be ­educated, travel, and hear Beethoven; while millions did not eat, had no clothes or shoes, neither studied nor traveled, much less ­listened to Beethoven. Any restriction on this way of life, in the name of the rights of the community, appears to the former oppressors as a profound violation of their individual rights—although they had no respect for the millions who suffered and died of hunger, pain, sorrow, and despair. For the oppressors, “human beings” refers only to themselves; other people are “things.” For the oppressors, there exists only one right: their right to live in peace, over against the right, not always even recognized, but simply conceded, of the oppressed to survival. And they make this concession only because the existence of the oppressed is necessary to their own existence.

这种行为，这种理解世界和人民的方式（这必然使压迫者抵制新政权的建立）是由他们作为统治阶级的经历来解释的。一旦暴力和压迫的局面建立起来，它就会为那些陷入其中的人——压迫者和被压迫者——产生一整套生活方式和行为。两者都沉浸在这种局面中，都带有压迫的痕迹。对压迫的存在情况的分析表明，它们的起源在于暴力行为——由掌权者发起。这种暴力作为一个过程，一代又一代的压迫者延续下来，他们成为暴力的继承者，并在暴力的氛围中形成。这种氛围在压迫者身上产生了一种强烈的占有意识——对世界和男人女人的占有。除了对世界和人民的直接、具体的、物质的占有之外，压迫者的意识无法理解自己——甚至无法存在。弗洛姆谈到这种意识时说，没有这种占有，“它就会与世界失去联系”。压迫者意识倾向于将其周围的一切都变成其统治的对象。土地、财产、生产、人类的创造物、人类本身、时间——一切都被降为可供其支配的物品。

This behavior, this way of understanding the world and people (which necessarily makes the oppressors resist the installation of a new regime) is explained by their experience as a dominant class. Once a situation of violence and oppression has been established, it engenders an entire way of life and behavior for those caught up in it—oppressors and oppressed alike. Both are submerged in this ­situation, and both bear the marks of oppression. Analysis of existen­tial situations of oppression reveals that their inception lay in an act of violence—initiated by those with power. This violence, as a proc­ess, is perpetuated from generation to generation of oppressors, who become its heirs and are shaped in its climate. This ­climate ­creates in the oppressor a strongly possessive consciousness—­possessive of the world and of men and women. Apart from direct, concrete, material possession of the world and of people, the oppressor consciousness could not understand itself—could not even exist. Fromm said of this consciousness that, without such possession, “it would lose contact with the world.” The oppressor consciousness tends to transform everything surrounding it into an object of its domination. The earth, property, production, the creations of people, people themselves, time—everything is reduced to the status of objects at its disposal.

压迫者在对占有的无节制渴望中，形成了这样一种信念：他们能够把所有东西都变成他们有购买力的东西；因此，他们形成了严格的物质主义生存观。金钱是衡量一切的标准，利润是首要目标。对于压迫者来说，值得的是拥有更多——永远更多——即使以被压迫者拥有更少或一无所有为代价。对他们来说，存在就是拥有，成为“富人”阶层。

In their unrestrained eagerness to possess, the oppressors de­-velop the conviction that it is possible for them to transform every­thing into objects of their purchasing power; hence their strictly ­materialistic concept of existence. Money is the measure of all things, and profit the primary goal. For the oppressors, what is worthwhile is to have more—always more—even at the cost of the oppressed having less or having nothing. For them, to be is to have and to be the class of the “haves.”

作为压迫环境的受益者，压迫者无法意识到，如果拥有是生存的条件，那么它就是所有女性和男性的必要条件。这就是为什么他们的慷慨错误。人性是一种“东西”，他们拥有它作为一种专有权利，一种继承的财产。对于压迫者意识来说，“他人”的人性化，人民的人性化，看起来不是对完整人性的追求，而是颠覆。

As beneficiaries of a situation of oppression, the oppressors ­cannot perceive that if having is a condition of being, it is a necessary ­condition for all women and men. This is why their ­generosity is false. Humanity is a “thing,” and they possess it as an ­exclusive right, as inherited property. To the oppressor consciousness, the ­humanization of the “others,” of the people, appears not as the pursuit of full humanity, but as subversion.

压迫者并不认为，他们垄断了更多东西是一种特权，这种特权使他人和自己都失去了人性。他们看不到，作为一个有产阶级，他们在自私地追求拥有时，会窒息于自己的拥有物中，不再存在；他们只是拥有而已。对他们来说，拥有更多是一种不可剥夺的权利，这种权利是他们通过自己的“努力”和“勇于冒险”获得的。如果别人没有拥有更多，那是因为他们无能和懒惰，最糟糕的是他们对统治阶级的“慷慨姿态”毫无道理地忘恩负义。正因为他们“忘恩负义”和“嫉妒”，被压迫者被视为必须警惕的潜在敌人。

The oppressors do not perceive their monopoly on having more as a privilege which dehumanizes others and themselves. They cannot see that, in the egoistic pursuit of having as a possessing class, they suffocate in their own possessions and no longer are; they merely have. For them, having more is an inalienable right, a right they acquired through their own “effort,” with their “courage to take risks.” If others do not have more, it is because they are incompetent and lazy, and worst of all is their unjustifiable ingratitude towards the “generous gestures” of the dominant class. Precisely because they are “­ungrateful” and “envious,” the oppressed are regarded as potential enemies who must be watched.

不可能不是这样。如果被压迫者的人性化意味着颠覆，那么他们的自由也意味着颠覆；因此需要不断的控制。压迫者越是控制被压迫者，他们就越是把他们变成看似无生命的“东西”。压迫者意识在渴望占有的过程中，倾向于将所遇到的一切和每个人都“无生命化”，这无疑与虐待狂的倾向相符。

It could not be otherwise. If the humanization of the oppressed ­signifies subversion, so also does their freedom; hence the ­necessity for constant control. And the more the oppressors control the op-pressed, the more they change them into apparently inanimate “things.” This tendency of the oppressor consciousness to “in-animate” everything and everyone it encounters, in its eagerness to ­possess, unquestionably corresponds with a tendency to sadism.

完全控制他人（或其他有生命的生物）所带来的快感正是虐待狂驱动力的本质。另一种表述同样思想的方式是说虐待狂的目的是将人变成物体，将有生命的生物变成无生命的生物，因为通过完全和绝对的控制，生命体会失去生命的基本品质——自由。12

The pleasure in complete domination over another person (or other animate creature) is the very essence of the sadistic drive. Another way of formulating the same thought is to say that the aim of sadism is to transform a man into a thing, something ­animate into something inanimate, since by complete and abso­-lute control the living loses one essential quality of life—freedom.12

施虐之爱是一种变态的爱——爱死，而不是爱生。因此，压迫者意识及其恋尸癖世界观的特征之一就是施虐。作为压迫者意识，为了统治，它试图阻止生命所特有的探索欲望、不安分和创造力，它扼杀生命。压迫者越来越多地将科学技术作为实现其目的的无可置疑的强大工具：通过操纵和镇压来维持压迫秩序。13被 压迫者作为客体，作为“事物”，除了压迫者为他们规定的目的之外，没有其他目的。

Sadistic love is a perverted love—a love of death, not of life. One of the characteristics of the oppressor consciousness and its ­necrophilic view of the world is thus sadism. As the oppressor consciousness, in order to dominate, tries to deter the drive to search, the restless­ness, and the creative power which characterize life, it kills life. More and more, the oppressors are using science and technology as unquestionably powerful instruments for their purpose: the mainte­nance of the oppressive order through manipulation and repression.13 The oppressed, as objects, as “things,” have no purposes except those their oppressors prescribe for them.

鉴于上述背景，另一个不容置疑的重要问题出现了：压迫阶级的某些成员加入被压迫者的解放斗争，从而从矛盾的一极转向另一极。他们的作用是根本性的，在整个斗争历史中都是如此。然而，当他们不再是剥削者或漠不关心的旁观者或仅仅是剥削的继承者而转向被剥削者一边时，他们几乎总是带着他们出身的痕迹：他们的偏见和畸形，包括对人民思考、欲望和认知能力缺乏信心。因此，这些人民事业的追随者经常冒着陷入与压迫者一样邪恶的慷慨的风险。压迫者的慷慨是由不公正的秩序所滋养的，为了证明这种慷慨是正当的，必须维持这种秩序。另一方面，我们的皈依者真正渴望改变不公正的秩序；但由于他们的背景，他们认为自己必须是变革的执行者。他们谈论人民，但他们并不信任人民；而信任人民是革命变革的必不可少的先决条件。真正的人道主义者更能体现出他对人民的信任，这使他参与到人民的斗争中，而不是在没有这种信任的情况下为人民采取千百种行动。

Given the preceding context, another issue of indubitable importance arises: the fact that certain members of the oppressor class join the oppressed in their struggle for liberation, thus moving from one pole of the contradiction to the other. Theirs is a ­fundamental role, and has been so throughout the history of this struggle. It happens, however, that as they cease to be exploiters or indifferent spectators or simply the heirs of exploitation and move to the side of the exploited, they almost always bring with them the marks of their origin: their prejudices and their deformations, which include a lack of confidence in the people’s ability to think, to want, and to know. Accordingly, these adherents to the people’s cause constantly run the risk of falling into a type of generosity as malefic as that of the oppressors. The generosity of the oppressors is nourished by an unjust order, which must be maintained in order to justify that generosity. Our converts, on the other hand, truly desire to trans­-form the unjust order; but because of their background they believe that they must be the executors of the transformation. They talk about the people, but they do not trust them; and trusting the ­people is the indispensable precondition for revolutionary change. A real humanist can be identified more by his trust in the people, which engages him in their struggle, than by a thousand actions in their favor without that trust.

那些真正致力于人民的人必须不断地重新审视自己。这种转变是如此彻底，以至于不允许模棱两可的行为。要肯定这种承诺，就要认为自己是革命智慧的拥有者——这必须给予（或强加给）人民的，就是保留旧的方式。男人或女人宣称献身于解放事业，却无法与人民交流，而他或她仍然认为人民完全无知，这是严重的自欺欺人。皈依者接近人民，但对他们迈出的每一步、表达的每一个怀疑、提出的每一个建议感到恐慌，并试图强加他的“地位”，他仍然怀念他的出身。

Those who authentically commit themselves to the people must re-examine themselves constantly. This conversion is so radical as not to allow of ambiguous behavior. To affirm this commitment but to consider oneself the proprietor of revolutionary wisdom—which must then be given to (or imposed on) the people—is to retain the old ways. The man or woman who proclaims devotion to the cause of liberation yet is unable to enter into communion with the people, whom he or she continues to regard as totally ignorant, is grievously self-deceived. The convert who approaches the people but feels alarm at each step they take, each doubt they express, and each ­suggestion they offer, and attempts to impose his “status,” remains nostalgic towards his origins.

皈依人民需要深刻的重生。经历重生的人必须采取一种新的生存方式；他们不能再保持原样。只有通过与被压迫者的友谊，皈依者才能理解他们独特的生活和行为方式，这些方式在不同的时刻反映了统治的结构。这些特征之一就是前面提到的被压迫者存在的二元性，他们既是自己，又是他们内化了其形象的压迫者。因此，在他们具体“发现”压迫者并进而发现自己的意识之前，他们几乎总是对自己的处境表现出宿命论的态度。

Conversion to the people requires a profound rebirth. Those who undergo it must take on a new form of existence; they can no longer remain as they were. Only through comradeship with the oppressed can the converts understand their characteristic ways of living and behaving, which in diverse moments reflect the structure of domina-tion. One of these characteristics is the previously mentioned exis-tential duality of the oppressed, who are at the same time themselves and the oppressor whose image they have internalized. Accordingly, until they concretely “discover” their oppressor and in turn their own consciousness, they nearly always express fatalistic attitudes towards their situation.

当农民意识到自己依赖老板时，他开始鼓起勇气克服依赖。直到那时，他才会顺从老板，说“我能做什么？我只是个农民。” 14

The peasant begins to get courage to overcome his dependence when he realizes that he is dependent. Until then, he goes along with the boss and says “What can I do? I’m only a peasant.”14

从表面上分析，这种宿命论有时被解释为顺从，这是民族性格的特征。以顺从为幌子的宿命论是历史和社会环境的产物，而不是民族行为的本质特征。它几乎总是与命运、命运或运气的力量——不可避免的力量——或对上帝的扭曲看法有关。在魔法和神话的支配下，被压迫者（尤其是几乎被自然淹没的农民）15 认为他们的苦难是剥削的结果，这是上帝的意志——就好像上帝是这种“有组织的混乱”的创造者一样。

When superficially analyzed, this fatalism is sometimes interpreted as a docility that is a trait of national character. Fatalism in the guise of docility is the fruit of an historical and sociological situation, not an essential characteristic of a people’s behavior. It almost always is related to the power of destiny or fate or fortune—inevitable forc­-es—or to a distorted view of God. Unde r the sway of magic and myth, the oppressed (especially the peasants, who are almost submerged in nature)15 see their suffering, the fruit of exploitation, as the will of God—as if God were the creator of this “organized disorder.”

被压迫者沉浸在现实之中，无法看清他们所内化的压迫者形象所代表的“秩序”，他们被这种秩序的束缚所折磨，常常表现出一种横向暴力，为了最微不足道的理由而攻击自己的同志。

Submerged in reality, the oppressed cannot perceive clearly the “order” which serves the interests of the oppressors whose image they have internalized. Chafing under the restrictions of this order, they often manifest a type of horizontal violence, striking out at their own comrades for the pettiest reasons.

被殖民者首先会表现出这种根植于骨子里的对自己族人的攻击性。这是黑鬼们互相殴打、警察和地方官员面对北非惊人的犯罪浪潮不知所措的时期。……虽然殖民者或警察有权整天殴打土著人、侮辱土著人并迫使土著人向他们跪下，但你会看到土著人只要被另一个土著人投以最轻微的敌意或攻击性的目光，就会伸手去拿刀；因为土著人最后的手段就是在面对兄弟时捍卫自己的人格。16

The colonized man will first manifest this aggressiveness which has been deposited in his bones against his own people. This is the period when the niggers beat each other up, and the police and ­magistrates do not know which way to turn when faced with the astonishing waves of crime in North Africa. . . . While the ­settler or the policeman has the right the livelong day to strike the native, to insult him and to make him crawl to them, you will see the native reaching for his knife at the slightest ­hostile or aggressive glance cast on him by another native; for the last resort of the native is to defend his personality vis-à-vis his ­brother.16

或许，他们的这种行为再次体现了他们的二重性，因为压迫者存在于被压迫的同志之中，当他们攻击同志时，他们也在间接攻击压迫者。

It is possible that in this behavior they are once more manifesting their duality. Because the oppressor exists within their oppressed comrades, when they attack those comrades they are indirectly at-tacking the oppressor as well.

另一方面，在他们生存体验的某个时刻，被压迫者会对压迫者和他们的生活方式产生一种不可抗拒的吸引力。分享这种生活方式成为一种压倒性的渴望。在异化中，被压迫者不惜一切代价想要模仿压迫者、效仿他们、追随他们。这种现象在中产阶级被压迫者中尤为普遍，他们渴望与上层阶级的“杰出”男女平起平坐。阿尔伯特·梅米在对“被殖民心态”的出色分析中提到了他对殖民者的蔑视，以及对他的“热情”吸引力。

On the other hand, at a certain point in their existential experience the oppressed feel an irresistible attraction towards the oppressors and their way of life. Sharing this way of life becomes an overpowering aspiration. In their alienation, the oppressed want at any cost to resemble the oppressors, to imitate them, to follow them. This phenomenon is especially prevalent in the middle-class op-pressed, who yearn to be equal to the “eminent” men and women of the upper class. Albert Memmi, in an exceptional analysis of the “colonized mentality,” refers to the contempt he felt towards the ­colonizer, mixed with “passionate” attraction towards him.

殖民者怎么能一边照顾工人，一边定期枪杀一群被殖民者？被殖民者怎么能如此残忍地自我否定，却又提出如此过分的要求？他怎么能憎恨殖民者，却又如此热情地钦佩他们？（我也情不自禁地感到了这种钦佩。）17

How could the colonizer look after his workers while periodically gunning down a crowd of colonized? How could the colonized deny himself so cruelly yet make such excessive demands? How could he hate the colonizers and yet admire them so passion­-ately? (I too felt this admiration in spite of myself.)17

自我贬低是被压迫者的另一个特征，这源于他们对压迫者对他们的看法的内化。他们经常听到别人说他们一无是处、一无所知、学不会任何东西——他们病了、懒了、没有生产力——最终他们确信自己不适合当这个角色。

Self-depreciation is another characteristic of the oppressed, which derives from their internalization of the opinion the oppressors hold of them. So often do they hear that they are good for nothing, know nothing and are incapable of learning anything—that they are sick, lazy, and unproductive—that in the end they become convinced of their own unfitness.

农民觉得自己比老板低下，因为老板似乎是唯一一个懂事、能管理事情的人。18

The peasant feels inferior to the boss because the boss seems to be the only one who knows things and is able to run things.18

他们自称无知，说“教授”才是有知识的人，他们应该听从教授的话。他们所接受的知识标准是传统的。一位参加文化圈的农民说：“你为什么不先 解释一下这些图片？这样既省时又不给我们添麻烦。”

They call themselves ignorant and say the “professor” is the one who has knowledge and to whom they should listen. The criteria of knowledge imposed upon them are the conventional ones. “Why don’t you,” said a peasant participating in a culture circle,19 “explain the pictures first? That way it’ll take less time and won’t give us a headache.”

他们几乎从未意识到，他们也“知道”他们在与世界、与其他女人和男人的关系中所学到的东西。考虑到造成他们二元性的环境，他们不信任自己是很自然的。

Almost never do they realize that they, too, “know things” they have learned in their relations with the world and with other women and men. Given the circumstances which have produced their duality, it is only natural that they distrust themselves.

参与教育项目的农民经常会开始热烈讨论一个生成主题，然后突然停下来对教育者说：“对不起，我们应该保持安静，让你说话。你才是知道的人，我们什么都不知道。”他们经常坚持认为他们和动物没有区别；当他们承认有区别时，这对动物有利。“他们比我们自由。”

Not infrequently, peasants in educational projects begin to ­discuss a generative theme in a lively manner, then stop suddenly and say to the educator: “Excuse us, we ought to keep quiet and let you talk. You are the one who knows, we don’t know anything.” They often insist that there is no difference between them and the ani­-mals; when they do admit a difference, it favors the animals. “They are freer than we are.”

然而，令人吃惊的是，这种自我贬低随着压迫状况的第一次变化而发生了变化。我听到一位农民领袖在一次asentamiento 20 会议上说：“他们过去常说我们没有生产力，因为我们懒惰和酗酒。全是谎言。现在我们作为男人受到尊重，我们要向所有人证明，我们从来不是酒鬼或懒惰的人。我们被剥削了！”

It is striking, however, to observe how this self-depreciation changes with the first changes in the situation of oppression. I heard a peasant leader say in an asentamiento 20 meeting, “They used to say we were unproductive because we were lazy and drunkards. All lies. Now that we are respected as men, we’re going to show every-one that we were never drunkards or lazy. We were exploited!”

只要这种模棱两可的心态持续存在，被压迫者就不愿意反抗，而且对自己完全没有信心。他们有一种模糊的、神奇的信念，相信压迫者是无懈可击的，而且力量强大。21地主 权力的神奇力量在农村地区尤其具有影响力。我的一位社会学家朋友讲述了一群拉丁美洲国家的武装农民最近占领了一个大庄园的故事。出于战术原因，他们计划把地主扣为人质。但没有一个农民有勇气保护他；他的存在本身就令人恐惧。反抗老板的行为也可能激起了他们的负罪感。事实上，老板就在他们“内心”。

As long as their ambiguity persists, the oppressed are reluctant to resist, and totally lack confidence in themselves. They have a ­diffuse, magical belief in the invulnerability and power of the oppressor.21 The magical force of the landowner’s power holds particular sway in the rural areas. A sociologist friend of mine tells of a group of armed peasants in a Latin American country who recently took over a latifundium. For tactical reasons, they planned to hold the landowner as a hostage. But not one peasant had the courage to guard him; his very presence was terrifying. It is also possible that the act of opposing the boss provoked guilt feelings. In truth, the boss was “inside” them.

被压迫者必须看到压迫者脆弱的例子，这样他们内心才能开始形成相反的信念。除非这种情况发生，否则他们将继续灰心丧气、心存恐惧和遭受打击。22只要 被压迫者不知道自己处境的原因，他们就会宿命地“接受”剥削。此外，当面对为自由和自我肯定而斗争的必要性时，他们倾向于以被动和疏远的方式做出反应。然而，他们逐渐倾向于尝试各种形式的反抗行动。在争取解放的过程中，人们既不能忽视这种被动性，也不能忽视觉醒的时刻。

The oppressed must see examples of the vulnerability of the op-pressor so that a contrary conviction can begin to grow within them. Until this occurs, they will continue disheartened, fearful, and ­beaten.22 As long as the oppressed remain unaware of the causes of their condition, they fatalistically “accept” their exploitation. Further, they are apt to react in a passive and alienated manner when confronted with the necessity to struggle for their freedom and self-affirmation.
