10 “我们的文化工作者必须满腔热情、全心全意地为人民服务，必须联系群众，而不能脱离群众。要做到这一点，就必须按照群众的需要和愿望去做。一切为群众所做的工作，都必须从群众的需要出发，而不能从个人的愿望出发，不管个人的愿望是多么好心。常常有这样的情况：群众在客观上需要某种改变，而在主观上还没有意识到，还没有愿意、没有决心去改变。在这种情况下，我们应该耐心等待。等到经过我们的工作，大多数群众已经意识到了这种需要，并且愿意、有决心去改变，我们才去改变，否则，我们就会脱离群众。……这里有两个原则：一个是群众的实际需要，而不是我们想象的群众需要；另一个是群众的愿望，群众必须自己作出决定，而不是我们替他们作出决定。”—— 《毛泽东选集》第144卷三、《文化工作的统一战线》（1944年10月30日）（北京，1967年），第186-187页。

10 “Our cultural workers must serve the people with great enthusiasm and ­devotion, and they must link themselves with the masses, not divorce themselves from the masses. In order to do so, they must act in accordance with the needs and wishes of the masses. All work done for the masses must start from their needs and not from the desire of any individual, however well-intentioned. It often­happens that objectively the masses need a certain change, but subjectively they are not yet conscious of the need, not yet willing or determined to make the change. In such cases, we should wait patiently. We should not make the change until, through our work, most of the masses have become conscious of the need and are willing and determined to carry it out. Otherwise we shall isolate ourselves from the masses. . . . There are two principles here: one is the actual needs of the masses rather than what we fancy they need, and the other is the wishes of the masses, who must make up their own minds instead of our making up their minds for them.” From the Selected Works of Mao-Tse-Tung, Vol. III. “The United Front in ­Cultural Work” (October 30, 1944) (Peking, 1967), pp. 186–187.

11这一点我们将在第4章中详细分析。

11 This point will be analyzed in detail in chapter 4.

12真正的人文主义者使用灌输式教学法，就如同右派人士进行问题提出式教育一样，是自相矛盾的。（后者始终如一——他们从不使用问题提出式教学法。）

12 It is as self-contradictory for true humanists to use the banking method as it would be for rightists to engage in problem-posing education. (The latter are always consistent—they never use a problem-posing pedagogy.)

13 “有意义的主题”这一表述具有同样的含义。

13 The expression “meaningful thematics” is used with the same connotation.

14在英语中，“live”和“exist”这两个词的含义与其词源相反。在这里，“live”是更基本的术语，仅表示生存；“exist”则意味着更深层次地参与“成为”的过程。

14 In the English language, the terms “live” and “exist” have assumed implica-tions opposite to their etymological origins. As used here, “live” is the more basic term, implying only survival; “exist” implies a deeper involvement in the process of “becoming.”

15阿尔瓦罗·维埃拉·平托教授清晰地分析了“极限情况”问题，他所用的概念没有雅斯贝斯原有的悲观主义色彩。对维埃拉·平托来说，“极限情况”不是“可能性终结的不可逾越的边界，而是所有可能性开始的真正边界”；它们不是“存在与虚无之间的边界，而是存在与虚无之间的边界，而是存在与更多之间的边界。”阿尔瓦罗·维埃拉·平托，《国家科学与现实》（里约热内卢，1960 年），第 II 卷，第 284 页。

15 Professor Alvaro Vieira Pinto analyzes with clarity the problem of “limit­situations,” using the concept without the pessimistic aspect originally found in ­Jaspers. For Vieira Pinto, the “limit-situations” are not “the impassable ­boundaries where ­possibilities end, but the real boundaries where all possibilities begin”; they are not “the frontier which separates being from nothingness, but the ­frontier which separates being from nothingness but the frontier which separates being from being more.” Alvaro Vieira Pinto, Consciência e Realidade Nacional (Rio de Janeiro, 1960), Vol. II, p. 284.

16卡尔·马克思，《1844年经济学哲学手稿》， Dirk Struik 主编（纽约，1964 年），第 113 页。

16 Karl Marx, Economic and Philosophical Manuscripts of 1844, Dirk Struik, ed. (New York, 1964), p. 113.

17关于这一点，参见 Karel Kosik, Dialética de lo Concreto (墨西哥，1967 年)。

17 Regarding this point, see Karel Kosik, Dialética de lo Concreto (Mexico, 1967).

18关于历史时期的问题，见 Hans Freyer, Teoría de la época atual (墨西哥)。

18 On the question of historical epochs, see Hans Freyer, Teoría de la época atual (Mexico).

19我把这些主题称为“生成性的”，因为（不管它们如何被理解，也不管它们会引起什么样的行动）它们都包含着再次展开为尽可能多的主题的可能性，而这些主题又反过来要求完成新的任务。

19 I have termed these themes “generative” because (however they are comprehended and whatever action they may evoke) they contain the possibility of un­-folding into again as many themes, which in their turn call for new tasks to be fulfilled.

20中产阶级的个人经常表现出这种行为，尽管方式与农民不同。他们对自由的恐惧导致他们建立防御机制和合理化，从而掩盖根本性问题，强调偶然性，否认具体现实。面对一个问题的分析会导致令人不快的极限情况感知，他们倾向于停留在讨论的边缘，抵制任何触及问题核心的尝试。当有人指出一个基本命题来解释他们一直赋予首要重要性的偶然或次要问题时，他们甚至会感到恼火。

20 Individuals of the middle class often demonstrate this type of behavior, al-though in a different way from the peasant. Their fear of freedom leads them to erect defense mechanisms and rationalizations which conceal the fundamental, emphasize the fortuitous, and deny concrete reality. In the face of a problem whose analysis would lead to the uncomfortable perception of a limit-situation, their tendency is to remain on the periphery of the discussion and resist any attempt to reach the heart of the question. They are even annoyed when someone points out a ­fundamental ­proposition which explains the fortuitous or secondary matters to which they had been assigning primary importance.

21存在情境的编码是该情境的表征，展示了该情境的一些构成要素之间的相互作用。解码是对编码情境的批判性分析。

21 The coding of an existential situation is the representation of that situation, ­showing some of its constituent elements in interaction. Decoding is the critical ­analysis of the coded situation.

22关于“生成词”的调查和使用，请参阅我的Educação como Prática da Liberdade。

22 Regarding the investigation and use of “generative words,” see my Educação como Prática da Liberdade.

23巴西社会学家玛丽亚·埃迪·费雷拉（Maria Edy Ferreira）在其未发表的著作中指出，主题调查只有在将真正属于人民的东西归还给他们的范围内才是合理的；它不是为了了解人民，而是为了和人民一起认识挑战他们的现实。

23 According to the Brazilian sociologist Maria Edy Ferreira (in an unpublished work), thematic investigation is only justified to the extent that it returns to the ­people what truly belongs to them; to the extent that it represents, not an attempt to learn about the people, but to come to know with them the reality which chal-lenges them.

24巴西小说家吉马良斯·罗萨 (Guimaraẽs Rosa) 是一个杰出的例子，说明作家如何真实地捕捉人们的语法结构，而不是发音或语法错误。事实上（这并不是贬低他作为作家的卓越价值），吉马良斯·罗萨是巴西腹地居民“有意义的主题”的杰出研究者。保罗·德·塔索教授目前正在撰写一篇文章，分析《大塞尔唐—维尔达斯》作者作品中这一鲜为人知的方面[英文译本：《腹地的魔鬼报应》（纽约，1963 年）]。

24 The Brazilian novelist Guimaraẽs Rosa is a brilliant example of how a writer can capture authentically, not the pronunciation or the grammatical ­corruptions of the people, but their syntax: the very structure of their thought. Indeed (and this is not to disparage his exceptional value as a writer), Guimaraes Rosa was the ­investigator par excellence of the “meaningful thematics” of the inhabitants of the ­Brazilian hinterland. Professor Paulo de Tarso is currently preparing an essay which analyzes this little-considered aspect of the work of the author of Grande Sertão—­Veredas [in English translation: The Devil to Pay in the Backlands (New York, 1963)].

25 Lucien Goldman，《人文科学与哲学》（伦敦，1969 年），第 118 页。

25 Lucien Goldman, The Human Sciences and Philosophy (London, 1969), p. 118.

26参见 André Nicolaï，《经济行为和社会结构》（巴黎，1960 年）。

26 See André Nicolaï, Comportment Économique et Structures Sociales (Paris, 1960).

27编纂也可以是口头的。在这种情况下，它们由几个词组成，提出一个存在的问题，然后进行解码。智利农业发展研究所 (Instituto de Desarrollo Agropecuario ) 的团队在专题调查中成功地使用了这种方法。

27 The codifications may also be oral. In this case they consist of a few words ­presenting an existential problem, followed by decoding. The team of the Instituto de Desarrollo Agropecuario (Institute for Agrarian Development) in Chile has used this method successfully in thematic investigations.

28该建议由 José Luis Fiori 在一份未发表的手稿中提出。

28 This recommendation is made by José Luis Fiori, in an unpublished manu­-script.

29直到最近，INDAP 一直由经济学家和真正的人道主义者 Jacques Chonchol 领导。

29 Until recently, INDAP was directed by the economist and authentic human­-ist Jacques Chonchol.

30根据菲奥里的定义，这些编纂并不是“包容性的”。

30 These codifications were not “inclusive,” in Fiori’s definition.

31每个“调查圈”最多应有 20 人。调查圈的数量应尽可能多，以覆盖所研究区域或子区域的 10% 为参与者。

31 Each “investigation circle” should have a maximum of twenty persons. There should be as many circles as necessary to involve, as participants, ten percent of the area or sub-area being studied.

32这些后续分析会议应包括协助调查的当地志愿者和“主题调查圈”的一些参与者。他们的贡献既是他们应得的权利，也是专家分析不可或缺的帮助。作为专家的共同调查者，他们将纠正和/或批准后者对调查结果的解释。从方法论的角度来看，他们的参与为调查（从一开始就基于“同情”关系）提供了额外的保障：从一开始到最后阶段，即主题分析阶段，人民代表的批判性存在，在组织教育行动作为解放文化行动的计划内容时继续存在。

32 These subsequent meetings of analysis should include the volunteers from the area who assisted in the investigation, and some participants of the ­“thematic ­investigation circles.” Their contribution is both a right to which they are ­entitled and an indispensable aid to the analysis of the specialists. As co-investigators of the ­specialists, they will rectify and/or ratify the interpretations the latter make of the ­findings. From the methodological point of view, their participation gives the investigation (which from the beginning is based on a “sympathetic” ­relationship) an additional safeguard: the critical presence of representatives of the people from the ­beginning until the final phase, that of thematic analysis, continued in the ­organization of the program content of educational action as liberating cultural action.

33不幸的是，这项特别调查尚未完成。

33 This particular investigation was, unfortunately, not completed.

34精神病学家帕特里西奥·洛佩斯 (Patricio Lopes)，其工作在 Educação como Prática da Liberdade 中有描述。

34 The psychiatrist Patricio Lopes, whose work is described in Educação como Prática da Liberdade.

35参见 Niebuhr，上文。

35 See Niebuhr, op cit.

36关于文化人类学分析的重要性，参见Educação como Prática da Liberdade。

36 With regard to the importance of the anthropological analysis of culture, see Educação como Prática da Liberdade.

37请注意，整个程序是由相互关联的单元组成的整体，这些单元本身也是整体。主题本身是整体，但也是相互作用构成整个程序的主题单元的元素。主题分解将总主题拆分以寻找其基本核心，即部分元素。编码过程试图在存在情况的表示中重新整合分离的主题。在解码过程中，个人将编码拆分以理解其隐含的主题。辩证解码过程并没有就此结束，而是在重新整合分离的整体时完成，因此可以更清楚地理解（以及它与其他编码情况的关系，所有这些都代表了存在情况）。

37 Note that the entire program is a totality made up of interrelated units which in themselves are also totalities.The themes are totalities in themselves but are also elements which in interaction constitute the thematic units of the entire program.The thematic breakdown splits the total themes in search of their fundamental nuclei, which are the partial elements.The codification process attempts to re-totalize the disjoined theme in the repre­sentation of existential situations.In decoding, individuals split the codification to apprehend its implicit theme or themes. The dialectical decoding process does not end there, but is completed in the re-totalization of the disjoined whole which is thus more clearly understood (as are also its relations to other codified situations, all of which represent existential situations).

38编码

   a) 简单：

      视觉通道

        图画

        图形

      触觉通道

      听觉通道     

   b) 复合：通道同时性

38 codification

   a) Simple:

      visual channel

        pictorial

        graphic

      tactile channel

      auditive channel     

   b) Compound: simultaneity of channels

章

CHAPTER

4

4

本章分析了从反对话和对话矩阵发展而来的文化行动理论，并将频繁参考前几章提出的观点，以扩展这些观点或澄清新的肯定。

This chapter, which analyses the theories of cultural action which develop from antidialogical and dialogical matrices, will make frequent reference to points presented in the previous chapters, either to expand these points or to clarify new affirmations.

首先我要重申，人类是实践的存在，不同于动物，动物是纯粹的活动的存在。动物不考虑世界；它们沉浸于世界之中。相反，人类从世界中产生，将其客体化，从而能够理解世界，并通过劳动改造世界。

I shall start by reaffirming that humankind, as beings of the praxis, differ from animals, which are beings of pure activity. Animals do not consider the world; they are immersed in it. In contrast, human beings emerge from the world, objectify it, and in so doing can understand it and transform it with their labor.

动物不劳动，生活在无法超越的环境中。因此，每种动物都生活在适合其自身的环境中，这些环境虽然对人类开放，但它们之间却无法交流。

Animals, which do not labor, live in a setting which they cannot transcend. Hence, each animal species lives in the context appro­priate to it, and these contexts, while open to humans, cannot communicate among themselves.

但人类活动由行动和反思组成：它是实践；它是世界的改造。作为实践，它需要理论来阐明它。人类活动是理论和实践；它是反思和行动。正如我在第二章中强调的那样，它不能被简化为语言主义或行动主义。

But human activity consists of action and reflection: it is praxis; it is transformation of the world. And as praxis, it requires theory to illuminate it. Human activity is theory and practice; it is reflection and action. It cannot, as I stressed in chapter 2, be reduced to either verbalism or activism.

列宁有句名言：“没有革命的理论，就不会有革命的运动。” 1 这意味着革命是实现这一目标既不是靠空谈，也不是靠行动，而是靠实践，即通过反思和行动来改变需要改变的结构。彻底改变这些结构的革命努力不能将其领导者指定为思想家，而将受压迫者指定为单纯的行动者。

Lenin’s famous statement: “Without a revolutionary theory there can be no revolutionary movement”1 means that a revolution is achieved with neither verbalism nor activism, but rather with praxis, that is, with reflection and action directed at the structures to be transformed. The revolutionary effort to transform these structures radically cannot designate its leaders as its thinkers and the op-­pressed as mere doers.

如果对人民的真正承诺，包括改变压迫人民的现实，需要一种变革行动理论，那么这种理论就不能不赋予人民在变革过程中的基本作用。领导人不能把被压迫者视为纯粹的积极分子，剥夺他们反思的机会，只允许他们有行动的假象，而事实上，他们将继续受到操纵——在这种情况下，操纵者是操纵的假定敌人。

If true commitment to the people, involving the transformation of the reality by which they are oppressed, requires a theory of transforming action, this theory cannot fail to assign the people a fundamental role in the transformation process. The leaders cannot treat the oppressed as mere activists to be denied the opportunity of reflection and allowed merely the illusion of acting, whereas in fact they would continue to be manipulated—and in this case by the presumed foes of manipulation.

领导者确实承担着协调的责任，有时还承担着指导的责任——但拒绝向被压迫者提供实践的领导者，也因此使自己的实践无效。通过将自己的言论强加于他人，他们歪曲了自己的言论，并造成了他们的方法与目标之间的矛盾。如果他们真正致力于解放，他们的行动和思考就离不开他人的行动和思考。

The leaders do bear the responsibility for coordination and, at times, direction—but leaders who deny praxis to the oppressed thereby invalidate their own praxis. By imposing their word on others, they falsify that word and establish a contradiction between their methods and their objectives. If they are truly committed to liberation, their action and reflection cannot proceed without the action and reflection of others.

革命实践必须与统治精英的实践对立，因为它们本质上是对立的。革命实践不能容忍一种荒谬的二分法，即人民的实践仅仅是遵循领导者的决定——这种二分法反映了统治精英的规定性方法。革命实践是一个整体，领导者不能把被压迫者当作自己的财产。

Revolutionary praxis must stand opposed to the praxis of the dominant elites, for they are by nature antithetical. Revolutionary praxis cannot tolerate an absurd dichotomy in which the praxis of the people is merely that of following the leaders’ decisions—a dichotomy reflecting the prescriptive methods of the dominant elites. Revolutionary praxis is a unity, and the leaders cannot treat the oppressed as their possession.

操纵、口号、“沉积”、管制和规定不能成为革命实践的组成部分，因为它们是统治实践的组成部分。为了统治，统治者别无选择，只能剥夺人民真正的实践，剥夺他们说自己的话和思考自己思想的权利。他和她不能对话式地行动；因为这样做要么意味着他们放弃了统治权力并加入了被压迫者的事业，要么因为误判而失去了这种权力。

Manipulation, sloganizing, “depositing,” regimentation, and prescription cannot be components of revolutionary praxis, precisely because they are components of the praxis of domination. In order to dominate, the dominator has no choice but to deny true praxis to the people, deny them the right to say their own word and think their own thoughts. He and she cannot act dialogically; for to do so would mean either that they had relinquished their power to dominate and joined the cause of the oppressed, or had lost that power through miscalculation.

相反，那些在与人民的关系中不采取对话式行动的革命领袖，要么保留了统治者的特征，不是真正的革命者；要么他们对自己角色的理解完全被误导，并且受制于自己的宗派主义，同样不革命。他们甚至可能掌权。但任何由反对话式行动引起的革命的有效性都是完全值得怀疑的。

Obversely, revolutionary leaders who do not act dialogically in their relations with the people either have retained characteristics of the dominator and are not truly revolutionary; or they are totally misguided in their conception of their role, and, prisoners of their own sectarianism, are equally non-revolutionary. They may even reach power. But the validity of any revolution resulting from antidia-logical action is thoroughly doubtful.

被压迫者在参与革命进程时，必须日益意识到自己作为变革主体的角色，这是绝对必要的。如果他们以模棱两可的身份被卷入这一进程，一部分是他们自己，一部分是他们内心的压迫者——如果他们掌权时仍然体现着压迫处境强加给他们的模棱两可性——我认为他们只会想象自己已经掌权。2他们 存在的二元性甚至可能助长宗派主义气氛的兴起，导致破坏革命的官僚机构的建立。如果被压迫者在革命过程中没有意识到这种模棱两可性，他们可能会以复仇主义而非革命主义的精神参与这一进程。3他们 可能渴望革命作为一种统治手段，而不是解放之路。

It is absolutely essential that the oppressed participate in the revolutionary process with an increasingly critical awareness of their role as Subjects of the transformation. If they are drawn into the process as ambiguous beings, partly themselves and partly the oppressors housed within them—and if they come to power still em­bodying that ambiguity imposed on them by the situation of oppression—it is my contention that they will merely imagine they have reached power.2 Their existential duality may even facilitate the rise of a sectarian climate leading to the installation of bureaucracies which undermine the revolution. If the oppressed do not become aware of this ambiguity during the course of the revolutionary proc­ess, they may participate in that process with a spirit more revanch­ist than revolutionary.3 They may aspire to revolution as a means of domination, rather than as a road to liberation.

如果体现真正人道主义的革命领袖们都遇到困难和问题，那么对于一群试图（即使怀着最好的意图）为人民进行革命的领导人来说，困难和问题将更加严重。这样做就等于在没有人民的情况下进行革命，因为人民被过去压迫他们的同样手段和程序卷入这一进程。

If revolutionary leaders who incarnate a genuine humanism have difficulties and problems, the difficulties and problems will be far greater for a group of leaders who try (even with the best of intentions) to carry out the revolution for the people. To attempt this is equivalent to carrying out a revolution without the people, because the people are drawn into the process by the same methods and procedures used to oppress them.

与人民对话对于每一场真正的革命来说都是至关重要的。这就是革命不同于军事政变的原因。政变不会带来对话——只会带来欺骗（为了获得“合法性”）或武力（为了镇压）。真正的革命迟早必须与人民展开勇敢的对话。它的合法性就在于对话。4它 不能害怕人民，不能害怕人民的表达，不能害怕人民对权力的有效参与。它必须对人民负责，必须坦率地向人民讲述它的成就、错误、误判和困难。

Dialogue with the people is radically necessary to every authentic revolution. This is what makes it a revolution, as distinguished from a military coup. One does not expect dialogue from a coup—only deceit (in order to achieve “legitimacy”) or force (in order to repress). Sooner or later, a true revolution must initiate a courageous dialogue with the people. Its very legitimacy lies in that dialogue.4 It cannot fear the people, their expression, their effective participation in power. It must be accountable to them, must speak frankly to them of its achievements, its mistakes, its miscalculations, and its diffi­culties.

对话开始得越早，运动就越具有革命性。革命所必不可少的对话与另一种根本需求相对应：女性和男性作为人，离开交流就无法成为真正的人，因为他们本质上是交流的生物。阻碍交流就是把男性贬低为“物品”——这是压迫者的工作，不是革命者的工作。

The earlier dialogue begins, the more truly revolutionary will the movement be. The dialogue which is radically necessary to revolution corresponds to another radical need: that of women and men as beings who cannot be truly human apart from communication, for they are essentially communicative creatures. To impede communication is to reduce men to the status of “things”—and this is a job for oppressors, not for revolutionaries.

我要强调的是，我对实践的辩护并不意味着将实践分为反思的先行阶段和行动的后继阶段的二分法。行动和反思是同时发生的。然而，对现实的批判性分析可能会揭示出某种形式的行动在目前是不可能或不合适的。那些通过反思认识到一种或另一种形式的行动不可行或不合适的人（因此应该推迟或取而代之）不能因此被指责为不作为。批判性反思也是行动。

Let me emphasize that my defense of the praxis implies no dichotomy by which this praxis could be divided into a prior stage of reflection and a subsequent stage of action. Action and reflection occur simultaneously. A critical analysis of reality may, however, reveal that a particular form of action is impossible or inappropriate at the present time. Those who through reflection perceive the infeasibility or inappropriateness of one or another form of action (which should accordingly be postponed or substituted) cannot thereby be accused of inaction. Critical reflection is also action.

我之前曾说过，在教育中，师生试图理解一个可认知的对象，其努力并未止于该对象，因为这种行为延伸至其他学生-教师，例如认知对象调节他们理解能力的方式。革命行动也是如此。也就是说，被压迫者和领导者同样是革命行动的主体，现实是这两个群体变革行动的媒介。在这种行动理论中，我们不能谈论行动者，也不能简单地谈论行动者，而是谈论相互交流的行动者。

I previously stated that in education the attempt of the teacher-student to understand a cognizable object is not exhausted in that object, because this act extends to other students-teachers in such a way that the cognizable object mediates their capacity for understanding. The same is true of revolutionary action. That is, the oppressed and the leaders are equally the Subjects of revolutionary action, and reality serves as the medium for the transforming action of both groups. In this theory of action one cannot speak of an actor, nor simply of actors, but rather of actors in intercommunication.

这种肯定似乎意味着革命力量的分裂、二分法和破裂；事实上，它恰恰意味着相反的：他们的团结。除了这种团结之外，我们确实看到了二分法：一边是领导人，另一边是人民，这是压迫关系的翻版。否认革命进程中的团结，以组织人民、加强革命力量或确保统一战线为借口避免与人民对话，实际上是对自由的恐惧。这是对人民的恐惧或缺乏信心。但如果人民不值得信任，就没有解放的理由；在这种情况下，革命甚至不是为人民而进行的，而是由人民为领导人进行的：完全的自我否定。

This affirmation might appear to imply division, dichotomy, rup­ture of the revolutionary forces; in fact, it signifies exactly the opposite: their communion. Apart from this communion, we do see dichotomy: leaders on one side and people on the other, in a replica of the relations of oppression. Denial of communion in the revolutionary process, avoidance of dialogue with the people under the pretext of organizing them, of strengthening revolutionary power, or of ensuring a united front, is really a fear of freedom. It is fear of or lack of faith in the people. But if the people cannot be trusted, there is no reason for liberation; in this case the revolution is not even carried out for the people, but “by” the people for the leaders: a complete self-negation.

革命既不是由领袖为人民而革命，也不是由人民为领袖而革命，而是由双方共同坚定不移地团结一致而革命。只有当领袖们以谦逊、爱心和勇敢的态度与人民接触时，这种团结才会诞生。并非所有的男人和女人都有足够的勇气进行这种接触——但当他们避免接触时，他们就会变得僵化，将他人视为纯粹的物品；他们不是滋养生命，而是扼杀生命；他们不是寻找生命，而是逃离生命。这些都是压迫者的特征。

The revolution is made neither by the leaders for the people, nor by the people for the leaders, but by both acting together in unshakable solidarity. This solidarity is born only when the leaders witness to it by their humble, loving, and courageous encounter with the people. Not all men and women have sufficient courage for this encounter—but when they avoid encounter they become inflexible and treat others as mere objects; instead of nurturing life, they kill life; instead of searching for life, they flee from it. And these are oppressor characteristics.

有些人可能认为，肯定对话（即世界上女性和男性相遇以改变世界）是天真而主观的理想主义。5然而 ，没有什么比人与人、人与人之间以及某些人与其他人、压迫者和被压迫者之间的互动更真实、更具体。

Some may think that to affirm dialogue—the encounter of women and men in the world in order to transform the world—is naïvely and subjectively idealistic.5 There is nothing, however, more real or concrete than people in the world and with the world, than humans with other humans—and some people against others, as oppressing and oppressed classes.

真正的革命试图改变导致这种非人性化状况的现实。那些从现实中获益的人无法实现这种转变；它必须由被暴政者及其领导人来实现。然而，这一真理必须具有根本性的意义；也就是说，领导人必须通过与人民的交流来体现它。在这种交流中，两个群体共同成长，领导人不是简单地自我任命，而是在实践中与人民的实践相结合或认证。

Authentic revolution attempts to transform the reality which begets this dehumanizing state of affairs. Those whose interests are served by that reality cannot carry out this transformation; it must be achieved by the tyrannized, with their leaders. This truth, however, must become radically consequential; that is, the leaders must incarnate it, through communion with the people. In this communion both groups grow together, and the leaders, instead of being simply self-appointed, are installed or authenticated in their praxis with the praxis of the people.

许多人被机械论的现实观所束缚，没有意识到个人的具体处境决定了他们对世界的意识，而这种意识又决定了他们的态度和处理现实的方式。他们认为，现实可以机械地改变，6 而不必把个人对现实的错误意识当作问题，也不必通过革命行动发展出一种越来越不错误的意识。没有不人性的历史现实。没有人类就没有历史，也没有人类的历史；只有人类的历史，由人民创造，并（如马克思所指出的）反过来又创造人民。当大多数人被剥夺作为主体参与历史的权利时，他们就会被统治和异化。因此，要用主体地位取代他们作为客体的状况——任何真正的革命的目标——需要人民对要改变的现实采取行动，并进行反思。

Many persons, bound to a mechanistic view of reality, do not perceive that the concrete situation of individuals conditions their consciousness of the world, and that in turn this consciousness conditions their attitudes and their ways of dealing with reality. They think that reality can be transformed mechanistically,6 without pos-ing the person’s false consciousness of reality as a problem or, through revolutionary action, developing a consciousness which is less and less false. There is no historical reality which is not human. There is no history without humankind, and no history for human beings; there is only history of humanity, made by people and (as Marx pointed out) in turn making them. It is when the majorities are denied their right to participate in history as Subjects that they become dominated and alienated. Thus, to supersede their condi­tion as objects by the status of Subjects—the objective of any true revolution—requires that the people act, as well as reflect, upon the reality to be transformed.

确实，如果说人们仅仅通过反思压迫性现实并发现自己作为客体的地位，就已经成为主体，那么这种说法是理想主义的。但是，虽然这种看法本身并不意味着思想者已经成为主体，但它 正如我的一位合作研究者7 所言，这确实意味着他们是“充满期待的主体” ——这种期待促使他们寻求巩固自己的新地位。

It would indeed be idealistic to affirm that, by merely reflecting on oppressive reality and discovering their status as objects, persons have thereby already become Subjects. But while this perception in and of itself does not mean that thinkers have become Subjects, it does mean, as one of my co-investigators7 affirmed, that they are “Subjects in expectancy”—an expectancy which leads them to seek to solidify their new status.

另一方面，认为激进主义（不是真正的行动）是革命之路则是一个错误的前提。如果人们充分实践，也就是说，如果他们的行动包含批判性反思，这种反思会逐渐组织他们的思想，从而引导他们从对现实的纯粹天真的认识转向更高的层次，使他们能够感知现实的原因，那么他们就会真正具有批判性。如果革命领袖剥夺了人民的这一权利，他们就会损害自己的思考能力——或者至少是正确思考的能力。革命领袖不能不考虑人民，也不能为人民而思考，而只能与人民一起思考。

On the other hand, it would be a false premise to believe that activism (which is not true action) is the road to revolution. People will be truly critical if they live the plenitude of the praxis, that is, if their action encompasses a critical reflection which increasingly organizes their thinking and thus leads them to move from a purely naïve knowledge of reality to a higher level, one which enables them to perceive the causes of reality. If revolutionary leaders deny this right to the people, they impair their own capacity to think—or at least to think correctly. Revolutionary leaders cannot think without the people, nor for the people, but only with the people.

另一方面，占统治地位的精英们可以——而且确实——不考虑人民的感受——尽管他们不允许自己不考虑人民，以便更好地了解人民，从而更有效地统治人民。因此，精英和民众之间任何表面上的对话或交流实际上都是“公报”的发表，其内容旨在发挥驯服的影响。

The dominant elites, on the other hand, can—and do—think without the people—although they do not permit themselves the luxury of failing to think about the people in order to know them better and thus dominate them more efficiently. Consequently, any apparent dialogue or communication between the elites and the masses is really the depositing of “communiqués,” whose contents are intended to exercise a domesticating influence.

为什么统治精英不与人民一起思考就不会衰弱呢？因为人民是他们的对立面，是他们存在的理由。如果精英与人民一起思考，矛盾就会被取代，他们就无法再统治了。从任何时代的统治者的角度来看，正确的思考是以人民不思考为前提的。

Why do the dominant elites not become debilitated when they do not think with the people? Because the latter constitute their antithesis, their very reason for existence. If the elites were to think with the people, the contradiction would be superseded and they could no longer dominate. From the point of view of the dominators in any epoch, correct thinking presupposes the non-thinking of the people.

后来担任英国皇家学会会长的吉迪先生提出了在每一个国家都可能出现的反对意见：“无论给贫穷的劳动阶级提供教育的计划在理论上有多么合理，它都会损害他们的道德和幸福；它会教他们鄙视自己的命运。它不但不能使他们成为农业和其他体力劳动的好仆人，反而会使他们变得难以驾驭；它不但不能教会他们服从，反而会使他们变得暴躁和难以控制，就像在制造业县所表现的那样；它会使他们阅读反基督教的煽动性小册子、恶毒书籍和出版物；它会使他们对上级傲慢无礼，几年后，立法机关就会发现有必要将强大的权力力量指向他们。8

A Mr. Giddy, later President of the Royal Society, raised objections which could be matched in every country: “However specious in theory the project might be of giving education to the laboring classes of the poor, it would be prejudicial to their morals and happiness; it would teach them to despise their lot in life instead of making them good servants in agricultural and other laborious employments; instead of teaching them subordi­nation it would render them fractious and refractory as was evi­dent in the manufacturing counties; it would enable them to read seditious pamphlets, vicious books and publications against Christianity; it would render them insolent to their superiors and in a few years the legislature would find it necessary to direct the strong arm of power against them.8

吉迪先生真正想要的（也是当今精英们想要的，尽管他们并没有如此愤世嫉俗地公开谴责大众教育）是让人们不要思考。因为所有时代的吉迪先生，作为压迫阶级，不能与人民一起思考，也不能让人民自己思考。

What Mr. Giddy really wanted (and what the elites of today want, although they do not denounce popular education so cynically and openly) was for the people not to think. Since the Mr. Giddys of all epochs, as an oppressor class, cannot think with the people, neither can they let the people think for themselves.

然而，革命领袖的情况并非如此；如果他们不与人民一起思考，他们就会失去活力。人民是他们的组成母体，而不仅仅是思考的对象。尽管革命领袖也必须考虑人民，以便更好地理解他们，但这种思考方式不同于精英的思考方式；因为在思考人民以解放（而不是统治）人民时，领袖们把自己奉献给了人民的思考。一个是主人的思考方式；另一个是同志的思考方式。

The same is not true, however, of revolutionary leaders; if they do not think with the people, they become devitalized. The people are their constituent matrix, not mere objects thought of. Although revolutionary leaders may also have to think about the people in order to understand them better, this thinking differs from that of the elite; for in thinking about the people in order to liberate (rather than dominate) them, the leaders give of themselves to the thinking of the people. One is the thinking of the master; the other is the thinking of the comrade.

统治，就其本质而言，只需要一个处于对立矛盾中的统治极和一个被统治极；试图解决这一矛盾的革命解放，不仅意味着这些极的存在，还意味着在这一尝试中出现的领导集团的存在。这个领导集团要么认同人民的受压迫状态，要么就不是革命的。如果像统治者那样，只是简单地考虑人民，而没有在这种思考中付出任何自我牺牲，无法与人民一起思考，那么就肯定不会成为革命领袖。

Domination, by its very nature, requires only a dominant pole and a dominated pole in antithetical contradiction; revolutionary liberation, which attempts to resolve this contradiction, implies the existence not only of these poles but also of a leadership group which emerges during this attempt. This leadership group either identifies itself with the oppressed state of the people, or it is not revolution-ary. To simply think about the people, as the dominators do, without any self-giving in that thought, to fail to think with the people, is a sure way to cease being revolutionary leaders.

在压迫的过程中，精英们依靠被压迫者的“活着的死亡”而生存，并在他们与被压迫者的垂直关系中找到自己的真实性；在革命的在这个过程中，新兴领导人只有一种方法来实现真实性：他们必须“死去”，才能通过被压迫者、与被压迫者一起重生。

In the process of oppression the elites subsist on the “living death” of the oppressed and find their authentication in the vertical relationship between themselves and the latter; in the revolutionary process there is only one way for the emerging leaders to achieve authenticity: they must “die,” in order to be reborn through and with the oppressed.

我们可以合理地说，在压迫过程中，有人压迫别人；但我们不能说，在革命过程中，有人解放别人，也不能说有人解放自己，而是人类在共融中相互解放。这种肯定并不意味着低估革命领袖的重要性，相反，是为了强调他们的价值。还有什么比与被压迫者、与“被生活抛弃的人”、与“地球上的可怜人”一起生活和工作更重要呢？在这种共融中，革命领袖不仅应该找到存在的理由，还应该找到欢欣鼓舞的动机。革命领袖本质上可以做到统治精英本质上无法做到的事情。

We can legitimately say that in the process of oppression someone oppresses someone else; we cannot say that in the process of revolution someone liberates someone else, nor yet that someone liberates himself, but rather that human beings in communion liberate each other. This affirmation is not meant to undervalue the importance of revolutionary leaders but, on the contrary, to emphasize their value. What could be more important than to live and work with the oppressed, with the “rejects of life,” with the “wretched of the earth”? In this communion, the revolutionary leaders should find not only their raison d’être but a motive for rejoicing. By their very nature, revolutionary leaders can do what the dominant elites—by their very nature—are unable to do in authentic terms.

精英阶层对待被压迫者的方式都带有第一章中描述的虚假慷慨。但革命领袖不能虚假慷慨，也不能操纵。压迫者精英通过践踏人民而蓬勃发展，而革命领袖只有与人民共融才能蓬勃发展。因此，压迫者的活动不可能是人道主义的，而革命者的活动必然是人道主义的。

Every approach to the oppressed by the elites, as a class, is couched in terms of the false generosity described in chapter 1. But the revolutionary leaders cannot be falsely generous, nor can they manipulate. Whereas the oppressor elites flourish by trampling the people underfoot, the revolutionary leaders can flourish only in communion with the people. Thus it is that the activity of the op-pressor cannot be humanist, while that of the revolutionary is necessarily so.

压迫者的残酷无情和革命人道主义都利用了科学。但为前者服务的科学技术被用来将被压迫者贬低为“物”；为后者服务的科学技术被用来促进人性化。然而，被压迫者必须成为后者过程的主体，否则他们将继续被视为科学兴趣的单纯对象。

The inhumanity of the oppressors and revolutionary humanism both make use of science. But science and technology at the service of the former are used to reduce the oppressed to the status of “things”; at the service of the latter, they are used to promote hu-manization. The oppressed must become Subjects of the latter pro-cess, however, lest they continue to be seen as mere objects of scientific interest.

科学的革命人道主义不能以革命的名义把被压迫者当作要分析的对象，并（根据这种分析）向他们提供行为处方。这样做就等于落入压迫者意识形态的神话之一：无知的绝对化。这一神话意味着存在下达命令使别人无知的人。下达命令的人将自己和自己所属的阶级定义为有知识或生来就有知识的人；因此，他将其他人定义为外来实体。他自己阶级的话语成为“真实”的话语，他将这些话语强加或试图强加给其他人：被压迫的人，他们的话语被偷走了。那些偷走别人话语的人对其他人的能力产生了深深的怀疑，认为他们无能。每当他们说出自己的话而不听那些他们禁止说话的人的话时，他们就会更加习惯权力，并养成指导、命令和指挥的习惯。他们再也无法没有人可以发号施令了。在这种情况下，对话是不可能的。

Scientific revolutionary humanism cannot, in the name of revolu­tion, treat the oppressed as objects to be analyzed and (based on that analysis) presented with prescriptions for behavior. To do this would be to fall into one of the myths of the oppressor ideology: the absolutizing of ignorance. This myth implies the existence of someone who decrees the ignorance of someone else. The one who is doing the decreeing defines himself and the class to which he belongs as those who know or were born to know; he thereby defines others as alien entities. The words of his own class come to be the “true” words, which he imposes or attempts to impose on the others: the oppressed, whose words have been stolen from them. Those who steal the words of others develop a deep doubt in the abilities of the others and consider them incompetent. Each time they say their word without hearing the word of those whom they have forbidden to speak, they grow more accustomed to power and acquire a taste for guiding, ordering, and commanding. They can no longer live without having someone to give orders to. Under these circumstances, dialogue is impossible.

另一方面，科学和人文主义的革命领袖不能相信人民无知的神话。他们没有权利一刻怀疑这只是一个神话。他们不能相信他们，而且只有他们知道任何事情——因为这意味着怀疑人民。虽然他们可能合理地承认自己由于革命意识而具有与人民所拥有的经验知识水平不同的革命知识水平，但他们不能把自己和自己的知识强加给人民。他们不能向人民灌输口号，而必须与他们对话，以便人民对现实的经验知识在领袖的批判知识的滋养下逐渐转化为对现实原因的认识。

Scientific and humanist revolutionary leaders, on the other hand, cannot believe in the myth of the ignorance of the people. They do not have the right to doubt for a single moment that it is only a myth. They cannot believe that they, and only they, know anything—for this means to do ubt the people. Although they may legitimately recognize themselves as having, due to their revolutionary consciousness, a level of revolutionary knowledge different from the level of empirical knowledge held by the people, they cannot impose themselves and their knowledge on the people. They cannot slo­ganize the people, but must enter into dialogue with them, so that the people’s empirical knowledge of reality, nourished by the lead-ers’ critical knowledge, gradually becomes transformed into know­ledge of the causes of reality.

期望压迫者精英谴责将人民的无知绝对化的神话是幼稚的；如果革命领袖不这样做，那将是自相矛盾的，如果他们按照这个神话行事，那就更加自相矛盾了。革命领袖的任务不仅是提出这个神话，而且是提出压迫者精英用来压迫的所有其他神话的问题。如果革命领袖坚持模仿压迫者的统治方法，人民可能会以两种方式作出反应。在某些历史情况下，他们可能被领导者灌输给他们的新内容驯服。在其他情况下，他们可能会被威胁他们内心压迫者的“话语”吓坏。9在 这两种情况下，他们都不会成为革命者。在第一种情况下，革命是一种幻想；在第二种情况下，革命是不可能的。

It would be naïve to expect oppressor elites to denounce the myth which absolutizes the ignorance of the people; it would be a contradiction in terms if revolutionary leaders were not to do so, and more contradictory still were they to act in accordance with that myth. The task of revolutionary leaders is to pose as problems not only this myth, but all the other myths used by the oppressor elites to oppress. If, instead, revolutionary leaders persist in imitating the oppressors’ methods of domination, the people may respond in either of two ways. In certain historical circumstances, they may become domesticated by the new contents which the leaders deposit in them. In other circumstances, they may become frightened by a “word” which threatens the oppressor housed within them.9 In neither event do they become revolutionary. In the first case, the revo­lution is an illusion; in the second case, an impossibility.

一些好心却误入歧途的人认为，既然对话过程被延长了10 （顺便说一句，事实并非如此），他们就应该通过“公报”的方式，不通过交流来进行革命，一旦革命胜利，他们就会开展彻底的教育工作。他们进一步为这一程序辩护，说在夺取政权之前不可能进行教育——解放教育。

Some well-intentioned but misguided persons suppose that since the dialogical process is prolonged10 (which, incidentally, is not true), they ought to carry out the revolution without communication, by means of “communiqués,” and that once the revolution is won, they will then develop a thoroughgoing educational effort. They further justify this procedure by saying that it is not possible to carry out education—liberating education—before taking power.

值得分析上述断言的一些基本点tions。这些男人和女人（或他们中的大多数人）相信与人民对话的必要性，但不相信这种对话在掌权之前是可行的。当他们否认领导人在掌权之前可以采取批判性教育方式的可能性时，他们就否认了革命作为准备成为文化革命的文化行动的教育性质。另一方面，他们把文化行动与掌权后即将开始的新教育混为一谈。

It is worth analyzing some fundamental points of the above assertions. These men and women (or most of them) believe in the necessity for dialogue with the people, but do not believe this dialogue is feasible prior to taking power. When they deny the possibility that the leaders can behave in a critically educational fashion before taking power, they deny the revolution’s educational quality as cultural action preparing to become cultural revolution. On the other hand, they confuse cultural action with the new education to be inaugurated once power is taken.

我已经肯定，期望压迫者精英进行解放教育确实是天真的。但因为革命无疑具有教育性质，即除非它解放，否则它就不是革命，夺取政权只是革命进程中的一个瞬间——无论它有多么决定性。作为过程，革命的“前奏”位于压迫者社会中，只有革命意识才能意识到。

I have already affirmed that it would indeed be naïve to expect the oppressor elites to carry out a liberating education. But because the revolution undeniably has an educational nature, in the sense that unless it liberates it is not revolution, the taking of power is only one moment—no matter how decisive—in the revolutionary process. As process, the “before” of the revolution is located within the oppressor society and is apparent only to the revolutionary consciousness.

革命是压迫社会中的社会实体，就其文化行为而言，它不能不与其起源的社会实体的潜力相呼应。每个实体都是通过其矛盾的相互作用在自身内部发展（或转变）的。外部条件虽然必要，但只有与这些潜力相吻合时才有效。11 革命的 新颖性是在旧的压迫社会中产生的；夺取政权只是一个决定性的时刻革命进程的持续性。从动态而非静态的角度来看，革命没有绝对的“之前”或“之后”，夺取政权是分界线。

The revolution is born as a social entity within the oppressor society; to the extent that it is cultural action, it cannot fail to correspond to the potentialities of the social entity in which it originated. Every entity develops (or is transformed) within itself, through the interplay of its contradictions. External conditioners, while necessary, are effective only if they coincide with those potentialities.11 The newness of the revolution is generated within the old, oppressive society; the taking of power constitutes only a decisive moment of the continuing revolutionary process. In a dynamic, rather than static, view of revolution, there is no absolute “before” or “after,” with the taking of power as the dividing line.

革命源于客观条件，旨在通过在持续解放的过程中建立一个男女社会来取代压迫状况。革命的教育性和对话性，也使其成为一场“文化革命”，革命的各个阶段都必须具备这种教育性和对话性。这种教育性是防止革命在反革命官僚机构中制度化和分层的最有效手段之一；因为反革命是由成为反动分子的革命者进行的。

Originating in objective conditions, revolution seeks to supersede the situation of oppression by inaugurating a society of women and men in the process of continuing liberation. The educational, dialogical quality of revolution, which makes it a “cultural revolution” as well, must be present in all its stages. This educational quality is one of the most effective instruments for keeping the revolution from becoming institutionalized and stratified in a counter-revolutionary bureaucracy; for counter-revolution is carried out by revolutionaries who become reactionary.

如果在夺取政权之前无法与人民对话，因为人民没有对话经验，那么人民也不可能掌权，因为他们同样缺乏使用权力的经验。革命过程是动态的，正是在这种持续的动态中，在人民与革命领袖的实践中，人民和领袖将学会对话和使用权力。（这就像肯定一个人是在水中而不是在图书馆里学会游泳一样明显。）

Were it not possible to dialog ue with the people before power is taken, because they have no experience with dialogue, neither would it be possible for the people to come to power, for they are equally inexperienced in the use of power. The revolutionary process is dynamic, and it is in this continuing dynamics, in the praxis of the people with the revolutionary leaders, that the people and the lead-ers will learn both dialogue and the use of power. (This is as obvious as affirming that a person learns to swim in the water, not in a library.)

与人民对话既不是让步也不是恩赐，更不是用来统治的手段。对话是人们为“命名”世界而进行的相遇，是他们真正人性化的根本前提。用加约·彼得罗维奇的话来说：

Dialogue with the people is neither a concession nor a gift, much less a tactic to be used for domination. Dialogue, as the encounter among men to “name” the world, is a fundamental precondition for their true humanization. In the words of Gajo Petrovic:

自由的行动只能是人改变世界和自我的行动……自由的积极条件是对必然性的限度的认识，对人类创造可能性的认识……为自由社会而斗争，除非通过它创造了更大程度的个人自由，否则就不是为自由社会而斗争。12

A free action can only be one by which a man changes his world and himself . . . A positive condition of freedom is the know-ledge of the limits of necessity, the awareness of human creative possibilities . . . The struggle for a free society is not a struggle for a free society unless through it an ever greater degree of individual freedom is created.12

如果这种观点是正确的，那么革命过程就具有极强的教育意义。因此，革命之路需要对人民开放，而不是对人民冷漠无情；需要与人民交流，而不是不信任。而且，正如列宁所指出的，革命越需要理论，其领导人就越需要与人民站在一起，以抵抗压迫的力量。

If this view be true, the revolutionary process is eminently educational in character. Thus the road to revolution involves openness to the people, not imperviousness to them; it involves communion with the people, not mistrust. And, as Lenin pointed out, the more a revolution requires theory, the more its leaders must be with the people in order to stand against the power of oppression.

基于这些一般命题，让我们对反对话和对话行为的理论进行更为深入的分析。

Based on these general propositions, let us undertake a more lengthy analysis of the theories of antidialogical and dialogical action.

征服

Conquest

反对话行为的第一个特点是征服的必要性。反对话的个人在与他人的关系中，旨在征服他人——从最强硬到最精致，从最压抑到最关心（家长制），不断增加，用尽一切手段。

The first characteristic of antidialogical action is the necessity for conquest. The antidialogical individual, in his relations with others, aims at conquering them—increasingly and by every means, from the toughest to the most refined, from the most repressive to the most solicitous (paternalism).

每一次征服行为都意味着征服者和被征服的人或物。征服者将自己的目标强加给被征服者，并将其变为自己的所有物。他将自己的轮廓强加给被征服者，被征服者内化这种轮廓，成为“容纳”他人的模糊存在。从一开始，将人降为物的地位的征服行为就是恋尸癖。

Every act of conquest implies a conqueror and someone or something which is conquered. The conqueror imposes his objectives on the vanquished, and makes of them his possession. He imposes his own contours on the vanquished, who internalize this shape and become ambiguous beings “housing” another. From the first, the act of conquest, which reduces persons to the status of things, is necrophilic.

正如反对话行动伴随现实、具体的压迫形势一样，对话行动对于革命性地取代这种形势也是必不可少的。个人不是抽象的反对话或对话者，而是世界上的对话者。他或她不是先反对话，然后是压迫者；而是两者同时存在。在客观的压迫形势下，反对话对于压迫者来说是必要的，因为它是进一步压迫的手段——不仅是经济的，而且是文化的：被征服者被剥夺了他们的话语、他们的表达能力和他们的文化。此外，一旦压迫形势开始，反对话对于维持这种形势就变得不可或缺。

Just as antidialogical action is a concomitant of the real, concrete situation of oppression, dialogical action is indispensable to the revo-lutionary supersedence of that situation. An individual is not antidia­logical or dialogical in the abstract, but in the world. He or she is not first antidialogical, then oppressor; but both, simultaneously. Within an objective situation of oppression, antidialogue is necessary to the oppressor as a means of further oppression—not only economic, but cultural: the vanquished are dispossessed of their word, their expressiveness, their culture. Further, once a situation of oppression has been initiated, antidialogue becomes indispensable to its preservation.

因为解放行动本质上是对话性的，对话不能是解放行动的后继，而必须与解放行动同时发生。由于解放必须是一种永久状态，对话成为解放行动的一个持续方面。13

Because liberating action is dialogical in nature, dialogue cannot be a posteriori to that action, but must be concomitant with it. And since liberation must be a permanent condition, dialogue becomes a continuing aspect of liberating action.13

征服的欲望（或者说征服的必要性）始终存在于反对话的行动中。为此，压迫者试图摧毁被压迫者作为世界“观察者”的品质。由于压迫者无法完全实现这种破坏，他们必须将世界神话化。为了向被压迫者和被征服者展示一个旨在增加他们异化和被动性的欺骗世界，压迫者开发了一系列方法，排除将世界作为问题的任何呈现，而是将其展示为一个固定的实体，一个既定的东西——人们作为纯粹的旁观者必须适应的东西。

The desire for conquest (or rather the necessity of conquest) is at all times present in antidialogical action. To this end the oppressors attempt to destroy in the oppressed their quality as “considerers” of the world. Since the oppressors cannot totally achieve this destruction, they must mythicize the world. In order to present for the consideration of the oppressed and subjugated a world of deceit designed to increase their alienation and passivity, the oppressors develop a series of methods precluding any presentation of the world as a problem and showing it rather as a fixed entity, as something given—something to which people, as mere spectators, must adapt.

压迫者必须通过征服来接近人民，以使他们处于被动地位。但这种接近并不涉及与人民在一起，也不需要真正的交流。压迫者通过树立维护现状所必需的神话来实现这一目标：例如，压迫秩序是一个“自由社会”的神话；所有人都可以自由地在他们愿意的地方工作，如果他们不喜欢他们的老板，他们可以离开他并寻找另一份工作的神话；这种秩序尊重人权并因此值得尊重的神话；任何勤奋的人都可以成为企业家的神话——更糟糕的是，街头小贩和大工厂的老板一样都是企业家；普遍受教育权的神话，但巴西所有进入小学的孩子中，只有很小一部分能上大学；人人平等的神话，但“你知道你在和谁说话吗？”这个问题在我们中间仍然存在；神话压迫阶级作为“西方基督教文明”的捍卫者，反对“唯物主义野蛮主义”的英雄主义；精英阶层慈善和慷慨的神话，而他们作为一个阶级的真正所作所为是促进选择性的“善行”（后来发展成为“无私援助”的神话，在国际层面上受到教皇约翰二十三世的严厉批评）；14 占统治地位的精英阶层“认识到自己的责任”，促进人民的进步，以便人民出于感激之情，接受精英阶层的话语并顺从他们；反叛是对上帝的罪孽的神话；私有财产是个人发展的基础的神话（只要压迫者是唯一真正的人）；压迫者勤劳，被压迫者懒惰和不诚实的神话，以及后者天生低劣而前者优越的神话。15

It is necessary for the oppressors to approach the people in order, via subjugation, to keep them passive. This approximation, however, does not involve being with the people, or require true communication. It is accomplished by the oppressors’ depositing myths indispensable to the preservation of the status quo: for example, the myth that the oppressive order is a “free society”; the myth that all persons are free to work where they wish, that if they don’t like their boss they can leave him and look for another job; the myth that this order respects human rights and is therefore worthy of esteem; the myth that anyone who is industrious can become an entrepreneur—worse yet, the myth that the street vendor is as much an entrepreneur as the owner of a large factory; the myth of the universal right of education, when of all the Brazilian children who enter primary schools only a tiny fraction ever reach the university; the myth of the equality of all individuals, when the question: “Do you know who you’re talking to?” is still current among us; the myth of the heroism of the oppressor classes as defenders of “Western Christian civilization” against “materialist barbarism”; the myth of the charity and generosity of the elites, when what they really do as a class is to foster selective “good deeds” (subsequently elaborated into the myth of “disinterested aid,” which on the international level was severely criticized by Pope John XXIII);14 the myth that the dominant elites, “recognizing their duties,” promote the advancement of the people, so that t he people, in a gesture of gratitude, should accept the words of the elites and be conformed to them; the myth that rebellion is a sin against God; the myth of private property as fundamental to personal human development (so long as oppressors are the only true human beings); the myth of the industriousness of the oppressors and the laziness and dishonesty of the oppressed, as well as the myth of the natural inferiority of the latter and the superiority of the former.15

所有这些神话（以及读者可以列出的其他神话），其内化对于被压迫者的征服至关重要，都是通过精心组织的宣传和口号通过大众“传播”媒体呈现给他们的——就好像这种疏远构成了真正的交流！16

All these myths (and others the reader could list), the internalization of which is essential to the subjugation of the oppressed, are presented to them by well-organized propaganda and slogans, via the mass “communications” media—as if such alienation constituted real communication!16

总而言之，没有一种压迫现实不是必然反对话的，正如没有一种反对话，压迫者在其中不会孜孜不倦地献身于不断征服被压迫者。在古罗马，统治精英们谈到需要给人民“面包和马戏”，以“软化他们”并确保他们自己的安宁。今天的统治精英，就像任何时代的统治精英一样，继续（以“原罪”的形式）需要征服他人——无论有没有面包和马戏。征服的内容和方法在历史上各不相同；不变的是（只要统治精英存在）压迫的恋尸癖激情。

In sum, there is no oppressive reality which is not at the same time necessarily antidialogical, just as there is no antidialogue in which the oppressors do not untiringly dedicate themselves to the constant conquest of the oppressed. In ancient Rome, the dominant elites spoke of the need to give “bread and circus” to the people in order to “soften them up” and to secure their own tranquility. The dominant elites of today, like those of any epoch, continue (in a ­version of “original sin”) to need to conquer others—with or without bread and circus. The content and methods of conquest vary histori­cally; what does not vary (as long as dominant elites exist) is the ­necrophilic passion to oppress.

分而治之

Divide and Rule

这是压迫行为理论的另一个基本维度，它与压迫本身一样古老。由于压迫者少数服从多数并控制多数，因此为了继续掌权，他们必须分裂多数并保持多数的分裂。少数人不能容忍人民的统一，这无疑会对他们自己的霸权构成严重威胁。因此，压迫者会用任何方法（包括暴力）阻止任何行动，哪怕这些行动只是刚刚开始，而这些行动可能会唤醒被压迫者对团结的需要。团结、组织和斗争等概念立即被贴上了危险的标签。事实上，这些概念当然对压迫者来说是危险的，因为它们的实现对于解放行动是必要的。

This is another fundamental dimension of the theory of oppressive action which is as old as oppression itself. As the oppressor minority subordinates and dominates the majority, it must divide it and keep it divided in order to remain in power. The minority cannot permit itself the luxury of tolerating the unification of the people, which would undoubtedly signify a serious threat to their own ­hegemony. Accordingly, the oppressors halt by any method (including ­violence) any action which in even incipient fashion could awaken the op-pressed to the need for unity. Concepts such as unity, ­organization, and struggle are immediately labeled as dangerous. In fact, of course, these concepts are dangerous—to the oppressors—for their realization is necessary to actions of liberation.

压迫者的目的是进一步削弱被压迫者，孤立他们，制造和加深他们之间的裂痕。压迫者通过各种手段来实现这一目的，从政府官僚机构的镇压手段到文化行动，通过给人民留下他们正在得到帮助的印象来操纵人民。

It is in the interest of the oppressor to weaken the oppressed still further, to isolate them, to create and deepen rifts among them. This is done by varied means, from the repressive methods of the government bureaucracy to the forms of cultural action with which they manipulate the people by giving them the impression that they are being helped.

压迫性文化行动的一个特点是，它强调从局部角度看待问题，而不是将其视为整体的维度，而这些特点几乎从未被那些专注但天真的专业人士所察觉。在“社区发展”项目中，一个地区或区域被分解得越严重，如果不将这些社区作为整体本身和另一个整体（地区、区域等）的一部分进行研究，而这些整体又是一个更大的整体（国家，作为大陆整体的一部分）的一部分，那么异化就会加剧。人们越是被异化，就越容易分裂他们并使他们保持分裂。这些集中的行动形式通过强化被压迫者（尤其是在农村地区）集中的生活方式，阻碍了被压迫者批判性地看待现实，使他们与其他地区被压迫妇女和男子的问题隔绝。17

One of the characteristics of oppressive cultural action which is almost never perceived by the dedicated but naïve professionals who are involved is the emphasis on a focalized view of problems rather than on seeing them as dimensions of a totality. In “community development” projects the more a region or area is broken down into “local communities,” without the study of these communities both as totalities in themselves and as parts of another totality (the area, region, and so forth)—which in its turn is part of a still larger totality (the nation, as part of the continental totality)—the more alienation is intensified. And the more alienated people are, the ­easier it is to divide them and keep them divided. These ­focalized forms of action, by intensifying the focalized way of life of the op-pressed (especially in rural areas), hamper the oppressed from perceiving reality critically and keep them isolated from the problems of oppressed women and men in other areas.17

所谓的“领导培训课程”也产生了同样的分裂效应，这些课程最终会疏远人们（尽管许多组织者在开展这些课程时并没有这样的意图）。这些课程基于一个天真的假设，即人们可以通过培训社区的领导者来促进社区的发展——好像是部分促进了整体，而不是整体在得到提升时促进了部分的发展。那些表现出足够领导能力而被选中参加这些课程的社区成员必然会反映和表达他们社区个人的愿望。他们与他们的同志们的生活和思考现实的方式是一致的，尽管他们展现出特殊的能力，使他们获得了“领导者”的地位。一旦他们完成课程并带着他们以前不具备的资源回到社区，他们要么利用这些资源来控制他们同志们被淹没和被支配的意识，要么在自己的社区中成为陌生人，从而威胁到他们以前的领导地位。为了不失去领导地位，他们可能会倾向于继续操纵社区，但以更有效的方式。

The same divisive effect occurs in connection with the so-called “leadership training courses,” which are (although carried out without any such intention by many of their organizers) in the last analysis alienating. These courses are based on the naïve assumption that one can promote the community by training its leaders—as if it were the parts that promote the whole and not the whole which, in being promoted, promotes the parts. Those members of the commu­nities who show sufficient leadership capacities to be chosen for these courses necessarily reflect and express the aspirations of the individuals of their community. They are in harmony with the way of living and thinking about reality which characterizes their comrades, even though they reveal special abilities which give them the status of “leaders.” As soon as they complete the course and return to the community with resources they did not formerly possess, they either use these resources to control the submerged and dominated consciousness of their comrades, or they become strangers in their own communities and their former leadership position is thus threat­ened. In order not to lose their leadership status, they will probably tend to continue manipulating the community, but in a more efficient manner.

当文化行动作为一个整体化和全面化的过程，影响到整个社区而不仅仅是其领导者时，就会发生相反的过程。要么前任领导者与其他人一起成长，要么他们被社区新社会意识的出现所取代。

When cultural action, as a totalized and totalizing process, ap-proaches an entire community and not merely its leaders, the oppo-site process occurs. Either the former leaders grow along with ­everyone else, or they are replaced by new leaders who emerge as a result of the new social consciousness of the community.

压迫者并不赞成推动整个社会的发展，而是赞成选出领导者。后一种做法通过保持疏离状态，阻碍了意识的出现和对整体现实的批判性干预。而没有这种批判性干预，被压迫者作为一个阶级的团结总是很难实现的。

The oppressors do not favor promoting the community as a whole, but rather selected leaders. The latter course, by preserving a state of alienation, hinders the emergence of consciousness and critical intervention in a total reality. And without this critical intervention, it is always difficult to achieve the unity of the oppressed as a class.

阶级冲突是另一个让压迫者感到不安的概念，因为他们不想把自己视为压迫阶级。他们无法否认社会阶级的存在，尽管他们竭尽全力，但他们宣扬购买者和被迫出卖劳动力的人之间需要理解和和谐。18然而 ，两个阶级之间存在的不可掩盖的对抗使这种“和谐”成为不可能。19精英 们呼吁和谐，因为他们认为，阶级之间的和谐，就好像阶级是周日下午好奇地看着商店橱窗的偶然聚集体。唯一可行的和可证明的和谐是压迫者之间的和谐。尽管他们可能会有分歧，有时甚至会因为群体利益而发生冲突，但他们在阶级受到威胁时会立即团结起来。同样，被压迫者的和谐只有在其成员为解放而斗争时才有可能。只有在特殊情况下，两个阶级才不仅可能而且有必要团结起来并和谐行动；但是当使他们团结起来的紧急情况过去后，他们将回到定义他们存在的矛盾中，而这种矛盾从未真正消失过。

Class conflict is another concept which upsets the oppressors, since they do not wish to consider themselves an oppressive class. Unable to deny, try as they may, the existence of social classes, they preach the need for understanding and harmony between those who buy and those who are obliged to sell their labor.18 However, the unconcealable antagonism which exists between the two classes makes this “harmony” impossible.19 The elites call for harmony be-tween classes as if classes were fortuitous agglomerations of individuals curiously looking at a shop window on a Sunday afternoon. The only harmony which is viable and demonstrable is that found among the oppressors themselves. Although they may diverge and upon occasion even clash over group interests, they unite immediately at a threat to the class. Similarly, the harmony of the oppressed is only possible when its members are engaged in the struggle for libera­-tion. Only in exceptional cases is it not only possible but necessary for both classes to unite and act in harmony; but when the emer­-gency which united them has passed they will return to the contra­diction which defines their existence and which never really ­disappeared.

统治阶级的一切行动都表明，它需要分裂，以便于压迫国家的保存。它干涉工会，偏袒被统治阶级的某些“代表”（他们实际上代表的是压迫者，而不是他们自己的同志）；它提拔那些表现出领导能力的人，如果不这样“软化”，他们可能会构成威胁；它向一些人分配利益，向另一些人施以惩罚：所有这些都是为了维护有利于精英的制度而进行的分裂。这些行动形式直接或间接地利用了被压迫者的弱点之一：他们基本的不安全感。被压迫者作为“收容”压迫者的存在，在他们的双重性中是不安全的。一方面，他们反抗她或他；另一方面，在他们关系的某个阶段，他们被他或她吸引。在这种情况下，压迫者很容易从分裂行动中获得积极的结果。

All the actions of the dominant class manifest its need to divide in order to facilitate the preservation of the oppressor state. Its interference in the unions, favoring certain “representatives” of the dominated classes (who actually represent the oppressor, not their own comrades); its promotion of individuals who reveal leadership capacity and could signify a threat if they were not “softened up” in this way; its distribution of benefits to some and penalties to others: all these are ways of dividing in order to preserve the system which favors the elite. They are forms of action which exploit, directly or indirectly, one of the weak points of the oppressed: their basic insecurity. The oppressed are insecure in their duality as beings which “house” the oppressor. On the one hand, they resist her or him; on the other hand, at a certain stage in their relationship, they are attracted by him or her. Under these circumstances, the oppressors easily obtain positive results from divisive action.

此外，被压迫者从经验中知道，拒绝接受旨在阻止他们作为一个阶级团结的“邀请”的代价：失去工作，发现自己的名字被列入“黑名单”，这意味着其他工作的大门被关闭，这是最不可能发生的事。因此，他们基本的不安全感直接与奴役他们的劳动力（这实际上意味着奴役他们的人身，正如斯普利特主教强调的那样）。

In addition, the oppressed know from experience the price of not accepting an “invitation” offered with the purpose of preventing their unity as a class: losing their jobs and finding their names on a “black list” signifying closed doors to other jobs is the least that can happen. Their basic insecurity is thus directly linked to the enslavement of their labor (which really implies the enslavement of their person, as Bishop Split emphasized).

人们只有在创造自己的世界（即人类世界）并用他们的变革性劳动创造它时才会感到满足。因此，人类作为人的满足感在于世界的满足感。如果一个人在工作中完全依赖他人、没有安全感、永远受到威胁——如果他们的工作不属于他们——那么这个人就无法感到满足。不自由的工作不再是一种令人满意的追求，而成为一种有效的非人性化手段。

People are fulfilled only to the extent that they create their world (which is a human world), and create it with their transforming labor. The fulfillment of humankind as human beings lies, then, in the ­fulfillment of the world. If for a person to be in the world of work is to be totally dependent, insecure, and permanently threatened—if their work does not belong to them—the person cannot be ful­-filled. Work that is not free ceases to be a fulfilling pursuit and becomes an effective means of dehumanization.

被压迫者为团结而采取的每一个行动都指向其他行动；这意味着被压迫者迟早会意识到他们人格被非化的状态，并发现只要他们分裂，他们就永远是操纵和统治的容易牺牲品。团结和组织可以使他们把自己的弱点转化为一种变革力量，他们可以借此重塑世界，使它更加人性化。20然而 ，他们所向往的更加人性化的世界与压迫者的“人性世界”是对立的——压迫者独有的世界，他们鼓吹自己（非人性化）和被压迫者（被非人性化）之间不可能的和谐。由于压迫者和被压迫者是对立的，符合一个群体利益的事情也会损害另一个群体的利益。

Every move by the oppressed towards unity points towards other actions; it means that sooner or later the oppressed will perceive their state of depersonalization and discover that as long as they are divided they will always be easy prey for manipulation and domination. Unity and organization can enable them to change their weakness into a transforming force with which they can re-create the world and make it more human.20 The more human world to which they justly aspire, however, is the antithesis of the “human world” of the oppressors—a world which is the exclusive possession of the oppressors, who preach an impossible harmony between themselves (who dehumanize) and the oppressed (who are dehumanized). Since oppressors and oppressed are antithetical, what serves the interests of one group disserves the interests of the others.

因此，为了维持现状而进行分裂必然是反对话行动理论的基本目标。此外，统治者试图将自己展现为他们所非人化和分裂的男女的救世主。然而，这种救​​世主主义无法掩盖他们的真实意图：拯救自己。他们想要保住自己的财富、权力、生活方式：这些东西让他们能够征服他人。他们的错误在于，人们无法拯救自己（无论人们如何理解“拯救”），无论是作为个人还是作为压迫阶级。拯救只能通过他人来实现。然而，如果精英阶层进行压迫，他们就无法与被压迫者站在一起；因为反对他们是压迫的本质。

Dividing in order to preserve the status quo, then, is ­necessarily a fundamental objective of the theory of antidialogical action. In addition, the dominators try to present themselves as saviors of the women and men they dehumanize and divide. This messianism, however, cannot conceal their true intention: to save themselves. They want to save their riches, their power, their way of life: the things that enable them to subjugate others. Their mistake is that men cannot save themselves (no matter how one understands “salvation”), either as individuals or as an oppressor class. Salvation can be achieved only with others. To the extent, however, that the elites oppress, they cannot be with the oppressed; for being against them is the essence of oppression.

对压迫行为的心理分析可能会揭示压迫者的“虚假慷慨”（第 1 章中描述）是后者罪恶感的一个维度。凭借这种虚假的慷慨，他不仅试图维护不公正和恋尸癖的秩序，还试图为自己“购买”和平。和平是买不到的；和平是在团结和爱心行为中体验到的，而这些行为不能体现在压迫中。因此，反对话行动理论的弥赛亚元素强化了这种行动的第一个特征：征服的必要性。

A psychoanalysis of oppressive action might reveal the “false generosity” of the oppressor (described in chapter 1) as a dimension of the latter’s sense of guilt. With this false generosity, he attempts not only to preserve an unjust and necrophilic order, but to “buy” peace for himself. It happens that peace cannot be bought; peace is experience d in solidary and loving acts, which cannot be incarnated in oppression. Hence, the messianic element of the theory of antidialogical action reinforces the first characteristic of this action: the necessity for conquest.

因为必须分裂人民才能维持现状，从而维护统治者的权力，所以压迫者必须让被压迫者不察觉他们的策略。因此，压迫者必须让被压迫者相信，他们正在“保卫”自己，抵御“边缘人、流氓和上帝的敌人”的恶魔行为（因为这些是针对那些勇敢追求人性化的人的绰号）。为了分裂和迷惑人民，破坏者自称建设者，并指责真正的建设者是破坏性的。然而，历史总是会自行修改这些称谓。今天，虽然官方术语仍然称蒂拉登特斯 21 为阴谋家 （“不自信”） ，称他领导的自由主义运动为阴谋（ “不自信”），但民族英雄并不是那个 称蒂拉登特斯为“土匪”、命令他绞死并分尸，将血淋淋的尸体碎片散落在邻近村庄的街道上以示警戒。蒂拉登特斯才是英雄。历史撕毁了精英们给他的“头衔”，承认了他的行为是真实的。英雄是那些在自己时代寻求团结以求解放的人，而不是那些利用权力分裂和统治的人。

Since it is necessary to divide the people in order to preserve the status quo and (thereby) the power of the dominators, it is essential for the oppressors to keep the oppressed from perceiving their strat­egy. So the former must convince the latter that they are being “­defended” against the demonic action of “marginals, rowdies, and enemies of God” (for these are the epithets directed at men who lived and are living the brave pursuit of man’s humanization). In order to divide and confuse the people, the destroyers call themselves builders, and accuse the true builders of being destructive. History, however, always takes it upon itself to modify these designa­tions. Today, although the official terminology continues to call Ti­radentes21 a conspirator (“Inconfidente”) and the libertarian movement which he led a conspiracy (“Inconfidência”), the national hero is not the man22 who called Tiradentes a “bandit,” ordered him hanged and quartered, and had pieces of the bloody corpse strewn through the streets of the neighboring villages as an example. It is Tiradentes who is the hero. History tore up the “title” given him by the elites, and recognized his action for what it was. It is the men who in their own time sought unity for liberation who are the he­roes—not those who used their power to divide and rule.

操纵

Manipulation

操纵是反对话行动理论的另一个维度，与分裂策略一样，是一种征服工具：该理论的所有维度都围绕这一目标展开。通过操纵，统治精英试图让群众顺从他们的目标。这些人（无论是农村还是城市）的政治不成熟程度越高，他们就越容易被那些不想失去权力的人操纵。

Manipulation is another dimension of the theory of antidialogical action, and, like the strategy of division, is an instrument of conquest: the objective around which all the dimensions of the theory revolve. By means of manipulation, the dominant elites try to conform the masses to their objectives. And the greater the political immaturity of these people (rural or urban) the more easily the latter can be manipulated by those who do not wish to lose their power.

人民被本章前面描述的一系列神话所操纵，还有另一个神话：资产阶级向人民展示的资产阶级自身的模式，作为他们自身上升的可能性。然而，为了使这些神话发挥作用，人民必须接受资产阶级的话语。

The people are manipulated by the series of myths described earlier in this chapter, and by yet another myth: the model of itself which the bourgeoisie presents to the people as the possibility for their own ascent. In order for these myths to function, however, the people must accept the word of the bourgeoisie.

在特定历史条件下，操纵是通过统治阶级和被统治阶级之间的契约来实现的——这些契约，如果从表面上看，可能会给人一种阶级对话的印象。但实际上，这些契约并不是对话，因为它们的真正目标是由统治精英的明确利益决定的。归根结底，契约是统治者用来达到自己目的的。23人民 支持所谓的“民族资产阶级”来捍卫所谓的“民族资本主义”，就是一个例子点。这些契约迟早都会加剧人民的压迫。只有当人民开始（甚至天真地）脱离历史进程，并借此威胁统治精英时，才会提出这些契约。人民在历史进程中的存在，不再是单纯的旁观者，而是带着最初的攻击性迹象，足以令人不安，吓得统治精英加倍操纵策略。

Within certain historical conditions, manipulation is accom­plished by means of pacts between the dominant and the ­dominated classes—pacts which, if considered superficially, might give the impression of a dialogue between the classes. In reality, however, these pacts are not dialogue, because their true objectives are determined by the unequivocal interest of the dominant elites. In the last analysis, pacts are used by the dominators to achieve their own ends.23 The support given by the people to the so-called “national bourgeoisie” in defense of so-called “national capitalism” is an example in point. Sooner or later, these pacts always increase the subjugation of the people. They are proposed only when the people begin (even naively) to emerge from the historical process and by this emergence to threaten the dominant elites. The presence of the people in the historical process, no longer as mere spectators, but with the first signs of aggressivity, is sufficiently disquieting to frighten the dominant elites into doubling the tactics of manipulation.

在这个历史阶段，操纵成为维护统治的基本手段。在人民出现之前，没有操纵（确切地说），而是完全镇压。当被压迫者几乎完全淹没在现实中时，就没有必要操纵他们了。在反对话行动理论中，操纵是压迫者对历史进程的新具体条件的反应。通过操纵，统治精英可以引导人民进入一种不真实的“组织”，从而避免威胁性的选择：出现和正在出现的人民的真正组织。24后者 在进入历史进程时只有两种可能性：要么他们必须为自己的解放而真实地组织起来，要么他们将被精英操纵。统治者显然不会刺激真正的组织；这是革命领袖的任务。

In this historical phase, manipulation becomes a fundamental instrument for the preservation of domination. Prior to the emergence of the people there is no manipulation (precisely speaking), but rather total suppression. When the oppressed are almost completely submerged in reality, it is unnecessary to manipulate them. In the antidialogical theory of action, manipulation is the response of the oppressor to the new concrete conditions of the historical process. Through manipulation, the dominant elites can lead the people into an unauthentic type of “organization,” and can thus avoid the threatening alternative: the true organization of the emerged and emerging people.24 The latter have only two possibilities as they enter the historical process: either they must organize authentically for their liberation, or they will be manipulated by the elites. Authentic organization is obviously not going to be stimulated by the domi­nators; it is the task of the revolutionary leaders.

然而，被压迫的大多数人会形成城市无产阶级，尤其是在工业化程度较高的国家中心地区。尽管这些阶层偶尔会感到不安，但他们缺乏革命意识，认为自己享有特权。操纵以及一系列欺骗和承诺通常在这里找到沃土。

It happens, however, that large sectors of the oppressed form an urban proletariat, especially in the more industrialized centers of the country. Although these sectors are occasionally restive, they lack revolutionary consciousness and consider themselves privileged. Manipulation, with its series of deceits and promises, usually finds fertile ground here.

操纵的解药在于批判意识的革命政治组织，它将向人民提出他们在历史进程中的地位、国家现实以及操纵本身的问题。用弗朗西斯科·韦弗特的话来说：

The antidote to manipulation lies in a critically conscious revolutionary organization, which will pose to the people as problems their position in the historical process, the national reality, and manipulation itself. In the words of Francisco Weffert:

左翼的所有政策都基于群众，取决于群众的意识。如果群众意识混乱，左翼就会失去根基，必然会垮台，尽管（如巴西的情况）左翼可能会误以为它可以通过迅速重掌权力来实现革命。25

All the policies of the Left are based on the masses and depend on the consciousness of the latter. If that consciousness is con­fused, the Left will lose its roots and certain downfall will be imminent, although (as in the Brazilian case) the Left may be deluded into thinking it can achieve the revolution by means of a quick return to power.25

在被操纵的境况下，左翼几乎总是受到“迅速重掌权力”的诱惑，忘记了与被压迫者联合起来建立组织的必要性，误入与统治精英不可能的“对话”的误区，最终被这些精英所操纵，而自己也常常陷入一种精英主义的游戏，即所谓的“现实主义”。

In a situation of manipulation, the Left is almost always tempted by a “quick return to power,” forgets the necess ity of joining with the oppressed to forge an organization, and strays into an impossible “dialogue” with the dominant elites. It ends by being manipulated by these elites, and not infrequently itself falls into an elitist game, which it calls “realism.”

操纵就像征服一样，它所服务的目标就是试图麻醉人民，使他们无法思考。因为如果人民在参与历史进程的同时，对这一进程进行批判性思考，他们出现的威胁就会在革命中实现。无论人们把这种正确的思维称为“革命意识”还是“阶级意识”，它都是革命不可或缺的先决条件。统治精英们非常清楚这一事实，他们本能地使用一切手段，包括暴力，来阻止人民思考。他们敏锐地直觉到，对话能够培养批评能力。虽然一些革命领袖认为与人民对话是一种“资产阶级和反动”的活动，但资产阶级认为被压迫者和革命领袖之间的对话是一个非常现实的危险，必须避免。

Manipulation, like the conquest whose objectives it serves, attempts to anesthetize the people so they will not think. For if the people join to their presence in the historical process critical thinking about that process, the threat of their emergence materializes in revolution. Whether one calls this correct thinking “revolutionary consciousness” or “class consciousness,” it is an indispensable precondition of revolution. The dominant elites are so well aware of this fact that they instinctively use all means, including physical violence, to keep the people from thinking. They have a shrewd intuition of the ability of dialogue to develop a capacity for criticism. While some revolutionary leaders consider dialogue with the people a “bourgeois and reactionary” activity, the bourgeoisie regard dialogue between the oppressed and the revolutionary leaders as a very real danger to be avoided.

操纵的方法之一是向个人灌输资产阶级对个人成功的渴望。这种操纵有时由精英直接进行，有时由个人进行。直接通过民粹主义领袖。正如韦弗特指出的那样，这些领袖充当寡头精英与民众之间的中介。因此，民粹主义作为一种政治行动方式的出现与被压迫者的出现是因果一致的。从这一过程中崛起的民粹主义领袖是一个模棱两可的存在，是一个生活在两个元素中的“两栖动物”。他在民众和占主导地位的寡头集团之间来回穿梭，身上带着两个群体的印记。

One of the methods of manipulation is to inoculate individuals with the bourgeois appetite for personal success. This manipulation is sometimes carried out directly by the elites and sometimes indirectly, through populist leaders. As Weffert points out, these leaders serve as intermediaries between the oligarchical elites and the people. The emergence of populism as a style of political action thus coincides causally with the emergence of the oppressed. The populist leader who rises from this process is an ambiguous being, an “amphibian” who lives in two elements. Shuttling back and forth between the people and the dominant oligarchies, he bears the marks of both groups.

由于民粹主义领袖只是操纵，而不是为真正的民众组织而战，这种类型的领袖对革命几乎没有任何帮助。只有通过放弃其模棱两可的性格和双重行动，并果断地选择人民（从而不再是民粹主义者），他才能放弃操纵并致力于组织的革命任务。此时，他不再是人民和精英之间的中介，而是成为后者的矛盾体；于是精英们立即联手遏制他。请观察一下热图利奥·巴尔加斯26 在担任国家元首的最后时期，在 5 月 1 日庆祝活动上对工人发表的戏剧性和最终明确的讲话：

Since the populist leader simply manipulates, instead of fighting for authentic popular organization, this type of leader serves the revolution little if at all. Only by abandoning his ambiguous charac­ter and dual action and by opting decisively for the people (thus ceasing to be populist) does he renounce manipulation and ­dedicate himself to the revolutionary task of organization. At this point he ceases to be an intermediary between the people and the elites, and becomes a contradiction of the latter; thereupon the elites immediately join forces to curb him. Observe the dramatic and finally unequivocal terms in which Getulio Vargas26 spoke to the workers at a May 1 celebration during his last period as head of state:

我想告诉你们，如果没有工人的支持和每天的坚定合作，我的政府开始进行的巨大的革新工作就不可能成功完成。27

I want to tell you that the gigantic work of renewal which my Administration is beginning to carry out cannot be completed successfully without the support and the daily, steadfast cooperation of the workers.27

瓦加斯随后谈到了他上任后的前九十天，他称这是“对政府行动所面临的困难和障碍的评估”。他直接向民众讲述了他如何深刻感受到“无助、贫穷、高昂的生活成本、低工资……希望减少不幸者的痛苦，满足大多数对美好生活充满期待的人的需求。”

Vargas then spoke of his first ninety days in office, which he called “an estimate of the difficulties and obstacles which, here and there, are being raised in opposition to the actions of the government.” He spoke directly to the people about how deeply he felt “the help­lessness, poverty, the high cost of living, low salaries . . . the hopelessness of the unfortunate and the demands of the majority who live in hope of better days.”

他对工人的呼吁随后变得更加客观：

His appeal to the workers then took on more objective tones:

我来这里是想说，目前政府还没有法律或具体的工具来立即采取行动来保护人民的经济。因此，人民必须组织起来——不仅要捍卫自己的利益，还要为政府提供实现其目标所需的支持基础……我需要你们的团结。我需要你们团结一致地组织工会。我需要你们形成一个强大而有凝聚力的集团，与政府站在一起，这样政府就有解决你们问题所需的一切力量。我需要你们的团结，这样你们才能与破坏者作斗争，这样你们就不会沦为投机者和贪婪恶棍的牺牲品，损害人民的利益……现在是呼吁工人的时候了；在你们的工会中团结起来，成为自由和有组织的力量……目前，如果没有劳工组织的支持，任何政府都无法生存或拥有足够的力量来实现其社会目标。 二十八

I have come to say that at this moment the Administration does not yet have the laws or the concrete instruments for ­immediate action to defend the people’s economy. It is thus necessary for the people to organize—not only to defend their own interests, but also to give the government the base of support it requires to carry out its objectives . . . I need your unity. I need for you, in solidarity, to organize yourselves in unions. I need for you to form a strong and cohesive bloc to stand beside the government so that it will have all the force it needs to solve your problems. I need your unity so you can fight against saboteurs, so you do not fall prey to the interests of speculators and rapacious scoundrels in detriment of the interests of the people. . . . The hour has come to appeal to the workers; unite in your unions as free and organized forces . . . at the present time no Administra­tion can survive or dispose of sufficient force to achieve its social ends if it does not have the support of the laboring organiza­tions. 28

总之，瓦加斯在这次演讲中强烈呼吁人民组织起来，团结起来捍卫自己的权利；作为国家元首，他告诉他们，与他们一起治理国家会遇到障碍、阻碍和无数困难。从那一刻起，他的政府遇到了越来越多的困难，直到 1954 年 8 月悲剧的高潮。如果瓦加斯在他的最后一个任期内没有公开鼓励人民组织，随后又采取了一系列捍卫国家利益的措施，反动精英们可能就不会采取他们所做的极端措施了。

In sum, in this speech Vargas appealed vehemently to the people to organize and to unite in defense of their rights; and he told them, as Chief of State, of the obstacles, the hindrances, and the innumerable difficulties involved in governing with them. From that moment on his Administration encountered increasing ­difficulties, until the tragic climax of August 1954. If Vargas had not in his last term shown such open encouragement to the organization of the people, subsequently linked to a series of measures in defense of the national interest, possibly the reactionary elites would not have taken the extreme measures they did.

任何民粹主义领袖，只要以任何方式（即使是谨慎地）接近民众，而不是作为寡头政治的中间人，都会受到后者的遏制——如果他们有足够的力量阻止他的话。但只要领袖把自己限制在家长​​制和社会福利活动，尽管他与利益受到触及的寡头集团之间偶尔会有分歧，但深刻的分歧却很少。这是因为福利计划作为操纵工具，最终是为了征服的目的。它们起到麻醉剂的作用，分散了被压迫者的注意力，使他们不去关注问题的真正原因，也不去解决这些问题的具体问题。它们把被压迫者分裂成希望为自己多谋取一些利益的个人群体。然而，这种情况也包含一个积极的因素：得到一些援助的个人总是想要更多；那些没有得到援助的人，看到那些得到援助的人的例子，就会嫉妒，也想要得到帮助。由于统治精英不能“帮助”所有人，他们最终会加剧被压迫者的不安情绪。

Any populist leader who moves (even discreetly) towards the people in any way other than as the intermediary of the oligarchies will be curbed by the latter—if they have sufficient force to stop him. But as long as the leader restricts himself to paternalism and social welfare activities, although there may be occasional divergencies between him and groups of oligarchies whose interests have been touched, deep differences are rare. This is because welfare programs as instruments of manipulation ultimately serve the end of conquest. They act as an anesthetic, distracting the oppressed from the true causes of their problems and from the concrete solution of these problems. They splinter the oppressed into groups of individuals hoping to get a few more benefits for themselves. This situation contains, however, a positive element: the individuals who receive some aid always want more; those who do not receive aid, seeing the example of those who do, grow envious and also want assistance. Since the dominant elites cannot “aid” everyone, they end by in­creasing the restiveness of the oppressed.

革命领导者应该利用操纵的矛盾，将其作为被压迫者的问题，以组织他们。

The revolutionary leaders should take advantage of the contradictions of manipulation by posing it as a problem to the oppressed, with the objective of organizing them.

文化入侵

Cultural Invasion

反对话行动理论还有最后一个基本特征：文化入侵，它就像分裂策略和操纵一样，也服务于征服的目的。在这种现象中，入侵者渗透到另一个群体的文化背景，不尊重后者的潜力；他们把自己的世界观强加给入侵者，并通过限制被入侵者的表达来抑制他们的创造力。

The theory of antidialogical action has one last fundamental characteristic: cultural invasion, which like divisive tactics and manipula­tion also serves the ends of conquest. In this phenomenon, the invaders penetrate the cultural context of another group, in disre­spect of the latter’s potentialities; they impose their own view of the world upon those they invade and inhibit the creativity of the invaded by curbing their expression.

因此，无论是温和的还是粗暴的，文化入侵始终是对被入侵文化的个体的暴力行为，这些个体失去了原创性或面临失去原创性的威胁。在文化入侵中（就像在所有反对话行为中一样），入侵者是入侵过程的发起者和参与者；被入侵者是入侵对象。入侵者塑造；被入侵者被塑造。入侵者做出选择；被入侵者遵循这一选择——或者被期望遵循这一选择。入侵者采取行动；被入侵者通过入侵者的行动，只产生行动的幻觉。

Whether urbane or harsh, cultural invasion is thus always an act of violence against the persons of the invaded culture, who lose their originality or face the threat of losing it. In cultural invasion (as in all the modalities of antidialogical action) the invaders are the authors of, and actors in, the process; those they invade are the ­objects. The invaders mold; those they invade are molded. The invaders choose; those they invade follow that choice—or are expected to follow it. The invaders act; those they invade have only the illusion of acting, through the action of the invaders.

所有的统治都涉及侵略——有时是公开的、肉体上的侵略，有时是伪装的，侵略者扮演着帮助者的角色。归根结底，侵略是一种经济和文化统治。侵略可能由大都市社会对附属社会实施，也可能隐含在同一个社会中一个阶级对另一个阶级的统治中。

All domination involves invasion—at times physical and overt, at times camouflaged, with the invader assuming the role of a helping friend. In the last analysis, invasion is a form of economic and cultural domination. Invasion may be practiced by a metropolitan society upon a dependent society, or it may be implicit in the domination of one class over another within the same society.

文化征服导致被入侵者的文化不真实；他们开始对入侵者的价值观、标准和目标作出反应。入侵者热衷于统治，将他人塑造成他们的模式和生活方式，他们渴望知道被入侵者如何理解现实——但只是为了更有效地统治后者。29在 文化入侵中，被入侵者必须以入侵者的视角而不是自己的视角来看待现实；因为他们越模仿入侵者，后者的地位就越稳定。

Cultural conquest leads to the cultural inauthenticity of those who are invaded; they begin to respond to the values, the standards, and the goals of the invaders. In their passion to dominate, to mold others to their patterns and their way of life, the invaders desire to know how those they have invaded apprehend reality—but only so they can dominate the latter more effectively.29 In cultural invasion it is essential that those who are invaded come to see their reality with the outlook of the invaders rather than their own; for the more they mimic the invaders, the more stable the position of the latter becomes.

文化入侵要想成功，被入侵者必须确信自己天生低人一等。因为万事万物都有其对立面，如果被入侵者认为自己低人一等，他们就必然承认入侵者的优越性。后者的价值观因此成为前者的典范。入侵越是加剧，被入侵者越是疏远自己的文化精神和自我，后者就越是想像入侵者一样：像他们一样走路、穿衣、说话。

For cultural invasion to succeed, it is essential that those invaded become convinced of their intrinsic inferiority. Since everything has its opposite, if those who are invaded consider themselves inferior, they must necessarily recognize the superiority of the invaders. The values of the latter thereby become the pattern for the former. The more invasion is accentuated and those invaded are alienated from the spirit of their own culture and from themselves, the more the ­latter want to be like the invaders: to walk like them, dress like them, talk like them.

被入侵者的社会自我，就像每个社会自我一样，是在社会结构的社会文化关系中形成的，因此反映了被入侵文化的二元性。这种二元性（前面已经描述过）解释了为什么被入侵和被统治的个人，在他们存在体验的某一时刻，几乎“依附”于压迫者你。被压迫者我必须打破这种对压迫者你的近乎依附的状态，远离后者，以便更客观地看待他，此时她批判性地认识到自己与压迫者存在矛盾。在这样做的过程中，他“认为”他被压迫的结构是一种非人性的现实。这种对世界感知的质变只能在实践中实现。

The social I of the invaded person, like every social I, is formed in the socio-cultural relations of the social stucture, and therefore reflects the duality of the invaded culture. This duality (which was described earlier) explains why invaded and dominated individuals, at a certain moment of their existential experience, almost “adhere” to the oppressor Thou. The oppressed I must break with this near adhesion to the oppressor Thou, drawing away from the latter in order to see him more objectively, at which point she critically ­recognizes herself to be in contradiction with the oppressor.
