In so doing, he “considers” as a dehumanizing reality the structure in which he is being oppressed. This qualitative change in the perception of the world can only be achieved in the praxis.

文化入侵一方面是统治的工具，另一方面是统治的结果。因此，具有统治性质的文化行动（与其他形式的反对话行动一样）除了是经过深思熟虑和有计划的之外，在另一种意义上也只是压迫性现实的产物。

Cultural invasion is on the one hand an instrument of domination, and on the other, the result of domination. Thus, cultural action of a dominating character (like other forms of antidialogical action), in addition to being deliberate and planned, is in another sense simply a product of oppressive reality.

例如，僵化而压迫性的社会结构必然会影响该结构内的儿童抚养和教育机构。这些机构的行为模式遵循该结构的风格，并传播后者的神话。家庭和学校（从托儿所到大学）不是抽象的存在，而是存在于时间和空间中。在统治结构中，它们主要作为准备未来入侵者的机构发挥作用。

For example, a rigid and oppressive social structure necessarily influences the institutions of child rearing and education within that structure. These institutions pattern their action after the style of the structure, and transmit the myths of the latter. Homes and schools (from nurseries to universities) exist not in the abstract, but in time and space. Within the structures of domination they ­function largely as agencies which prepare the invaders of the future.

家庭中的亲子关系通常反映了周围社会结构的客观文化条件。如果家庭中的条件是专制的、僵化的和支配性的，家庭就会增加压迫的气氛。30随着 父母与子女之间的这种专制关系的加强，婴儿期的孩子会越来越多地内化父权。

The parent-child relationship in the home usually reflects the objective cultural conditions of the surrounding social structure. If the conditions which penetrate the home are authoritarian, rigid, and dominating, the home will increase the climate of oppression.30 As these authoritarian relations between parents and children intensify, children in their infancy increasingly internalize the paternal authority.

弗洛姆以一贯的清晰性提出了恋尸癖和亲生癖的问题，并分析了产生每种情况的客观条件，无论是在家庭中（冷漠和压迫的氛围或爱与自由的氛围中的亲子关系），还是在社会文化背景下。如果在无爱和压迫的环境中长大的孩子，其潜能受到挫败的孩子，在青春期无法走上真正的反叛之路，他们要么会陷入完全冷漠，被当局及其用来“塑造”他们的神话所疏远；要么会采取各种破坏性行动。

Presenting (with his customary clarity) the problem of necrophilia and biophilia, Fromm analyzes the objective conditions which generate each condition, whether in the home (parent-child relations in a climate of indifference and oppression or of love and freedom), or in a sociocultural context. If children reared in an atmosphere of lovelessness and oppression, children whose potency has been frustrated, do not manage during their youth to take the path of authentic rebellion, they will either drift into total indifference, alienated from reality by the authorities and the myths the latter have used to “shape” them; or they may engage in forms of destructive action.

家庭氛围在学校里延续，学生们很快发现（就像在家里一样）为了获得某种满足感，他们必须适应上级制定的戒律。这些戒律之一就是不要思考。

The atmosphere of the home is prolonged in the school, where the students soon discover that (as in the home) in order to achieve some satisfaction they must adapt to the precepts which have been set from above. One of these precepts is not to think.

这些年轻人通过学校所强调的僵化关系结构将父权内化，当他们成为专业人士时（正是因为这些关系灌输了对自由的恐惧），往往会重复他们所受过错误教育的僵化模式。这种现象，加上他们的阶级地位，也许可以解释为什么这么多专业人士坚持反对话行动。31无论 他们接触人民的专业是什么，他们几乎坚定地相信，他们的使命是“传授”人民他们的知识和技术。他们把自己视为人民的“推动者”。他们的行动计划（任何优秀的压迫行动理论家都可能规定这些计划）包括他们自己的目标、自己的信念和自己的关注点。他们不听人民的意见，而是计划教他们如何“摆脱懒惰”在这些专业人士看来，认为有必要尊重人民的“世界观”似乎是荒谬的。专业人士才是有“世界观”的人。他们认为，在组织教育行动的计划内容时必须征求人民的意见的说法同样荒谬。他们觉得，人民的无知是如此彻底，以至于他们除了接受专业人士的教导之外，什么都不配做。

Internalizing paternal authority through the rigid relationship structure emphasized by the school, these young people tend when they become professionals (because of the very fear of freedom instilled by these relationships) to repeat the rigid patterns in which they were miseducated. This phenomenon, in addition to their class position, perhaps explains why so many professionals adhere to anti-dialogical action.31 Whatever the specialty that brings them into contact with the people, they are almost unshakably convinced that it is their mission to “give” the latter their knowledge and techniques. They see themselves as “promotors” of the people. Their programs of action (which might have been prescribed by any good theorist of oppressive action) include their own objectives, their own convictions, and their own preoccupations. They do not listen to the people, but instead plan to teach them how to “cast off the laziness which creates underdevelopment.” To these professionals, it seems absurd to consider the necessity of respecting the “view of the world” held by the people. The professionals are the ones with a “world view.” They regard as equally absurd the affirmation that one must necessarily consult the people when organizing the program content of educational action. They feel that the ignorance of the people is so complete that they are unfit for anything except to receive the teachings of the professionals.

然而，当那些被入侵者在其生存体验的某个时刻开始以某种方式拒绝这种入侵（他们之前可能已经适应了这种入侵）时，专业人士为了证明自己的失败是合理的，会说被入侵群体的成员是“劣等的”，因为他们是“忘恩负义的”、“懒惰的”、“有病的”或“混血的”。

When, however, at a certain point of their existential experience, those who have been invaded begin in one way or another to reject this invasion (to which they might earlier have adapted), the professionals, in order to justify their failure, say that the members of the invaded group are “inferior” because they are “ingrates,” shiftless,” “diseased,” or of “mixed blood.”

善意的专业人士（那些使用“入侵”一词并非故意将其作为意识形态，而是将其作为自己成长经历的表达的人）最终发现，他们某些教育上的失败必须归咎于他们自己侵略行为的暴力，而不是“普通民众”的内在劣势。那些发现这一点的人面临着一个艰难的选择：他们觉得有必要放弃侵略，但统治模式在他们心中根深蒂固，以至于这种放弃会成为对他们自身身份的威胁。放弃侵略意味着结束他们作为被统治者和统治者的双重身份。这意味着放弃所有滋生侵略的神话，并开始体现对话行动。正因为如此，这意味着不再处于统治者或内部（作为外国人），而是与他人在一起（作为同志）。因此，对自由的恐惧控制了这些人。在这个痛苦的过程中，他们自然倾向于用一系列逃避来合理化他们的恐惧。

Well-intentioned professionals (those who use “invasion” not as deliberate ideology but as the expression of their own upbringing) eventually discover that certain of their educational failures must be ascribed, not to the intrinsic inferiority of the “simple men of the people,” but to the violence of their own act of invasion. Those who make this discovery face a difficult alternative: they feel the need to renounce invasion, but patterns of domination are so entrenched within them that this renunciation would become a threat to their own identities. To renounce invasion would mean ending their dual status as dominated and dominators. It would mean abandoning all the myths which nourish invasion, and starting to incarnate dialogical action. For this very reason, it would mean to cease being over or inside (as foreigners) in order to be with (as comrades). And so the fear of freedom takes hold of these men. During this traumatic process, they naturally tend to rationalize their fear with a series of evasions.

对于那些还没有发现自己的行为具有侵略性，并被告知其行为不人道的专业人士来说，对自由的恐惧更大。培训课程的参与者经常会以恼怒的口吻问协调员：“你到底想把我们引向何方？”协调员并不是想“引”他们去任何地方；只是在面对具体情况时，参与者开始意识到，如果他们对情况的分析更深入，他们要么必须放弃自己的神话，要么必须重申自己的神话。在那一刻，放弃和放弃自己的神话代表着一种自我暴力行为。另一方面，重申这些神话就是暴露自己。唯一的出路（起到防御机制的作用）是将他们自己的惯常做法投射到协调员身上：引导、征服和入侵 。32

The fear of freedom is greater still in professionals who have not yet discovered for themselves the invasive nature of their action, and who are told that their action is dehumanizing. Not infrequently, especially at the point of decoding concrete situations, training course participants ask the coordinator in an irritated manner: “Where do you think you’re steering us, anyway?” The coordinator isn’t trying to “steer” them anywhere; it is just that in facing a concrete situation as a problem, the participants begin to realize that if their analysis of the situation goes any deeper they will either have to divest themselves of their myths, or reaffirm them. ­Divesting themselves of and renouncing their myths represents, at that moment, an act of self-violence. On the other hand, to reaffirm those myths is to reveal themselves. The only way out (which functions as a defense mechanism) is to project onto the coordinator their own usual practices: steering, conquering, and invading. 32

这种退缩在那些被压迫的具体处境压垮、被慈善驯服的人们中也发生过，尽管规模较小。在罗伯特·福克斯的协调下，在纽约市开展了一项有价值的教育计划的“Full Circle” 33 的一位教师讲述了以下事件。纽约贫民窟的一个小组被呈现了一个编码的场景，场景中显示街角有一大堆垃圾——就在小组开会的那条街上。其中一位参与者立刻说：“我看到了一条非洲或拉丁美洲的街道。”“为什么不是在纽约？”老师问道。“因为我们是美国，这种事情不可能发生在这里。”毫无疑问，这个人和一些同意他观点的同志们正在逃避一个对他们来说如此令人反感的现实，以至于承认这个现实都是威胁。对于一个被成就和个人成功文化所制约的被疏远的人来说，承认自己的处境客观上不利似乎会阻碍他自己获得成功的可能性。

This same retreat occurs, though on a smaller scale, among men of the people who have been ground down by the concrete situation of oppression and domesticated by charity. One of the teachers of “Full Circle,”33 which carried out a valuable educational program in New York City under the coordination of Robert Fox, relates the ­following incident. A group in a New York ghetto was presented a coded situation showing a big pile of garbage on a street corner—the very same street where the group was meeting. One of the participants said at once, “I see a street in Africa or Latin America.” “And why not in New York?” asked the teacher. “Because we are the United States and that can’t happen here.” Beyond a doubt this man and some of his comrades who agreed with him were retreating from a reality so offensive to them that even to acknowledge that reality was threatening. For an alienated person, conditioned by a culture of achievement and personal success, to recognize his situation as objectively unfavorable seems to hinder his own possibilities of success.

在上述案例以及专业人士的案例中，文化的决定性力量显而易见，它发展了人们随后内化的神话。在这两种情况下，统治阶级的文化都阻碍了人们作为决策者的肯定。两者都没有无论是专业人士还是纽约贫民窟的讨论参与者，都不是作为历史进程的积极主体为自己说话和行动。他们都不是统治的理论家或空想家。相反，他们是结果，反过来又成为统治的原因。这是革命在取得权力时必须面对的最严重的问题之一。这一阶段要求领导者具备最大的政治智慧、决断力和勇气，正因为如此，他们必须有足够的判断力，以免陷入非理性的宗派主义立场。

In the case cited, and in that of the professionals, the ­determining force of the culture which develops the myths men subsequently internalize is evident. In both cases, the culture of the dominant class hinders the affirmation of men as beings of decision. Neither the professionals nor the discussion participants in the New York slums talk and act for themselves as active Subjects of the historical process. None of them are theoreticians or ideologues of domination. On the contrary, they are effects which in turn become causes of domination. This is one of the most serious problems the revolution must confront when it reaches power. This stage demands maximum political wisdom, decision, and courage from the leaders, who for this very reason must have sufficient judgment not to fall into irrationally sectarian positions.

无论是否大学毕业，任何专业的职业女性和男性都是被统治文化“从上而下决定的” 34 个体，这种文化将他们塑造为双重人格。（如果他们来自下层阶级，这种错误教育将是相同的，甚至更糟。）然而，这些专业人士对于新社会的重组是必不可少的。而且，由于他们中的许多人——尽管“害怕自由”并且不愿意参与人性化行动——实际上比其他任何人都更受误导，因此他们不仅可以，而且应该被革命重新改造。

Professional women and men of any specialty, university graduates or not, are individuals who have been “determined from above”34 by a culture of domination which has constituted them as dual beings. (If they had come from the lower classes this miseducation would be the same, if not worse.) These professionals, however, are necessary to the reorganization of the new society. And since many among them—even though “afraid of freedom” and reluctant to engage in humanizing action—are in truth more misguided than anything else, they not only could be, but ought to be, reclaimed by the ­revolution.

这一改造要求革命领袖从之前的对话式文化行动中前进，发起“文化革命”。此时，革命力量不再只是那些想要否定人类的人所面临的必要障碍，而是采取了一种新的、更大胆的立场，向所有希望参与社会重建的人发出了明确的邀请。从这个意义上说，“文化革命”是革命取得权力之前必须进行的对话式文化行动的必要延续。

This reclamation requires that the revolutionary leaders, progressing from what was previously dialogical cultural action, initiate the “cultural revolution.” At this point, revolutionary power moves beyond its role as a necessary obstacle confronting those who wish to negate humanity, and assumes a new and bolder position, with a clear invitation to all who wish to participate in the reconstruction of society. In this sense, “cultural revolution” is a necessary continu­ation of the dialogical cultural action which must be carried out before the revolution reaches power.

“文化革命”把要重建的整个社会，包括一切人类活动，作为改造行动的对象。社会不可能机械地重建，通过革命文化再造的文化是重建社会的根本手段。“文化革命”是革命的手段。革命政权在提高意识方面做出的最大努力是——它应该影响到每一个人，无论他们的个人道路如何。

“Cultural revolution” takes the total society to be reconstructed, including all human activities, as the object of its remolding action. Society cannot be reconstructed in a mechanistic fashion; the culture which is culturally recreated through revolution is the fundamental instrument for this reconstruction. “Cultural revolution” is the revo­lutionary regime’s maximum effort at conscientização—it should reach everyone, regardless of their personal path.

因此，这种意识提升的努力不能满足于对目标专家进行技术或科学培训。新社会在质量上与旧社会 有相当大的不同，而且这种不同不止是部分不同。革命社会不能把前一个社会所赋予的相同目的归于技术；因此，两个社会对人的培训也必须有所不同。只要革命社会中的科学和技术服务于永久的解放和人性化，技术和科学培训就不必与人文教育相抵触。

Consequently, this effort at conscientização cannot rest content with the technical or scientific training of intended specialists. The new society becomes qualitatively distinct from the old35 in more than a partial way. Revolutionary society cannot attribute to technol­ogy the same ends attributed by the previous society; accordingly, the training of people in the two societies must also differ. Technical and scientific training need not be inimical to humanistic education as long as science and technology in the revolutionary society are at the service of permanent liberation, of humanization.

从这个角度来看，对任何职业的个人进行培训（因为所有职业都发生在时间和空间中）都需要理解（a）文化是一种上层建筑，它可以在经历革命变革的下层建筑中保持过去的“残余” 36 的活力，以及（b）职业本身是文化变革的工具。随着文化革命加深新社会创造性实践中的意识，人们将开始理解为什么旧社会的神话残余会在新社会中生存。然后他们将能够更快地摆脱这些幽灵，这些幽灵通过阻碍新社会的教化，一直是每次革命的严重问题。通过这些文化残余，压迫社会继续入侵——这次入侵的是革命社会本身。

From this point of view, the training of individuals for any occupa­tion (since all occupations occur in time and space) requires the understanding of (a) culture as a superstructure which can maintain “remnants” of the past36 alive in the substructure undergoing revolutionary transformation and (b) the occupation itself as an instrument for the transformation of culture. As the cultural revolution deepens conscientização in the creative praxis of the new society, people will begin to perceive why mythical remnants of the old society survive in the new. And they will then be able to free themselves more rapidly of these specters, which by hindering the edification of a new society have always constituted a serious problem for every ­revolution. Through these cultural remnants the oppressor society continues to invade—this time invading the revolutionary society itself.

这种入侵尤其可怕，因为它不是由重组的统治精英进行的，而是由那些参与革命的人进行的。作为“收容”压迫者的人，他们像压迫者自己一样抵制革命必须采取的进一步基本步骤。作为双重存在，他们也接受（仍然由于残余）权力，这种权力变得官僚化，并对他们进行暴力镇压。反过来，这种暴力镇压官僚权力的出现可以用阿尔都塞所说的每当特殊情况允许时在新社会中“旧元素的重新激活” 37来解释。

This invasion is especially terrible because it is carried out not by the dominant elite reorganized as such, but by those who have ­participated in the revolution. As men who “house” the ­oppressor, they resist as might the latter themselves the further basic steps which the revolution must take. And as dual beings they also accept (still due to the remnants) power which becomes bureaucratized and which violently represses them. In turn, this violently repressive bureaucratic power can be explained by what Althusser calls the “reactivation of old elements”37 in the new society each time special circumstances permit.

出于上述原因，我将革命过程解释为对话式的文化行动，一旦夺取政权，这一行动将在“文化革命”中延续下去。在这两个阶段，都需要认真而深刻地努力进行意识教育——通过这种教育，人们通过真正的实践，摆脱客体地位，成为历史主体。

For all the above reasons, I interpret the revolutionary process as dialogical cultural action which is prolonged in “cultural revolution” once power is taken. In both stages a serious and profound effort at conscientização—by means of which the people, through a true praxis, leave behind the status of objects to assume the status of ­historical Subjects—is necessary.

最后，文化革命发展了领导人与人民之间永久对话的实践，巩固了人民当权者的参与。这样，随着领导人和人民继续他们的批判活动，革命将更容易地抵御官僚主义倾向（这会导致新的压迫形式）和“入侵”（入侵总是一样）。入侵者——无论是在资产阶级社会还是在革命社会——可能是农学家或社会学家、经济学家或公共卫生工程师、牧师或牧师、教育家或社会工作者——或革命者。

Finally, cultural revolution develops the practice of permanent dialogue between leaders and people, and consolidates the partici­pation of the people in power. In this way, as both leaders and ­people continue their critical activity, the revolution will more easily be able to defend itself against bureaucratic tendencies (which lead to new forms of oppression) and against “invasion” (which is always the same). The invader—whether in a bourgeois or in a revolutionary society—may be an agronomist or a sociologist, an economist or a public health engineer, a priest or a pastor, an educator or a social worker—or a revolutionary.

文化入侵是为了征服和维护压迫，它总是包含着狭隘的现实观、静态的世界观以及将一种世界观强加于另一种世界观。它暗示着入侵者的“优越性”和被入侵者的“劣等性”，以及前者强加的价值观，因为后者拥有后者，并且害怕失去它们。

Cultural invasion, which serves the ends of conquest and the ­preservation of oppression, always involves a parochial view of reality, a static perception of the world, and the imposition of one world view upon another. It implies the “superiority” of the invader and the “inferiority” of those who are invaded, as well as the ­imposition of values by the former, who possess the latter and are afraid of losing them.

文化入侵进一步表明，被入侵者行为的最终决定权不在于他们，而在于入侵者。当决策权在应该做决定的人之外而不是在应该做决定的人之内时，后者就只有做决定的幻觉。这就是为什么在一个双重的、“反射性”的被入侵社会中不可能有社会经济发展。因为要发生发展，必须：a）存在探索和创造的运动，其决定权在探索者手中；b）这种运动不仅发生在空间中，而且发生在有意识的探索者的存在时间中。

Cultural invasion further signifies that the ultimate seat of decision regarding the action of those who are invaded lies not with them but with the invaders. And when the power of decision is located outside rather than within the one who should decide, the latter has only the illusion of deciding. This is why there can be no socio-economic development in a dual, “reflex,” invaded society. For development to occur it is necessary: a) that there be a movement of search and creativity having its seat of decision in the searcher; b) that this movement occur not only in space, but in the existential time of the conscious searcher.

因此，虽然所有发展都是转变，但并非所有转变都是发展。种子在有利条件下发芽并生根，这种转变不是发展。同样，动物的转变也不是发展。种子和动物的转变由它们所属的物种决定；它们发生在不属于它们的时间里，因为时间属于人类。

Thus, while all development is transformation, not all transformation is development. The transformation occurring in a seed which under favorable conditions germinates and sprouts, is not development. In the same way, the transformation of an animal is not development. The transformations of seeds and animals are determined by the species to which they belong; and they occur in a time which does not belong to them, for time belongs to humankind.

在未完成的存在中，只有女性和男性在发展。作为历史的、自传的“自为的存在者”，他们的转变（发展）发生在他们自己的存在时间中，而不是在它之外。受制于具体压迫条件的男性无法真正发展，在压迫条件下，他们成为异化的“他人的存在者”，而不是他们所依赖的虚假的“自为的存在者”。他们被剥夺了自己在压迫者身上的决定权，只能遵循压迫者的规定。被压迫者只有在克服了他们所陷入的矛盾，成为“自为的存在者”时，才开始发展。

Women and men, among the uncompleted beings, are the only ones which develop. As historical, autobiographical, “beings for themselves,” their transformation (development) occurs in their own existential time, never outside it. Men who are submitted to con­crete conditions of oppression in which they become alienated “beings for another” of the false “being for himself” on whom they depend, are not able to develop authentically. Deprived of their own power of decision, which is located in the oppressor, they follow the prescriptions of the latter. The oppressed only begin to develop when, surmounting the contradiction in which they are caught, they become “be ings for themselves.”

如果我们将社会视为一种存在，那么显然只有“自为存在”的社会才能发展。二元的、“反射的”、被入侵的、依赖大都市社会的社会无法发展，因为它们被异化了；它们的政治、经济和文化决策权位于它们自身之外，位于入侵者社会中。归根结底，后者决定了前者的命运：仅仅是转型；因为正是它们的转型——而不是它们的发展——符合大都市社会的利益。

If we consider society as a being, it is obvious that only a society which is a “being for itself” can develop. Societies which are dual, “reflex,” invaded, and dependent on the metropolitan society cannot develop because they are alienated; their political, economic, and cultural decision-making power is located outside themselves, in the invader society. In the last analysis, the latter determines the destiny of the former: mere transformation; for it is their transformation—not their development—that is to the interest of the metropolitan society.

重要的是不要将现代化与发展混为一谈。前者虽然可能会影响“卫星社会”中的某些群体，但几乎总是被诱导的；而大都市社会才是从中真正受益的。一个只实现现代化而没有发展的社会将继续存在——即使它接管了一些最低限度的下放决策权——依赖外部国家。这是任何依赖性社会的命运，只要它仍然依赖外部国家。

It is essential not to confuse modernization with development. The former, although it may affect certain groups in the “satellite society,” is almost always induced; and it is the metropolitan society which derives the true benefits therefrom. A society which is merely modernized without developing will continue—even if it takes over some minimal delegated powers of decision—to depend on the outside country. This is the fate of any dependent society, as long as it remains dependent.

要判断一个社会是否在发展，就必须超越基于“人均”收入指数（以统计形式表达，具有误导性）以及专注于总收入研究的标准。最基本的标准是这个社会是否“自为存在”。如果不是，其他标准表明的是现代化，而不是发展。

In order to determine whether or not a society is developing, one must go beyond criteria based on indices of “per capita” income (which, expressed in statistical form, are misleading) as well as those which concentrate on the study of gross income. The basic, elementary criterion is whether or not the society is a “being for itself.” If it is not, the other criteria indicate modernization rather than development.

二元社会的主要矛盾，是二元社会与宗主社会的依附关系，一旦克服了这一矛盾，此前通过“援助”实现的改造（主要受益于宗主社会）就变成了真正的发展，有利于“自为”。

The principal contradiction of dual societies is the relationship of dependency between them and the metropolitan society. Once the contradiction has been superseded, the transformation hitherto effected through “aid,” which has primarily benefitted the metropolitan society, becomes true development, which benefits the “being for itself.”

出于上述原因，这些社会所尝试的纯粹改革主义解决方案（尽管其中一些改革可能会吓到甚至惊慌失措的精英群体中的反动分子）并不能解决其内部和外部矛盾。大都市社会几乎总是为了响应历史进程的要求而采取这些改革主义解决方案，作为维护其霸权的新方式。大都市社会似乎在说：“让我们在人民进行革命之前进行改革。”为了实现这一目标，大都市社会别无选择，只能征服、操纵、对附属社会进行经济和文化（有时是军事）入侵——在这种入侵中，被统治社会的精英领导人在很大程度上只是大都市社会领导人的经纪人。

For the above reasons, the purely reformist solutions attempted by these societies (even though some of the reforms may frighten and even panic the more reactionary members of the elite groups) do not resolve their external and internal contradictions. Almost always the metropolitan society induces these reformist solutions in response to the demands of the historical process, as a new way of preserving its hegemony. It is as if the metropolitan society were saying: “Let us carry out reforms before the people carry out a revolution.” And in order to achieve this goal, the metropolitan soci­ety has no options other than conquest, manipulation, economic and cultural (and sometimes military) invasion of the dependent society—an invasion in which the elite leaders of the dominated ­society to a large extent act as mere brokers for the leaders of the metropolitan society.

在结束对反对话行动理论的尝试性分析之前，我想重申，革命领袖不能使用压迫者所使用的反对话程序；相反，革命领袖必须遵循对话和沟通的道路。

To close this tentative analysis of the theory of antidialogical action, I wish to reaffirm that revolutionary leaders must not use the same antidialogical procedures used by the oppressors; on the contrary, revolutionary leaders must follow the path of dialogue and of communication.

在继续分析对话行动理论之前，有必要简要讨论一下革命领导团体是如何形成的，以及革命进程的一些历史和社会后果。通常，这个领导团体由以某种方式属于统治者社会阶层的男男女女组成。在他们生存经历的某个时刻，在特定的历史条件下，这些领导人放弃了他们所属的阶级，加入了被压迫者的行列，这是一种真正的团结（或者人们希望如此）。不管这种坚持是否源于对现实的科学分析，它都代表着（当真实的时候）一种爱和真正的承诺的行为。38加入被压迫者需要去找他们并与他们交流。人民必须在新兴领导人中找到自己，而新兴领导人必须 在人民中找到自己。

Before proceeding to analyze the theory of dialogical action, it is essential to discuss briefly how the revolutionary leadership group is formed, and some of the historical and sociological consequences for the revolutionary process. Usually this leadership group is made up of men and women who in one way or another have belonged to the social strata of the dominators. At a certain point in their existen­tial experience, under certain historical conditions, these leaders renounce the class to which they belong and join the oppressed, in an act of true solidarity (or so one would hope). Whether or not this adherence results from a scientific analysis of reality, it represents (when authentic) an act of love and true commitment.38 Joining the oppressed requires going to them and communicating with them. The people must find themselves in the emerging leaders, and the latter must find themselves in the people.

出现的领袖必然反映了被压迫者传达给他们的统治精英的矛盾，然而，被压迫者可能还没有清楚地认识到他们自己的压迫状态，或者批判地认识到他们与压迫者的对抗关系。39他们可能仍然处于以前被称为“附庸”压迫者的地位。另一方面，由于某些客观历史条件， 他们可能已经对自己的压迫状态有了相对清晰的认识。

The leaders who have emerged necessarily reflect the contradiction of the dominant elites communicated to them by the oppressed, who may not yet, however, clearly perceive their own state of oppression or critically recognize their relationship of antagonism to the oppressors.39 They may still be in the position previously termed “adhesion” to the oppressor. On the other hand, it is possible that due to certain objective historical conditions they have already reached a relatively clear perception of their state of oppression.

在第一种情况下，人民对压迫者的依附（或部分依附）使他们无法（重复法农的观点）将压迫者置于他们之外。在第二种情况下，他们能够找到压迫者，从而批判性地认识到他们与压迫者的对抗关系。

In the first case, the adhesion—or partial adhesion—of the ­people to the oppressor makes it impossible for them (to repeat Fanon’s point) to locate him outside themselves. In the second case, they can locate the oppressor and can thus critically recognize their relationship of antagonism to him.

在第一种情况下，压迫者“藏身”于人民之中，由此产生的模糊性使他们害怕自由。他们（在压迫者的刺激下）诉诸于神奇的解释或虚假的他们将自己受压迫状态的责任推卸给上帝。40这些自我怀疑、饱受压迫、绝望的人民极不可能寻求自己的解放——他们可能认为这种反抗行为是对上帝意志的不服从，是对命运的无端对抗。（因此，经常强调必须把压迫者 灌输给人民的神话当作问题。）在第二种情况下，当人民对压迫有了相对清晰的认识，使他们把压迫者定位在自己之外时，他们就开始为克服自己所处的矛盾而斗争。此时，他们克服了“阶级必然性”和“阶级意识”之间的距离。

In the first case, the oppressor is “housed” within the people, and their resulting ambiguity makes them fearful of freedom. They resort (stimulated by the oppressor) to magical explanations or a false view of God, to whom they fatalistically transfer the responsibility for their oppressed state.40 It is extremely unlikely that these self-mistrustful, downtrodden, hopeless people will seek their own liberation—an act of rebellion which they may view as a disobedient violation of the will of God, as an unwarranted confrontation with destiny. (Hence, the oft-emphasized necessity of posing as problems the myths fed to the people by the oppressors.) In the second case, when the people have reached a relatively clear picture of oppres­sion which leads them to localize the oppressor outside themselves, they take up the struggle to surmount the contradiction in which they are caught. At this moment they overcome the distance be­tween “class necessity” and “class consciousness.”

在第一种情况下，革命领袖不幸地、不由自主地成为人民的矛盾体。在第二种情况下，新兴领袖从人民那里得到同情和几乎即时的支持，这种支持在革命行动过程中往往会增加。领袖以一种自发的、狡猾的对话方式走向人民。人民和革命领袖之间几乎立即产生了共鸣：他们之间的相互承诺几乎立即得到了确认。在友谊中，他们认为自己是统治精英的平等矛盾。从这一点开始，人民和领袖之间对话的既定做法几乎是不可动摇的。当掌权时，这种对话将继续下去；人民会知道他们已经掌权了。

In the first case, the revolutionary leaders unfortunately and invol­untarily become the contradiction of the people. In the second case, the emerging leaders receive from the people sympathetic and al­most instantaneous support, which tends to increase during the process of revolutionary action. The leaders go to the people in a spontaneou sly dialogical manner. There is an almost immediate empathy between the people and the revolutionary leaders: their mutual commitment is almost instantly sealed. In fellowship, they consider themselves co-equal contradictions of the dominant elites. From this point on, the established practice of dialogue between people and leaders is nearly unshakable. That dialogue will continue when power is reached; and the people will know that they have come to power.

这种分享绝不会削弱革命领袖所应具备的斗争精神、勇气、爱心和胆识。菲德尔·卡斯特罗和他的同志们（当时许多人称他们为“不负责任的冒险家”）是一个极具对话精神的领导团体，他们与那些遭受残酷暴力的人们感同身受。巴蒂斯塔独裁统治的胜利。这种坚持并不容易；它需要领导人有足够的勇气去热爱人民，愿意为人民牺牲自己。它需要领导人勇敢地见证每一次灾难之后重新开始，对未来的胜利抱有不灭的希望，而这场胜利（因为是与人民共同铸就的）不仅属于领导人，而且属于领导人和人民——或者属于包括领导人在内的人民。

This sharing in no way diminishes the spirit of struggle, courage, capacity for love, or daring required of the revolutionary ­leaders. Fidel Castro and his comrades (whom many at the time termed “irresponsible adventurers”), an eminently dialogical leadership group, identified with the people who endured the brutal violence of the Batista dictatorship. This adherence was not easy; it required bravery on the part of the leaders to love the people sufficiently to be willing to sacrifice themselves for them. It required courageous witness by the leaders to recommence after each disaster, moved by undying hope in a future victory which (because forged together with the people) would belong not to the leaders alone, but to the leaders and the people—or to the people, including the leaders.

菲德尔逐渐分化了古巴人民的忠诚，而由于他们的历史经验，古巴人民已经开始脱离压迫者的忠诚。这种“脱离”压迫者的行为导致人民将他视为客体，并将自己视为他的矛盾。因此，菲德尔从未与人民发生矛盾。（格瓦拉在他的《革命战争关系》中偶尔出现叛逃或背叛，他在书中也提到了许多追随者，这是意料之中的。）

Fidel gradually polarized the adherence of the Cuban people, who due to their historical experience had already begun to break their adhesion to the oppressor. This “drawing away” from the oppressor led the people to objectify him, and to see themselves as his contradiction. So it was that Fidel never entered into contradiction with the people. (The occasional desertions or betrayals regis­tered by Guevara in his Relato de la Guerra Revolucionaria—in which he also refers to the many who adhered—were to be expected.)

因此，由于某些历史条件，革命领袖向人民的运动要么是水平的——领袖和人民形成一个整体，与压迫者对立——要么是三角的，革命领袖占据三角形的顶点，与压迫者和被压迫者对立。正如我们所看到的，当人民还没有对压迫现实形成批判性认识时，后一种情况是强加给领袖的。

Thus, due to certain historical conditions, the movement by the revolutionary leaders to the people is either horizontal—so that leaders and people form one body in contradiction to the oppressor—or it is triangular, with the revolutionary leaders occupying the vertex of the triangle in contradiction to the oppressors and to the oppressed as well. As we have seen, the latter situation is forced on the leaders when the people have not yet achieved a critical perception of oppressive reality.

然而，革命领导团体几乎从未意识到自己与人民形成矛盾。事实上，这种认识是痛苦的，而抵抗可能是一种防御机制。毕竟，通过支持被压迫者而崛起的领导人很难认识到自己与所支持的人存在矛盾。在分析革命领导人不由自主地成为人民矛盾（尽管不是对手）的某些行为形式时，认识到这种不情愿是很重要的。

Almost never, however, does a revolutionary leadership group per­ceive that it constitutes a contradiction to the people. Indeed, this perception is painful, and the resistance may serve as a defense mechanism. After all, it is not easy for leaders who have emerged through adherence to the oppressed to recognize themselves as be­ing in contradiction with those to whom they adhered. It is im­portant to recognize this reluctance when analyzing certain forms of behavior on the part of revolutionary leaders who involuntarily become a contradiction (although not antagonists) of the people.

为了进行革命，革命领袖无疑需要人民的支持。当领袖领导者与人民形成矛盾，他们寻求这种忠诚，却发现人民表现出一定的冷漠和不信任，他们常常认为这种反应表明人民本身存在缺陷。他们将人民意识的某个历史时刻解释为他们内在缺陷的证据。由于领导者需要人民的忠诚才能实现革命（但同时又不信任不信任的人民），他们倾向于使用统治精英压迫人民的相同程序。领导者合理化他们对人民的缺乏信心，说在掌权之前不可能与人民对话，从而选择了反对话的行动理论。从那时起——就像统治精英一样——他们试图征服人民：他们成为救世主；他们使用操纵并进行文化入侵。通过沿着这些道路前进，压迫的道路，他们将无法实现革命；或者如果他们这样做了，那将不是真正的革命。

In order to carry out the revolution, revolutionary leaders undoubtedly require the adherence of the people. When leaders who constitute a contradiction to the people seek this adherence, and find rather a certain aloofness and mistrust, they often regard this reaction as indicating an inherent defect on the part of the people. They interpret a certain historical moment of the people’s consciousness as evidence of their intrinsic deficiency. Since the leaders need the adherence of the people so that the revolution can be achieved (but at the same time mistrust the mistrustful people), they are tempted to utilize the same procedures used by the dominant elites to oppress. Rationalizing their lack of confidence in the people, the leaders say that it is impossible to dialogue with the people before taking power, thus opting for the antidialogical theory of action. Thenceforward—just like the dominant elites—they try to conquer the people: they become messianic; they use manipulation and carry out cultural invasion. By advancing along these paths, the paths of oppression, they will not achieve revolution; or if they do, it will not be authentic revolution.

革命领导的作用（在任何情况下，尤其是在所描述的情况下）是认真考虑，即使在他们行动时，人民也不信任他们的态度，并寻找与他们交流的真正途径，帮助人民帮助自己批判地认识压迫他们的现实。

The role of revolutionary leadership (under any circumstances, but especially so in those described) is to consider seriously, even as they act, the reasons for any attitude of mistrust on the part of the people, and to seek out true avenues of communion with them, ways of helping the people to help themselves critically perceive the reality which oppresses them.

被支配的意识是 双重的、模糊的、充满恐惧和不信任的。41格瓦拉在玻利维亚斗争的日记中多次提到农民参与的缺乏：

The dominated consciousness is dual, ambiguous, full of fear and mistrust.41 In his diary about the struggle in Bolivia, Guevara refers several times to the lack of peasant participation:

农民动员并不存在，除了有些让我们烦恼的通报任务。这些任务既不迅速，也不是很有效；它们可以被中和。……农民完全没有融入，尽管他们正在失去对我们的恐惧，我们正在成功赢得他们的钦佩。这是一项缓慢而耐心的任务。42

The peasant mobilization does not exist, except for informative duties which annoy us somewhat. They are neither very rapid nor very efficient; they can be neutralized. . . . Complete lack of incorporation of the peasants, although they are losing their fear of us and we are succeeding in winning their admiration. It is a slow and patient task.42

农民被统治的意识将压迫者内化，解释了他们的恐惧和无能。

The internalization of the oppressor by the dominated consciousness of the peasants explains their fear and their inefficiency.

被压迫者的行为和反应导致压迫者实施文化入侵，这应该促使革命者采取不同的行动理论。革命领袖与统治精英的区别不仅在于他们的目标，还在于他们的程序。如果他们以同样的方式行动，目标就变得相同。统治精英把人与世界的关系当作问题向人民提出，与革命领袖不这样做一样，都是自相矛盾的。

The behavior and reactions of the oppressed, which lead the oppressor to practice cultural invasion, should evoke from the revolutionary a different theory of action. What distinguishes ­revolutionary leaders from the dominant elite is not only their objectives, but their procedures. If they act in the same way, the objectives become identical. It is as self-contradictory for the dominant elites to pose human-world relations as problems to the people as it is for the revolutionary leaders not to do so.

现在让我们分析对话文化行动理论并尝试理解其组成要素。

Let us now analyze the theory of dialogical cultural action and attempt to apprehend its constituent elements.

合作

Cooperation

在反对话行动理论中，征服（作为其主要特征）涉及主体征服另一个人并将其转变为“物”。在对话行动理论中，主体齐聚一堂，合作改造世界。反对话的、支配性的我将被支配、被征服的你转变为单纯的它。43 然而 ，对话的我知道，正是你（“非我”）召唤了他或她自己的存在。他还知道，召唤他自己存在的你反过来又构成了一个我，而我的我中有你的你。因此，在这些关系的辩证法中，我和你变成两个你，而你又变成两个我。

In the theory of antidialogical action, conquest (as its primary characteristic) involves a Subject who conquers another person and transforms her or him into a “thing.” In the dialogical theory of action, Subjects meet in cooperation in order to transform the world. The antidialogical, dominating I transforms the dominated, conquered thou into a mere it. 43 The dialogical I, however, knows that it is precisely the thou (“not-I”) wh ich has called forth his or her own existence. He also knows that the thou which calls forth his own existence in turn constitutes an I which has in his I its thou. The I and the thou thus become, in the dialectic of these relationships, two thous which become two I’s.

对话式行动理论并不涉及通过征服进行统治的主体和被统治的对象。相反，存在着一些主体，他们聚集在一起命名世界，以改造世界。如果在某个历史时刻，被压迫者由于前面描述的原因无法履行其作为主体的使命，那么将他们所遭受的压迫本身视为一个问题（这总是涉及某种形式的行动）将有助于他们实现这一使命。

The dialogical theory of action does not involve a Subject, who dominates by virtue of conquest, and a dominated object. Instead, there are Subjects who meet to name the world in order to transform it. If at a certain historical moment the oppressed, for the reasons previously described, are unable to fulfill their vocation as Subjects, the posing of their very oppression as a problem (which always involves some form of action) will help them achieve this vocation.

以上所述并不意味着在对话任务中革命领导层没有任何作用。它仅仅意味着，尽管领导者发挥着重要、根本和不可或缺的作用，但他们并不拥有人民，也没有权利盲目地引导人民走向救赎。这样的救赎只是领导者送给人民的礼物——打破了他们之间的对话纽带，将人民从解放行动的共同发起者降格为解放行动的对象。

The above does not mean that in the dialogical task there is no role for revolutionary leadership. It means merely that the leaders—in spite of their important, fundamental, and indispensable role—do not own the people and have no right to steer the people blindly towards their salvation. Such a salvation would be a mere gift from the leaders to the people—a breaking of the dialogical bond between them, and a reducing of the people from co-authors of liberating ­action into the objects of this action.

合作是对话行动的一个特征，它只发生在主体之间（然而主体可能具有不同层次的功能，因而也具有不同的责任），只有通过沟通才能实现。对话作为必不可少的沟通，是任何合作的基础。在对话行动理论中，没有为革命事业征服人民的地方，只有获得他们的支持的地方。对话不强加、不操纵、不驯服、不“口号化”。但这并不意味着对话行动理论毫无意义；也不意味着对话人对自己想要什么或自己所致力于的目标没有清晰的认识。

Cooperation, as a characteristic of dialogical action—which occurs only among Subjects (who may, however, have diverse levels of functions and thus of responsibility)—can only be achieved through communication. Dialogue, as essential communication, must ­underlie any cooperation. In the theory of dialogical action, there is no place for conquering the people on behalf of the revolutionary cause, but only for gaining their adherence. Dialogue does not impose, does not manipulate, does not domesticate, does not “sloganize.” This does not mean, however, that the theory of dialogical action leads nowhere; nor does it mean that the dialogical human does not have a clear idea of what she wants, or of the objectives to which she is committed.

革命领袖对被压迫者的承诺同时也是对自由的承诺。而正是因为这种承诺，领袖们不能试图征服被压迫者，而必须实现对解放的坚持。被征服的坚持不是坚持；它是被征服者对征服者的“坚持”，征服者规定了前者的选择。真正的坚持是选择的自由巧合；它不能脱离人们之间的交流而发生，而要以现实为媒介。

The commitment of the revolutionary leaders to the oppressed is at the same time a commitment to freedom. And because of that commitment, the leaders cannot attempt to conquer the oppressed, but must achieve their adherence to liberation. Conquered adherence is not adherence; it is “adhesion” of the vanquished to the ­conqueror, who prescribes the options open to the former. Authentic adherence is the free coincidence of choices; it cannot occur apart from communication among people, mediated by reality.

因此，合作使对话主体将注意力集中在调解他们并作为问题对他们提出挑战的现实上。对话主体对这一挑战的回应是对现实采取行动以改变现实。让我再次强调，将现实作为问题并不意味着口号：它意味着对有问题的现实进行批判性分析。

Thus cooperation leads dialogical Subjects to focus their ­attention on the reality which mediates them and which—posed as a ­problem—challenges them. The response to that challenge is the action of ­dialogical Subjects upon reality in order to transform it. Let me re­emphasize that posing reality as a problem does not mean sloganiz­ing: it means critical analysis of a problematic reality.

与主流精英的神话化做法相反，对话理论要求揭示世界。然而，没有人可以为他人揭示世界。虽然一个主体可以代表他人发起揭示，但其他人也必须成为这一行为的主体。人民的坚持是通过在真实的实践中揭示世界和他们自己而实现的。

As opposed to the mythicizing practices of the dominant elites, dialogical theory requires that the world be unveiled. No one can, however, unveil the world for another. Although one Subject may ­initiate the unveiling on behalf of others, the others must also become Subjects of this act. The adherence of the people is made ­possible by this unveiling of the world and of themselves, in authentic praxis.

这种坚持与人民开始对自己和革命领袖的信任相一致，因为前者感受到了后者的奉献精神和真诚。人民对领袖的信任反映了领袖对人民的信心。

This adherence coincides with the trust the people begin to place in themselves and in the revolutionary leaders, as the former perceive the dedication and authenticity of the latter. The trust of the people in the leaders reflects the confidence of the leaders in the people.

然而，这种信心不应是幼稚的。领导者必须相信人民的潜力，不能将人民仅仅视为自己行动的对象；他们必须相信人民有能力参与追求解放。但他们必须始终不信任被压迫人民的模棱两可性，不信任“藏身”在被压迫人民身上的压迫者。因此，当格瓦拉劝告革命者始终保持不信任时，44 他并没有忽视对话行动理论的基本条件。他只是一个现实主义者。

This confidence should not, however, be naïve. The leaders must believe in the potentialities of the people, whom they cannot treat as mere objects of their own action; they must believe that the ­people are capable of participating in the pursuit of liberation. But they must always mistrust the ambiguity of oppressed people, mistrust the oppressor “housed” in the latter. Accordingly, when Guev­ara exhorts the revolutionary to be always mistrustful,44 he is not disregarding the fundamental condition of the theory of dialogical action. He is merely being a realist.

虽然信任是对话的基础，但它并不是对话的先验条件；它源自人们作为共同主体谴责世界的相遇，这是世界变革的一部分。但只要被压迫者“内部”的压迫者比他们自己更强大，他们对自由的自然恐惧就可能导致他们反而谴责革命领袖！领导者不能轻信，但必须警惕这些可能性。格瓦拉的插曲证实了这些风险：不仅是逃兵，甚至是背叛事业。在这份文件中，有时，虽然承认有必要惩罚逃兵以维护除了团体的凝聚力和纪律之外，格瓦拉还承认了导致叛逃的某些因素。其中之一，或许也是最重要的一个，就是叛逃者的模糊性。

Although trust is basic to dialogue, it is not an a priori condition of the latter; it results from the encounter in which persons are co-Subjects in denouncing the world, as part of the world’s transformation. But as long as the oppressor “within” the oppressed is stronger than they themselves are, their natural fear of freedom may lead them to denounce the revolutionary leaders instead! The leaders cannot be credulous, but must be alert for these possibilities. Guev­ara’s Episodes confirms these risks: not only desertions, but even betrayal of the cause. At times in this document, while ­recognizing the necessity of punishing the deserter in order to preserve the ­cohesion and discipline of the group, Guevara also recognizes certain factors which explain the desertion. One of them, perhaps the most important, is the deserter’s ambiguity.

格瓦拉文件的另一部分提到他（不仅作为一名游击队员，而且还作为一名医生）在马埃斯特腊山脉的一个农民社区的存在，并且与我们关于合作的讨论有关，这部分内容相当引人注目：

Another portion of Guevara’s document, which refers to his presence (not only as a guerrilla but as a medical doctor) in a peasant community in the Sierra Maestra and relates to our discussion of cooperation, is quite striking:

通过每天与这些人接触，了解他们的问题，我们坚信，我们人民的生活需要彻底改变。土地改革的想法变得非常清晰。与人民的交流不再只是一种理论，而是我们自身不可分割的一部分。

As a result of daily contact with these people and their problems we became firmly convinced of the need for a complete change in the life of our people. The idea of an agrarian reform became crystal-clear. Communion with the people ceased to be a mere theory, to become an integral part of ourselves.

游击队和农民开始融合成一个坚实的群体。没有人能确切地说出在这个漫长的过程中，这些想法何时变成了现实，我们成为了农民的一部分。就我而言，与塞拉山区的病人的接触使一个自发的、有点抒情的决定变成了一种更平静的力量，一种完全不同的价值。那些贫穷、受苦、忠诚的塞拉山区居民甚至无法想象他们为我们的革命意识形态的形成做出了多大的贡献 。45

Guerrillas and peasants began to merge into a solid mass. No one can say exactly when, in this long process, the ideas became reality and we became a part of the peasantry. As far as I am ­concerned, the contact with my patients in the Sierra turned a spontaneous and somewhat lyrical decision into a more serene force, one of an entirely different value. Those poor, suffering, loyal ­inhabitants of the Sierra cannot even imagine what a great contribution they made to the forging of our revolutionary ide-ology. 45

请注意，格瓦拉强调，与人民的交流对于将“自发的、有点抒情的决定转变为一种更平静的力量，一种完全不同的价值”具有决定性作用。因此，正是在与农民的对话中，格瓦拉的革命实践才得以确定。格瓦拉也许出于谦逊，没有说的是，正是他自己的谦逊和爱的能力使他与人民的交流成为可能。这种无可争辩的对话交流变成了合作。请注意，格瓦拉（他没有在寻找冒险的沮丧青年时期与菲德尔和他的同志们一起攀登马埃斯特拉山脉）承认，他的“与人民的交流不再是一种理论，而是成为[他自己]不可分割的一部分”。他强调，从从那一刻起，农民就成了他的游击队“革命思想​​”的“锻造者”。

Note Guevara’s emphasis that communion with the people was decisive for the transformation of a “spontaneous and somewhat lyri­cal decision into a more serene force, one of an entirely ­different value.” It was, then, in dialogue with the peasants that Guevaras ­revolutionary praxis became definitive. What Guevara did not say, perhaps due to humility, is that it was his own humility and ­capacity to love that made possible his communion with the people. And this indisputably dialogical communion became cooperation. Note that Guevara (who did not climb the Sierra Maestra with Fidel and his comrades as a frustrated youth in search of adventure) recognizes that his “communion with the people ceased to be a mere theory, to become an integral part of [himself].” He stresses how from the moment of that communion the peasants became “forgers” of his guerrillas’ “revolutionary ideology.”

甚至连格瓦拉以几乎福音派的语言讲述他和他的同志们的经历、描述他与“贫穷、忠诚”农民的接触的独特风格，都揭示了这位杰出人物深厚的爱与沟通能力。由此，他热情地见证了另一位充满爱心的人：卡米洛·托雷斯，“游击队牧师”。

Even Guevara’s unmistakable style of narrating his and his comrades’ experiences, of describing his contacts with the “poor, loyal” peasants in almost evangelical language, reveals this remarkable man’s deep capacity for love and communication. Thence emerges the force of his ardent testimony to the work of another loving man: Camilo Torres, “the guerrilla priest.”

如果没有促成真正合作的共融，古巴人民就只是马埃斯特腊山脉人民革命活动的对象，作为对象，他们的忠诚是不可能的。最多可能存在“忠诚”，但那是统治的组成部分，而不是革命的组成部分。

Without the communion which engenders true cooperation, the Cuban people would have been mere objects of the revolutionary activity of the men of the Sierra Maestra, and as objects, their adherence would have been impossible. At the most, there might have been “adhesion,” but that is a component of domination, not revo­lution.

对话理论认为，革命行动在任何阶段都不能放弃与人民的交流。交流反过来又引发合作，使领导人和人民实现格瓦拉所描述的融合。只有当革命行动真正具有人性、富有同情心、充满爱心、善于沟通和谦逊时，这种融合才能实现，才能实现解放。

In dialogical theory, at no stage can revolutionary action forgo communion with the people. Communion in turn elicits cooperation, which brings leaders and people to the fusion described by Guevara. This fusion can exist only if revolutionary action is really human, empathetic, loving, communicative, and humble, in order to be liberating.

革命热爱并创造生命；为了创造生命，革命可能不得不阻止某些人限制生命。除了自然界基本的生死循环之外，还有一种几乎非自然的活生生的死亡：生命被剥夺了其完整性。46

The revolution loves and creates life; and in order to create life it may be obliged to prevent some men from circumscribing life. In addition to the life-death cycle basic to nature, there is almost an unnatural living death: life which is denied its fullness.46

这里没有必要引用统计数据来表明有多少巴西人（以及拉丁美洲人）是“活尸体”，是人类的“影子”，是绝望的男人、女人和孩子，他们是无休止的“隐形战争” 47 的受害者，其中他们的残余的生命被肺结核、血吸虫病、婴儿腹泻……以及各种贫困疾病所吞噬（其中大多数，用压迫者的术语来说，被称为“热带疾病”）。

It should not be necessary here to cite statistics to show how many Brazilians (and Latin Americans in general) are “living corpses,” “shadows” of human beings, hopeless men, women, and children victimized by an endless “invisible war”47 in which their remnants of life are devoured by tuberculosis, schistosomiasis, infant diarrhea . . . by the myriad diseases of poverty (most of which, in the terminology of the oppressors, are called “tropical diseases”).

Chenu 神父针对上述极端情况可能产生的反应发表了以下评论：

Father Chenu makes the following comments regarding possible reactions to situations as extreme as the above:

参加会议的牧师和知情的平信徒中，许多人都担心，面对世界的需要和苦难，我们可能只是采取一种情绪化的抗议，以减轻贫困和不公正的表现和症状，而不去分析后者的原因，谴责一个包含这种不公正并造成“贫困”的政权。48

Many, both among the priests attending the Council and the informed laymen, fear that in facing the needs and suffering of the world we may simply adopt an emotional protest in favor of palliating the manifestations and symptoms of poverty and injustice without going on to analyze the causes of the latter, to denounce a regime which encompasses this injustice and engenders ‘his poverty.48

团结解放

Unity for Liberation

在反对话的行动理论中，统治者被迫分裂被压迫者，以便更容易地维护压迫状态；而在对话理论中，领导者必须不懈地努力团结被压迫者——以及领导者与被压迫者的团结——以实现解放。

Whereas in the antidialogical theory of action the dominators are compelled by necessity to divide the oppressed, the more easily to preserve the state of oppression, in the dialogical theory the leaders must dedicate themselves to an untiring effort for unity among the oppressed—and unity of the leaders with the oppressed—in order to achieve liberation.

困难在于，这种对话行动（和其他行动一样）不能脱离实践而发生。压迫实践对于统治精英来说很容易（或至少不难）；但对于革命领袖来说，实施解放实践并不容易。前者可以依靠使用权力工具；后者则有这种权力来对抗它。前者可以自由地组织起来，尽管它可能经历偶然和短暂的分裂，但面对对其根本利益的任何威胁，它会迅速团结起来。后者如果没有统治精英，就不可能存在。人，而这种情况正是其组织努力的第一个障碍。

The difficulty is that this category of dialogical action (like the ­others) cannot occur apart from the praxis. The praxis of oppression is easy (or at least not difficult) for the dominant elite; but it is not easy for the revolutionary leaders to carry out a liberating praxis. The former group can rely on using the instruments of power; the latter group has this power directed against it. The former group can organize itself freely, and though it may undergo fortuitous and momentary divisions, it unites rapidly in the face of any threat to its fundamental interests. The latter group cannot exist without the people, and this very condition constitutes the first obstacle to its efforts at organization.

统治精英允许革命领袖组织起来确实自相矛盾。统治精英的内部团结加强并组织了其权力，这需要人民分裂；革命领袖的团结只存在于人民之间的团结中，而人民又与革命领袖团结一致。精英的团结源于其与人民的对立；革命领导集团的团结源于与（团结的）人民的交流。压迫的具体情况——使被压迫者的自我二元化，从而使被压迫者变得模棱两可、情绪不稳定、害怕自由——通过阻碍解放所必需的统一行动，促进了统治者的分裂行动。

It would indeed be inconsistent of the dominant elite to allow the revolutionary leaders to organize. The internal unity of the ­dominant elite, which reinforces and organizes its power, requires that the people be divided; the unity of the revolutionary leaders only exists in the unity of the people among themselves and in turn with them. The unity of the elite derives from its antagonism with the people; the unity of the revolutionary leadership group grows out of communion with the (united) people. The concrete situation of oppression—which dualizes the I of the oppressed, thereby making the oppressed person ambiguous, emotionally unstable, and fearful of freedom—facilitates the divisive action of the dominator by hindering the unifying action indispensable to liberation.

此外，统治本身在客观上就是分裂性的。它使被压迫的自我处于“依附”于似乎无所不能、势不可挡的现实的地位，然后通过呈现神秘的力量来解释这种力量，从而疏远自我。被压迫的自我的一部分位于它“依附”的现实中；另一部分位于自我之外，位于被认为对无能为力的现实负责的神秘力量中。个人被分裂为相同的过去和现在，以及没有希望的未来。他或她是一个不认为自己正在成长的人；因此无法与他人团结一致地建立未来。但是，当他或她打破这种“依附”并客观化他或她开始出现的现实时，这个人开始作为一个主体（一个自我）与客体（现实）对抗。此时，打破分裂自我的虚假统一，一个人成为一个真正的个体。

Further, domination is itself objectively divisive. It maintains the oppressed I in a position of “adhesion” to a reality which seems all-powerful and overwhelming, and then alienates by presenting myste­rious forces to explain this power. Part of the oppressed I is located in the reality to which it “adheres”; part is located outside the self, in the mysterious forces which are regarded as responsible for a reality about which nothing can be done. The individual is divided between an identical past and present, and a future without hope. He or she is a person who does not perceive himself or herself as becoming; hence cannot have a future to be built in unity with others. But as he or she breaks this “adhesion” and objectifies the reality from which he or she starts to emerge, the person begins to integrate as a Subject (an I) confronting an object (reality). At this moment, sundering the false unity of the divided self, one becomes a true individual.

要分裂被压迫者，压迫的意识形态是必不可少的。相反，要实现他们的团结，就需要一种文化行动，通过这种行动，他们才能了解自己为何以及如何坚持现实——这需要去意识形态化。因此，团结被压迫者的努力并不需要单纯的意识形态“口号”。后者通过扭曲主体与客观现实之间的真实关系，也分离了整体、不可分割的人格的认知、情感和主动方面。

To divide the oppressed, an ideology of oppression is indispensa­ble. In contrast, achieving their unity requires a form of cultural action through which they come to know the why and how of their adhesion to reality—it requires de-ideologizing. Hence, the effort to unify the oppressed does not call for mere ideological “sloganizing.” The latter, by distorting the authentic relation between the ­Subject and objective reality, also separates the cognitive, the af­fective, and the active aspects of the total, indivisible personality.

对话自由主义行动的目的并非将被压迫者从神话现实中“驱逐”，以便将他们“束缚”到另一个现实。相反，对话行动的目的是让被压迫者通过感知他们的依附，选择改变不公正的现实。

The object of dialogical-libertarian action is not to “dislodge” the oppressed from a mythological reality in order to “bind” them to another reality. On the contrary, the object of dialogical action is to make it possible for the oppressed, by perceiving their adhe­sion, to opt to transform an unjust reality.

由于被压迫者的团结涉及他们之间的团结，无论他们的具体地位如何，这种团结无疑需要阶级意识。然而，拉丁美洲农民的特点是沉浸在现实中，这意味着在意识到自己是一个被压迫的阶级之前（或至少伴随着意识到自己是被压迫的个体）。49

Since the unity of the oppressed involves solidarity among them, regardless of their exact status, the unity unquestionably requires class consciousness. However, the submersion in reality which characterizes the peasants of Latin America means that consciousness of being an oppressed class must be preceded (or at least accompanied) by achieving consciousness of being oppressed individuals.49

对于欧洲农民来说，提出自己是人这一事实可能会让他们感到奇怪。但对于拉丁美洲农民来说情况并非如此，他们的世界通常止于大庄园的边界，他们的举止在某种程度上模仿动物和树木，他们常常认为自己与后者平等。

Proposing as a problem, to a European peasant, the fact that he or she is a person might strike them as strange. This is not true of Latin-American peasants, whose world usually ends at the boundaries of the latifundium, whose gestures to some extent simulate those of the animals and the trees, and who often consider themselves equal to the latter.

受自然和压迫者束缚的人必须认识到，他们自己是无法存在的人。而发现自我首先意味着发现他们是佩德罗、安东尼奥或约瑟法。这一发现意味着对名称含义的不同理解：“世界”、“人”、“文化”、“树木”、“工作”、“动物”等词语重新获得了它们的真实意义。农民现在通过他们的创造性劳动将自己视为现实（以前是一个神秘的实体）的改造者。他们发现，作为人，他们不再是被他人占有的“东西”；他们可以从被压迫个体的意识转变为被压迫阶级的意识。

Men who are bound to nature and to the oppressor in this way must come to discern themselves as persons prevented from being. And discovering themselves means in the first instance discovering themselves as Pedro, as Antonio, or as Josefa. This discovery implies a different perception of the meaning of designations: the words “world,” “men,” “culture,” “tree,” “work,” “animal,” reassume their true significance. The peasants now see themselves as transformers of reality (previously a mysterious entity) through their creative labor. They discover that—as people—they can no longer continue to be “things” possessed by others; and they can move from consciousness of themselves as oppressed individuals to the consciousness of an oppressed class.

任何以激进方式团结农民的尝试依赖“口号”而不处理这些基本方面的做法只会产生个人的简单并置，使他们的行动具有纯粹机械的特征。被压迫者的团结发生在人的层面，而不是事物的层面。它发生在现实中，而现实只有在下层建筑和上层建筑的辩证法中才能真正理解。

Any attempt to unify the peasants based on activist methods which rely on “slogans” and do not deal with these fundamental aspects produces a mere juxtaposition of individuals, giving a purely mechanistic character to their action. The unity of the oppressed occurs at the human level, not at the level of things. It occurs in a reality which is only authentically comprehended in the dialectic between the sub- and superstructure.

被压迫者要想团结起来，首先必须斩断将他们与压迫世界联系在一起的魔法和神话的脐带；将他们联系在一起的团结必须是另一种性质的。要实现这种不可或缺的团结，革命进程从一开始就必须是文化行动。实现被压迫者团结的方法将取决于后者在社会结构中的历史和生存经验。

In order for the oppressed to unite, they must first cut the umbilical cord of magic and myth which binds them to the world of oppression; the unity which links them to each other must be of a different nature. To achieve this indispensable unity the revolutionary process must be, from the beginning, cultural action. The methods used to achieve the unity of the oppressed will depend on the latter’s historical and existential experience within the social structure.

农民生活在一个“封闭”的现实中，压迫决策中心只有一个，紧凑；城市被压迫者生活在一个不断扩大的环境中，压迫指挥中心是多元而复杂的。农民处于一个体现压迫体系的统治人物的控制之下；在城市地区，被压迫者受到“压迫的非人性化”。在这两种情况下，压迫力量在一定程度上都是“看不见的”：在农村地区，因为它离被压迫者很近；在城市，因为它分散。

Peasants live in a “closed” reality with a single, compact center of oppressive decision; the urban oppressed live in an expanding context in which the oppressive command center is plural and complex. Peasants are under the control of a dominant figure who incarnates the oppressive system; in urban areas, the oppressed are subjected to an “oppressive impersonality.” In both cases the oppressive power is to a certain extent “invisible”: in the rural zone, because of its proximity to the oppressed; in the cities, because of its dispersion.

在这些不同情况下，文化行动的形式都具有相同的目标：向被压迫者阐明将他们与压迫者联系在一起的客观情况，无论这种联系是可见的还是不可见的。只有一方面避免单纯的演说和无效的“废话”，另一方面避免机械的行动主义的行动形式，才能反对统治精英的分裂行动，走向被压迫者的团结。

Forms of cultural action in such different situations as these have nonetheless the same objective: to clarify to the oppressed the ob­jective situation which binds them to the oppressors, visible or not. Only forms of action which avoid mere speech-making and ineffective “blah” on the one hand, and mechanistic activism on the other, can also oppose the divisive action of the dominant elites and move towards the unity of the oppressed.

组织

Organization

在反对话行动理论中，操纵对于征服和统治是必不可少的；在对话行动理论中，人民的组织代表了这种操纵的对立面。操纵。组织不仅与团结直接相关，而且是团结的自然发展。因此，领导人追求团结也必然是组织人民的一种尝试，需要见证解放斗争是一项共同的任务。这种持续、谦逊和勇敢的见证源于共同努力——解放妇女和男子——的合作，避免了反对话控制的危险。见证的形式可能有所不同，这取决于任何社会的历史条件；然而，见证本身是革命行动不可或缺的要素。

In the theory of antidialogical action, manipulation is indispensable to conquest and domination; in the dialogical theory of action the organization of the people presents the antagonistic opposite of this manipulation. Organization is not only directly linked to unity, but is a natural development of that unity. Accordingly, the leaders’ pursuit of unity is necessarily also an attempt to organize the ­people, requiring witness to the fact that the struggle for liberation is a common task. This constant, humble, and courageous witness emerging from cooperation in a shared effort—the liberation of women and men—avoids the danger of antidialogical control. The form of witness may vary, depending on the historical conditions of any society; witness itself, however, is an indispensable element of revolutionary action.

因此，为了确定见证的内容和方式，必须对当前的历史背景、人民的世界观、社会的主要矛盾以及矛盾的主要方面有越来越批判性的了解。由于见证的这些维度是历史的、对话的，因此也是辩证的，见证不能简单地从其他背景中引入它们，而不先分析自己的背景。否则就是将相对绝对化和神话化；异化将不可避免。在对话行动理论中，见证是革命的文化和教育特征的主要表现之一。

In order to determine the what and how of that witness, it is ­therefore essential to have an increasingly critical knowledge of the c urrent historical context, the view of the world held by the people,the principal contradiction of society, and the principal aspect of that contradiction. Since these dimensions of witness are historical, dialogical, and therefore dialectical, witness cannot simply import them from other contexts without previously analyzing its own. To do otherwise is to absolutize and mythologize the relative; ­alienation then becomes unavoidable. Witness, in the dialogical theory of action, is one of the principal expressions of the cultural and educational character of the revolution.

见证的基本要素在历史上不会发生变化，包括：言行一致；勇气，促使见证者直面作为永久风险的生存；激进化（而非宗派主义），引导见证者和接受见证的人不断采取行动；勇于去爱（这远非对不公正世界的适应，而是为人类日益解放而对世界进行的改造）；对人民的信任，因为见证是向人民进行的——尽管由于人民与统治精英的辩证关系，对人民的见证也会影响后者（他们以习惯的方式回应见证）。

The essential elements of witness which do not vary historically include: consistency between words and actions; boldness which urges the witnesses to confront existence as a permanent risk; radicalization (not sectarianism) leading both the witnesses and the ones receiving that witness to increasing action; courage to love (which, far from being accommodation to an unjust world, is rather the transformation of that world in behalf of the increasing liberation of humankind); and faith in the people, since it is to them that ­witness is made—although witness to the people, because of their ­dialectical relations with the dominant elites, also affects the latter (who respond to that witness in their customary way).

所有真实的（即批判性的）见证都涉及敢于冒险，包括领导者并不总是能赢得人民的立即拥护的可能性。没有在某一时刻和某些条件下结出的果实并不因此就无法在明天结出果实。由于见证不是一种抽象的姿态，而是一种行动——与世界和人的对抗——它不是静态的。它是一个动态元素，成为它发生的社会背景的一部分；从那一刻起，它就不会停止影响那个环境。50

All authentic (that is, critical) witness involves the daring to run risks, including the possibility that the leaders will not always win the immediate adherence of the people. Witness which has not borne fruit at a certain moment and under certain conditions is not thereby rendered incapable of bearing fruit tomorrow. Since witness is not an abstract gesture, but an action—a confrontation with the world and with people—it is not static. It is a dynamic element which becomes part of the societal context in which it occurred; from that moment, it does not cease to affect that context.50

在反对话行动中，操纵使人民麻木，便于他们进行统治；在对话行动中，操纵被真实的组织所取代。在反对话行动中，操纵服务于征服的目的；在对话行动中，勇敢而充满爱意的见证服务于组织的目的。

In antidialogical action, manipulation anesthetizes the people and facilitates their domination; in dialogical action manipulation is su­perseded by authentic organization. In antidialogical action, ma­nipulation serves the ends of conquest; in dialogical action, daring and loving witness serve the ends of organization.

对于统治精英来说，组织意味着组织他们自己。对于革命领袖来说，组织意味着与人民一起组织他们自己。在第一种情况下，统治精英越来越多地构建其权力，以便更有效地统治和去人性化；在第二种情况下，组织只有在其本身构成自由实践的情况下才符合其性质和目标。因此，任何组织所必需的纪律都不能与管制相混淆。确实，没有领导、纪律、决心和目标——没有要完成的任务和要交代的账目——一个组织就无法生存，革命行动因此被削弱。然而，这一事实永远不能成为将人民视为可以利用的东西的理由。人民已经被压迫非人性化——如果革命领袖操纵他们，而不是努力使他们觉醒，那么组织的目标（即解放）就会被否定。

For the dominant elites, organization means organizing themselves. For the revolutionary leaders, organization means ­organizing themselves with the people. In the first event, the dominant elite increasingly structures its power so that it can more efficiently domi­nate and depersonalize; in the second, organization only corre­sponds to its nature and objective if in itself it constitutes the practice of freedom. Accordingly, the discipline necessary to any organization must not be confused with regimentation. It is quite true that without leadership, discipline, determination, and objectives—without tasks to fulfill and accounts to be rendered—an ­organization cannot survive, and revolutionary action is thereby di­luted. This fact, however, can never justify treating the people as things to be used. The people are already depersonalized by oppression—if the revolutionary leaders manipulate them, instead of working towards their conscientização, the very objective of organization (that is, liberation) is thereby negated.

组织人民是革命领袖（他们同样被禁止发表自己的言论）发起 的学会如何命名世界。这是真正的学习经历，因此是对话式的。因此，领导者不能独自说话；他们必须与人民一起说。不对话式行事，而是坚持强加决定的领导者，不会组织人民——他们会操纵人民。他们不解放人民，也没有被解放：他们压迫人民。

Organizing the people is the process in which the revolutionary leaders, who are also prevented from saying their own word,51 initiate the experience of learning how to name the world. This is true learning experience, and therefore dialogical. So it is that the leaders cannot say their word alone; they must say it with the people. Leaders who do not act dialogically, but insist on imposing their decisions, do not organize the people—they manipulate them. They do not liberate, nor are they liberated: they oppress.

组织人民的领导人没有权利任意强加自己的言论，但这并不意味着他们必须采取自由主义立场，鼓励习惯于压迫的人民放纵自己。行动对话理论既反对威权主义，也反对放纵自己，从而肯定权威和自由。没有权威就没有自由，没有自由也没有权威。所有自由都包含着在特殊情况下（以及在不同的生存层面）成为权威的可能性。自由和权威不能孤立存在，而必须相互联系。52

The fact that the leaders who organize the people do not have the right to arbitrarily impose their word does not mean that they must therefore take a liberalist position which would encourage license among the people, who are accustomed to oppression. The dialogical theory of action opposes both authoritarianism and license, and thereby affirms authority and freedom. There is no freedom without authority, but there is also no authority without freedom. All freedom contains the possibility that under special circumstances (and at different existential levels) it may become authority. Freedom and authority cannot be isolated, but must be considered in relationship to each other.52

真正的权威不是通过权力的单纯转移而确立的，而是通过授权或同情性遵守而确立的。如果权威只是从一个群体转移到另一个群体，或强加给大多数人，就会堕落为独裁主义。只有当权威是“自由成为权威”时，它才能避免与自由发生冲突。一方的过度膨胀会导致另一方的萎缩。正如权威不能没有自由而存在，反之亦然，如果不否定自由，独裁主义就不可能存在，如果不否定权威，放纵就不可能存在。

Authentic authority is not affirmed as such by a mere ­transfer of power, but through delegation or in sympathetic adherence. If authority is merely transferred from one group to another, or is imposed upon the majority, it degenerates into authoritarianism. Authority can avoid conflict with freedom only if it is “freedom-become-authority.” Hypertrophy of the one provokes atrophy of the other. Just as authority cannot exist without freedom, and vice versa, authoritarianism cannot exist without denying freedom, nor license without denying authority.

在对话行动理论中，组织需要权威，所以不能专制；组织需要自由，所以不能放纵。组织是一个高度教育的过程，领导者和人民共同体验真正的权威和自由，然后他们寻求通过改变中介现实来在社会中建立自由。

In the theory of dialogical action, organization requires ­authority, so it cannot be authoritarian; it requires freedom, so it cannot be licentious. Organization is, rather, a highly educational process in which leaders and people together experience true authority and freedom, which they then seek to establish in society by trans­-forming the reality which mediates them.

文化综合

Cultural Synthesis

文化行动始终是一种系统而深思熟虑的行动形式，它作用于社会结构，其目的要么是维护该结构，要么是改变该结构。作为一种深思熟虑的系统行动形式，所有文化行动都有其理论，该理论决定了其目的并从而确定了其方法。文化行动要么服务于统治（有意识或无意识），要么服务于男性和女性的解放。由于这些辩证对立的文化行动类型在社会结构中发挥作用，它们创造了永恒与变化的辩证关系。

Cultural action is always a systematic and deliberate form of action which operates upon the social structure, either with the objective of preserving that structure or of transforming it. As a form of deliberate and systematic action, all cultural action has its theory which determines its ends and thereby defines its methods. Cultural action either serves domination (consciously or unconsciously) or it serves the liberation of men and women. As these dialectically opposed types of cultural action operate in and upon the social structure, they create dialectical relations of permanence and change.

社会结构为了存在，必须成为；换言之，成为是社会结构表达“持续时间”的方式，按照柏格森的理解。53

The social structure, in order to be, must become; in other words, becoming is the way the social structure expresses “duration,” in the Bergsonian sense of the term.53

对话式的文化行动的目的并不是使永恒—变化的辩证法消失（这是一个不可能实现的目标，因为辩证法的消失就意味着社会结构本身的消失，从而也意味着人的消失）；相反，它的目的是克服社会结构的对抗矛盾，从而实现人的解放。

Dialogical cultural action does not have as its aim the disappearance of the permanence-change dialectic (an impossible aim, since disappearance of the dialectic would require the disappearance of the social structure itself and thus of men); it aims, rather, at surmounting the antagonistic contradictions of the social structure, thereby achieving the liberation of human beings.

另一方面，反对话的文化行动旨在将这种矛盾神话化，从而希望避免（或尽可能阻碍）现实的彻底转变。反对话行动明确或隐含地旨在在社会结构中保留有利于其自身主体的局面。虽然后者永远不会接受足够彻底的结构转变以克服其对抗性矛盾，但他们可能会接受改革，并不影响他们对被压迫者的决定权。因此，这种行动方式涉及对人民的征服、分裂、操纵和文化入侵。它必然是一种诱导行为，从根本上说也是一种诱导行为。然而，对话行动的特点是超越任何诱导方面。反对话文化行动无法超越其诱导性，这是由于它的目标是统治；对话文化行动能够做到这一点，则在于它的目标是解放。

Antidialogical cultural action, on the other hand, aims at mythicizing such contradictions, thereby hoping to avoid (or hinder insofar as possible) the radical transformation of reality. Antidialogical action explicitly or implicitly aims to preserve, within the social structure, situations which favor its own agents. While the latter would never accept a transformation of the structure sufficiently radical to overcome its antagonistic contradictions, they may accept reforms which do not affect their power of decision over the oppressed. Hence, this modality of action involves the conquest of the people, their division, their manipulation, and cultural invasion. It is necessarily and fundamentally an induced action. Dialogical action, however, is characterized by the supersedence of any induced aspect. The incapacity of antidialogical cultural action to supersede its induced character results from its objective: domination; the capacity of dialogical cultural action to do this lies in its objective: liberation.

在文化入侵中，行为者从自己的价值观和意识形态中汲取行动的主题内容；他们的出发点是自己的世界，从那里进入被入侵者的世界。在文化综合中，从“另一个世界”来到人民世界的行为者并非以入侵者的身份来到这里。他们来这里不是为了教导、传播或给予任何东西，而是与人民一起学习人民的世界。

In cultural invasion, the actors draw the thematic content of their action from their own values and ideology; their starting point is their own world, from which they enter the world of those they invade. In cultural synthesis, the actors who come from “another world” to the world of the people do so not as invaders. They do not come to teach or to transmit or to give anything, but rather to learn, with the people, about the people’s world.

在文化入侵中，行为者（他们甚至不需要亲自到被入侵的文化中去；他们的行动越来越多地通过技术手段进行）将自己置于人民之上，人民则被赋予了观众和客体的角色。在文化综合中，行为者与人民融为一体，人民是共同作用于世界的行动的共同作者。

In cultural invasion the actors (who need not even go personally to the invaded culture; increasingly, their action is carried out by technological instruments) superimpose themselves on the people, who are assigned the role of spectators, of objects. In cultural syn­thesis, the actors become integrated with the people, who are co­authors of the action that both perform upon the world.

在文化入侵中，观众和所要保留的现实都是行动者行动的对象；在文化综合中，不存在观众，行动者行动的对象是为人的解放而需要改造的现实。

In cultural invasion, both the spectators and the reality to be ­preserved are objects of the actors’ action. In cultural synthesis, there are no spectators; the object of the actors’ action is the reality to be transformed for the liberation of men.

因此，文化综合是一种对抗文化本身的行动模式，文化本身是形成文化的结构的保护者。文化行动作为历史行动，是取代占主导地位的异化和异化文化的工具。从这个意义上讲，每一次真正的革命都是一场文化革命。

Cultural synthesis is thus a mode of action for confronting culture itself, as the preserver of the very structures by which it was formed. Cultural action, as historical action, is an instrument for superseding the dominant alienated and alienating culture. In this sense, every authentic revolution is a cultural revolution.

第三章中对人们的生成主题或有意义的主题的调查构成了文化综合行动过程的起点。事实上，不可能真正将这一过程分为两个独立的步骤：首先是主题调查，然后是文化综合行动。这样的二分法omy 意味着在初始阶段，人们作为被动对象，将被调查者研究、分析和调查——这一过程与反对话行动相一致。这种划分会导致一个天真的结论：作为综合的行动源于作为入侵的行动。

The investigation of the people’s generative themes or ­meaningful thematics described in chapter 3 constitutes the starting point for the process of action as cultural synthesis. Indeed, it is not really possible to divide this process into two separate steps; first, thematic investigation, and then action as cultural synthesis. Such a dichot­omy would imply an initial phase in which the people, as passive objects, would be studied, analyzed, and investigated by the investigators—a procedure congruent with antidialogical action. Such divi­sion would lead to the naïve conclusion that action as synthesis follows from action as invasion.

在对话理论中，这种划分是不可能发生的。主题调查的主体不仅是专业调查人员，而且是被调查主题世界的人们。调查——作为文化综合的行动的第一阶段——建立了一种创造性的氛围，这种氛围将在行动的后续阶段中发展。文化入侵中不存在这样的氛围，文化入侵通过异化扼杀了被入侵者的创造热情，使他们绝望并害怕冒险进行实验，而没有实验就没有真正的创造力。

In dialogical theory, this division cannot occur. The Subjects of thematic investigation are not only the professional investigators but also the men and women of the people whose thematic universe is being sought. Investigation—the first moment of action as cultural synthesis—establishes a climate of creativity which will tend to develop in the subsequent stages of action. Such a climate does not exist in cultural invasion, which through alienation kills the ­creative enthusiasm of those who are invaded, leaving them hopeless and fearful of risking experimentation, without which there is no true creativity.

被入侵者，无论其水平如何，很少会超越入侵者为他们规定的模式。在文化综合中，没有入侵者；因此，没有强加的模式。取而代之的是，有行为者批判性地分析现实（从不将这种分析与行动分开），并作为主体介入历史进程。

Those who are invaded, whatever their level, rarely go beyond the models which the invaders prescribe for them. In cultural synthesis there are no invaders; hence, there are no imposed models. In their stead, there are actors who critically analyze reality (never separating this analysis from action) and intervene as Subjects in the historical process.

领导者和民众不是按照预先确定的计划行事，而是相互认同，共同制定行动准则。在这种综合体中，领导者和民众以新知识和新行动的方式重生。对异化文化的了解导致变革性行动，从而形成一种摆脱异化的文化。领导者更复杂的知识在民众的经验知识中得到重塑，而后者又被领导者精炼。

Instead of following predetermined plans, leaders and people, mutually identified, together create the guidelines of their action. In this synthesis, leaders and people are somehow reborn in new knowledge and new action. Knowledge of the alienated culture leads to transforming action resulting in a culture which is being freed from alienation. The more sophisticated knowledge of the leaders is remade in the empirical knowledge of the people, while the latter is refined by the former.

在文化综合中——也只有在文化综合中——才有可能解决领导人的世界观与人民的世界观之间的矛盾，从而使双方都得到丰富。文化综合并不否认两种观点之间的差异；事实上，它正是建立在这些差异之上的。它确实否认一方对另一方的侵犯，但肯定双方对另一方给予的不可否认的支持。

In cultural synthesis—and only in cultural synthesis—it is possi­ble to resolve the contradiction between the world view of the lead­ers and that of the people, to the enrichment of both. Cultural ­synthesis does not deny the differences between the two views; indeed, it is based on these differences. It does deny the invasion of one by the other, but affirms the undeniable support each gives to the other.

革命领袖必须避免脱离人民组织起来；由于某些历史条件，偶然发生的与人民的矛盾都必须解决——而不是通过强加关系的文化入侵来加剧矛盾。文化融合是唯一的出路。

Revolutionary leaders must avoid organizing themselves apart from the people; whatever contradiction to the people may occur fortuitously, due to certain historical conditions, must be solved—not augmented by the cultural invasion of an imposed relationship. Cultural synthesis is the only way.

革命领袖们犯下了许多错误和失算，因为他们没有考虑到人民对世界的看法这种现实：这种看法明确或隐含地包含了他们的担忧、他们的疑虑、他们的希望、他们看待领袖的方式、他们对自己和压迫者的看法、他们的宗教信仰（几乎总是融合的）、他们的宿命论、他们的反叛反应。这些因素都不能单独看待，因为它们相互作用构成了一个整体。压迫者之所以对了解这个整体感兴趣，只是为了帮助他采取侵略行动，以统治或维护统治。对于革命领袖来说，了解这个整体对他们的文化综合行动是必不可少的。

Revolutionary leaders commit many errors and miscalculations by not taking into account something so real as the people’s view of the world: a view which explicitly and implicitly contains their concerns, their doubts, their hopes, their way of seeing the leaders, their ­perceptions of themselves and of the oppressors, their religious beliefs (almost always syncretic), their fatalism, their rebellious reac­tions. None of these elements can be seen separately, for in interaction all of them compose a totality. The oppressor is interested in knowing this totality only as an aid to his action of invasion in order to dominate or preserve domination. For the revolutionary leaders, the knowledge of this totality is indispensable to their action as cultural synthesis.

文化综合（正因为它是一种综合）并不意味着革命行动的目标应该受到人民世界观所表达的愿望的限制。如果这种情况发生（以尊重这种观点为幌子），革命领袖就会被动地受制于这种观点。无论是领袖侵入人民的世界观，还是领袖仅仅适应人民（往往是天真的）的愿望，都是不可接受的。

Cultural synthesis (precisely because it is a synthesis) does not mean that the objectives of revolutionary action should be limited by the aspirations expressed in the world view of the people. If this were to happen (in the guise of respect for that view), the revolutionary leaders would be passively bound to that vision. Neither invasion by the leaders of the people’s world view nor mere adaptation by the leaders to the (often naive) aspirations of the people is acceptable.

具体来说：如果在某一历史时刻，人民的基本愿望仅仅是要求增加工资，那么领导者可能会犯两种错误之一。他们可以将自己的行动限制在刺激这一要求上，或者 可以推翻这一大众的愿望，代之以更深远但尚未引起人民注意的东西。在第一种情况下，革命领袖遵循以下路线：第二种情况，不尊重人民的意愿，陷入文化侵略。

To be concrete: if at a given historical moment the basic aspiration of the people goes no further than a demand for salary increases, the leaders can commit one of two errors. They can limit their action to stimulating this one demand54 or they can overrule this ­popular aspiration and substitute something more far-reaching—but something which has not yet come to the forefront of the people’s attention. In the first case, the revolutionary leaders follow a line of adaptation to the people’s demands. In the second case, by disrespecting the aspirations of the people, they fall into cultural invasion.

解决方案在于综合：领导者一方面必须认同人民对更高工资的要求，另一方面必须将这一要求本身的意义提出来。通过这样做，领导者将一个真实、具体、历史的情况提出来，而工资要求只是其中的一个方面。由此可以清楚地看出，工资要求本身并不能构成一个明确的解决方案。这一解决方案的本质可以在前面引用的第三世界主教的声明中找到：“如果工人不能以某种方式成为自己劳动力的所有者，那么所有结构性改革都将无效……他们[必须]是劳动力的所有者，而不是卖方……[因为]任何劳动力的买卖都是一种奴役。”

The solution lies in synthesis: the leaders must on the one hand identify with the people’s demand for higher salaries, while on the other they must pose the meaning of that very demand as a problem. By doing this, the leaders pose as a problem a real, concrete, histori­cal situation of which the salary demand is one dimension. It will thereby become clear that salary demands alone cannot comprise a definitive solution. The essence of this solution can be found in the previously cited statement by bishops of the Third World that “if the workers do not somehow come to be owners of their own labor, all structural reforms will be ineffective . . . they [must] be owners, not sellers, of their labor . . . [for] any purchase or sale of labor is a type of slavery.”

要认识到必须成为“自己劳动力的主人”，劳动力“是人的一部分”，“人既不能被出售，也不能出卖自己”这些事实，就要比治标不治本的欺骗性做法更进一步。要真正改变现实，通过使现实人性化，使男人和女人人性化。

To achieve critical consciousness of the facts that it is necessary to be the “owner of one’s own labor,” that labor “constitutes part of the human person,” and that “a human being can neither be sold nor can he sell himself” is to go a step beyond the deception of ­palliative solutions. It is to engage in authentic transformation of reality in order, by humanizing that reality, to humanize women and men.

在反对话行为理论中，文化入侵服务于操纵的目的，操纵又服务于征服的目的，征服又服务于统治的目的。文化综合服务于组织的目的，组织服务于解放的目的。

In the antidialogical theory of action, cultural invasion serves the ends of manipulation, which in turn serves the ends of conquest, and conquest the ends of domination. Cultural synthesis serves the ends of organization; organization serves the ends of liberation.

这部作品涉及一个非常明显的事实：正如压迫者为了压迫需要一种压迫行动的理论一样，被压迫者为了获得自由，也需要一种行动理论。

This work deals with a very obvious truth: just as the ­oppressor, in order to oppress, needs a theory of oppressive action, so the oppressed, in order to become free, also need a theory of action.

压迫者在没有人民的情况下阐述他的行动理论，因为他与人民对立。人民——只要他们被压迫和压迫，内化压迫者的形象——就无法自己构建解放行动的理论。只有在人民与革命领袖的接触中——在他们的交流中，在他们的实践中——才能建立这一理论。

The oppressor elaborates his theory of action without the people, for he stands against them. Nor can the people—as long as they are crushed and oppressed, internalizing the image of the oppressor—construct by themselves the theory of their liberating action. Only in the encounter of the people with the revolutionary leaders—in their communion, in their praxis—can this theory be built.

笔记

Notes

1 弗拉基米尔·列宁，《该怎么办》，载《列宁全书选编》，亨利·M·克里斯特曼主编（纽约，1966 年），第 69 页。

1 Vladimir Lenin, “What is to be Done,” in Essential Works of Lenin, Henry M. Christman, ed. (New York, 1966), p. 69.

2 这种危险进一步要求革命领袖们抵制模仿压迫者的做法，压迫者“进入”被压迫者，并被后者“安置”。革命者在与被压迫者交往时，不能试图“居住”在后者身上。相反，当他们（与被压迫者一起）试图“赶走”压迫者时，他们这样做是为了与被压迫者生活在一起——而不是生活在他们之中。

2 This danger further requires the revolutionary leaders to resist imitating the procedures of the oppressors, who “enter” the oppressed and are “housed” by the latter. The revolutionaries, in their praxis with the oppressed, cannot try to “reside” in the latter. On the contrary, when they try (with the oppressed) to “throw out” the oppressors, they do this in order to live with the oppressed—not to live within them.

3 尽管被压迫的人们始终处于剥削制度之下，他们可能会理所当然地在革命斗争中赋予复仇主义的维度，但革命绝不能在这方面耗尽自己的力量。

3 Although the oppressed, who have always been subject to a regime of exploita­tion, may understandably impart a revanchist dimension to the revolutionary strug-gle, the revolution must not exhaust its forces in this dimension.

4 菲德尔·卡斯特罗在确认格瓦拉死讯时向古巴人民说：“虽然我们可能从怀疑中获得一些好处，但谎言、对真相的恐惧、对虚假幻想的同谋、对谎言的同谋从来都不是革命的武器。”引自《格拉玛》。1967 年 10 月 17 日。着重号是我加上的。

4 “While we might obtain some benefit from doubt,” said Fidel Castro to the Cuban people as he confirmed the death of Guevara, “lies, fear of the truth, com­plicity with false illusions, and complicity with lies have never been weapons of the revolution.” Quoted in Gramma. October 17, 1967. Emphasis added.

5 我再重复一遍，这种对话不可能发生在对手之间。

5 Once more, let me repeat that this dialogical encounter cannot take place between antagonists.

6 “在统治阶级稳定的时代，在工人运动必须保卫自己免受强大对手的威胁、且在任何情况下都牢牢掌握权力的时代，自然会产生一种社会主义文献，这种文献强调现实的‘物质’因素、需要克服的障碍以及人类意识和行动的微弱效力。” Goldman，上文，第 80-81 页。

6 “The epochs during which the dominant classes are stable, epochs in which the workers’ movement must defend itself against a powerful adversary which is occasionally threatening and is in every case solidly seated in power, produces naturally a socialist literature which emphasizes the ‘material’ element of reality, the obstacles to be overcome, and the scant efficacy of human awareness and action.” Goldman, op. cit., pp. 80–81.

7 洪都拉斯人费尔南多·加西亚 (Fernando García) 在拉丁美洲人课程上 (圣地亚哥，1967 年)。

7 Fernando García, a Honduran, in a course for Latin Americans (Santiago, 1967).

8 尼布尔，同上。引文，第 117-118 页。

8 Niebuhr, op. cit., pp. 117–118.

9 有时甚至连“话”都不说。只要有人（不一定属于革命团体）威胁“藏身”在人民中的压迫者，就足以使后者采取破坏性立场。一位学生曾经告诉我，在某个拉丁美洲农民社区，一位狂热的牧师谴责社区里有两个“共产主义者”的存在，说他们“危害”了他所谓的“天主教信仰”。当天晚上，农民们联合起来，活活烧死了两名正在教育当地儿童的朴实小学教师。也许那位牧师在教师家里看到了一本书，封面上有一个留着胡子的男人……

9 Sometimes this “word” is not even spoken.
