The presence of someone (not ­necessarily belonging to a revolutionary group) who can threaten the oppressor “housed” in the people is sufficient for the latter to assume destructive positions.A student once told me how, in a certain Latin American peasant community, a fanatical priest had denounced the presence in the community of two “communists” who were “endangering” what he called the “Catholic faith.” That very night the peasants, to a man, joined together to burn alive the two simple elementary school teachers who had been educating the local children. Perhaps that priest had seen in the house of the teachers a book with a bearded man on the cover . . .

10 我要再次强调，对话与革命行动之间并无二分。对话和革命并无二致。相反，对话是革命行动的本质。在这种行动的理论中，行动者以主体间性的方式将他们的行动指向一个对象（现实，它充当他们的中介），目标是使人人化（通过改变现实来实现）。

10 Once more, I wish to emphasize that there is no dichotomy between dialogue and revolutionary action. There is not one stage for dialogue and another for revolution. On the contrary, dialogue is the essence of revolutionary action. In the theory of this action, the actors intersubjectively direct their action upon an object (reality, which mediates them) with the humanization of men (to be achieved by trans-forming that reality) as their objective.

        在本质上反对话的压迫者行动理论中，上述方案被简化了。行动者同时将现实和被压迫者作为其行动的对象，并以维持压迫（通过维持压迫性现实）作为其目标。

        In the theory of oppressor action, antidialogical in essence, the above scheme is simplified. The actors have as simultaneous objects of their action both reality and the oppressed, and the preservation of oppression (through the preservation of oppressive reality) as their objective.

11 参见毛泽东，上文引文。

11 See Mao Tse Tung, op. cit.

12 Gajo Petrovic，《人与自由》，载埃里希·弗洛姆主编的《社会主义人道主义》（纽约，1965 年），第 274-276 页。同一位作者所著《20 世纪中叶的马克思》（纽约，1967 年）。

12 Gajo Petrovic, “Man and Freedom,” in Socialist Humanism, edited by Erich Fromm (New York, 1965), pp. 274–276. By the same author, see Marx in the Mid-Twentieth Century (New York, 1967).

13 人民革命一旦掌权，新政权就有道德义务镇压任何恢复旧压迫政权的企图，这一事实绝不意味着革命违背了其对话性质。在革命之前，作为对立阶级的压迫者和被压迫者之间不可能进行对话；革命之后，这种对话仍然不可能。

13 Once a popular revolution has come to power, the fact that the new power has the ethical duty to repress any attempt to restore the old oppressive power by no means signifies that the revolution is contradicting its dialogical character. Dialogue between the former oppressors and the oppressed as antagonistic classes was not possible before the revolution; it continues to be impossible afterward.

14 “此外，经济发达国家应特别注意，不要在向较贫穷的国家提供援助时，试图将当前的政治局势转变为自己的优势，并试图控制这些国家。如果真的有这样的企图，这显然只是另一种形式的殖民主义，虽然名义上是伪装的，但实际上只是反映了他们以前但过时的统治，现在已被许多国家抛弃。当国际关系受到阻碍时，所有人民的有序进步都会受到威胁。”教皇约翰二十三世，《基督教与社会进步》，摘自《母亲与导师》通谕，第 171 和 172 条。

14 “Moreover, economically developed countries should take particular care lest, in giving aid to poorer countries, they endeavor to turn the prevailing political situation to their own advantage, and seek to dominate them.Should perchance such attempts be made, this clearly would be but another form of colonialism which, although disguised in name, merely reflects their earlier but outdated dominion, now abandoned by many countries. When international ­relations are thus obstructed, the orderly progress of all peoples is endangered.” Pope John XXIII, “Christianity and Social Progress,” from the Encyclical Letter Mater et Magistra, articles 171 and 172.

15 梅米提到了殖民者为被殖民者构建的形象：“殖民者通过指控将被殖民者认定为懒惰。他认为懒惰是被殖民者天性使然。”梅米，上文，第 81 页。

15 Memmi refers to the image the colonizer constructs of the colonized: “By his accusation the colonizer establishes the colonized as being lazy. He decides that laziness is constitutional in the very nature of the colonized.” Memmi, op. cit., p. 81.

16 我批评的并不是媒体本身，而是媒体的使用方式。

16 It is not the media themselves which I criticize, but the way they are used.

17 当然，这种批评并不适用于辩证视角下的行动，这种行动基于对地方社区本身的理解，既将其视为一个整体，又将其视为更大整体的一部分。它针对的是那些没有意识到地方社区的发展只有在其所属的整体背景下，与其他部分相互作用的情况下才能发生的人。这一要求意味着在多样化中保持统一的意识，在分散中引导力量的组织，以及对改变现实的必要性的清晰认识。这（可以理解）正是压迫者所害怕的。

17 This criticism of course does not apply to actions within a dialectical perspec­-tive, based on the understanding of the local community both as a totality in itself and as part of a larger totality. It is directed at those who do not realize that the ­development of the local community cannot occur except in the total context of which it is a part, in interaction with other parts. This requirement implies the ­consciousness of unity in diversification, of organization which channels forces in ­dispersion, and a clear awareness of the necessity to transform reality. This (understandably) is what frightens the oppressors.

18 弗朗西斯普利特主教雄辩地提到了这一点：“如果工人不能以某种方式成为其劳动力的主人，那么所有结构性改革都将无效。即使工人在经济体系中获得了更高的工资，但他们并不满足于这些加薪。他们希望成为劳动力的主人，而不是卖家。……目前，工人们越来越意识到劳动力是人的一部分。但是，人是不能被收买的；人也不能出卖自己。任何劳动力的买卖都是一种奴役。人类社会在这方面的进化显然是在一个据说对人类尊严问题反应迟钝的体系中，即马克思主义中取得的进展。”“第三世界前进中的 15 个目标。” CIDOC Informa（墨西哥，1967 年），文件 67/35，第 1-11 页。

18 Bishop Franic Split refers eloquently to this point : “If the workers do not become in some way the owners of their labor, all structural reforms will be ineffec­-tive. [This is true] even if the workers receive a higher salary in an economic ­system but are not content with these raises. They want to be owners, not ­sellers, of their labor. . . . At ­present the workers are increasingly aware that labor represents a part of the human person. A person, however cannot be bought; neither can he sell ­himself. Any purchase or sale of labor is a type of slavery. The evolution of human society in this respect is clearly progressing within a system said to be less responsive than our own to the question of human dignity, i.e., Marxism.” “15 ­Obispos hablan en prol del Tercer Mundo.” CIDOC Informa (Mexico, 1967), Doc. 67/35, pp. 1–11.

19 关于社会阶级及其斗争（人们常常指责马克思捏造了这一现象），参见马克思1852年3月1日写给约·魏德迈的信：“……我发现现代社会中存在阶级及其斗争，这并不是我的功劳。早在我之前，资产阶级历史学家就描述了这一阶级斗争的历史发展，资产阶级经济学家也描述了阶级的经济结构。我所做的新颖的事情，是证明了：（1）阶级的存在只是和生产发展的某些历史阶段有关；（2）阶级斗争必然导致无产阶级专政；（3）这一专政本身只是走向消灭一切阶级和进入无阶级社会的过渡……”《马克思、恩格斯选集》（纽约，1968年），第679页。

19 With respect to social classes and the struggle between them (which Karl Marx is often accused of inventing), see Marx’s letter to J. Weydemeyer dated March 1, 1852: “. . . no credit is due to me for discovering the existence of classes in ­modern ­society or the struggle between them. Long before me bourgeois historians had described the historical development of this class struggle and bourgeois economists the economic anatomy of the classes. What I did that was new was to prove: (1) that the existence of classes is only bound up with particular historical phases in the development of production; (2) that the class struggle necessarily leads to the dictatorship of the proletariat; (3) that this dictatorship itself only constitutes the transition to the abolition of all classes and to classless society . . .” Karl Marx and Frederick Engels, Selected Works (New York, 1968), p. 679.

20 因此，压迫者必须将农民与城市工人隔离开来，就像必须将这两个群体与学生隔离开来一样。后者的叛乱证词（尽管他们在社会学上不构成一个阶级）使他们在加入人民时变得危险。因此，有必要说服下层阶级，学生是不负责任和无序的，他们的证词是虚假的，因为作为学生，他们应该学习，就像工厂工人和农民应该为“国家进步”而努力一样。

20 For this reason it is indispensable for the oppressors to keep the peasants ­isolated from the urban workers, just as it is indispensable to keep both groups ­isolated from the students. The testimony of rebellion of the latter (although they do not sociologically constitute a class) makes them dangerous in the event they join the people. It is thus necessary to convince the lower classes that students are ­irresponsible and disorderly, that their testimony is false because as students they should be studying, just as the factory workers and the peasants should be working towards the “nation’s progress.”

21 蒂拉登特斯是 1789 年在米纳斯吉拉斯州欧鲁普雷图发起的巴西从葡萄牙独立起义的领导人，但未遂。这一运动历史上被称为Inconfidência Mineira。 ——译者注。

21 Tiradentes was leader of an abortive revolt for the independence of Brazil from Portugal in 1789 in Ouro Preto, State of Minas Gerais. This movement is historically called the Inconfidência Mineira.—Translator’s note.

22 Visconde de Barbacena，该省的皇家行政长官。——译者注。

22 Visconde de Barbacena, royal administrator of the province.—Translator’s note.

23 只有当正在进行或将要开展的行动的目标受群众决定时，契约才对群众有效（在这种情况下它们不再是契约）。

23 Pacts are only valid for the masses (and in this case they are no longer pacts) when the objectives of the action in process or to be developed are subject to their decision.

24 在操纵行为产生的“组织”中，人们——仅仅是被引导的对象——被操纵者的目标所适应。在真正的组织中，个人积极参与组织过程，组织的目标不是由他人强加的。在第一种情况下，组织是一种“大众化”的手段，在第二种情况下，组织是一种解放的手段。[在巴西的政治术语中，“大众化”是将人们缩小为一个可管理的、不加思考的群体的过程。——译者]

24 In the “organization” which results from acts of manipulation, the people—mere guided objects—are adapted to the objectives of the manipulators. In true organization, the individuals are active in the organizing process, and the objectives of the organization are not imposed by others. In the first case, the organization is a means of “massification,” in the second, a means of liberation. [In Brazilian political terminology, “massification” is the process of reducing the people to a manageable, unthinking agglomeration.—Translator]

25 Francisco Weffert，“Politica de Massas”，《巴西的政治与社会革命》（里约热内卢，1967 年），第 14 页。 187.

25 Francisco Weffert, “Politica de massas,” Política e Revolução social no Brasil (Rio de Janeiro, 1967), p. 187.

26 1930 年，热图利奥·瓦加斯领导革命推翻了巴西总统华盛顿·路易斯。他以独裁者身份执政直至 1945 年。1950 年，他以民选总统身份重新掌权。1954 年 8 月，当反对派即将推翻他时，他自杀身亡。——译者注。

26 Getulio Vargas led the revolution which overthrew Brazilian President Wash­ington Luis in 1930. He remained in power as a dictator until 1945. In 1950 he returned to power as elected president. In August 1954, when the opposition was about to overthrow him, he committed suicide.—Translator’s note.

27 1950 年 5 月 1 日在瓦斯科达伽马体育场发表的讲话，O Governo Trabalhista no Brasil（里约），第 322-324 页。

27 Speech given in Vasco da Gama Stadium on May 1, 1950, O Governo Trabal­hista no Brasil (Rio), pp. 322–324.

28 同上。重点已添加。

28 Ibid. Emphasis added.

29 为此，侵略者越来越多地利用社会科学和技术，在一定程度上也利用物理科学，来改进和完善他们的行动。侵略者必须了解被侵略者的过去和现在，以便辨别后者未来的选择，并试图引导未来的发展朝着有利于他们自己利益的方向发展。

29 To this end, the invaders are making increasing use of the social sciences and technology, and to some extent the physical sciences as well, to improve and refine their action. It is indispensable for the invaders to know the past and ­present of those invaded in order to discern the alternatives of the latter’s future and thereby attempt to guide the evolution of that future along lines that will favor their own interests.

30 年轻人越来越多地认为父母和老师的专制主义不利于他们自己的自由。正因为如此，他们越来越反对那些削弱他们的表达能力和阻碍他们自我肯定的行为形式。这种非常积极的现象并非偶然。它实际上是历史氛围的一种表现，正如第 1 章所述，这种氛围将我们的时代描述为一个人类学时代。因此，除非有个人兴趣，否则人们不能将青年叛乱仅仅视为代际传统差异的一个例子。这里涉及更深层次的东西。年轻人在叛乱中谴责和谴责统治社会的不公正模式。然而，这种具有特殊维度的叛乱是最近才发生的；社会仍然具有专制性质。

30 Young people increasingly view parent and teacher authoritarianism as inimical to their own freedom. For this very reason, they increasingly oppose forms of action which minimize their expressiveness and hinder their self-affirmation. This very positive phenomenon is not accidental. It is actually a symptom of the historical climate which (as mentioned in chapter 1) characterizes our epoch as an anthropological one. For this reason one cannot (unless he has a personal interest in doing so) see the youth rebellion as a mere example of the traditional differences between generations. Something deeper is involved here. Young people in their rebellion are denouncing and condemning the unjust model of a society of domination. This rebellion with its special dimension, however, is very recent; society continues to be authoritarian in character.

31 这也许也解释了那些虽然坚信自己有革命决心，却仍然不信任人民并害怕与人民交流的人的反对话行为。这些人无意识地将压迫者保留在自己心中；由于他们“庇护”了主人，他们害怕自由。

31 It perhaps also explains the antidialogical behavior of persons who, although convinced of their revolutionary commitment, continue to mistrust the people and fear communion with them. Unconsciously, such persons retain the oppressor within themselves; and because they “house” the master, they fear freedom.

32 请参阅我的“Extensão ou Comunicação？” Introducción a la Acción Cultural（圣地亚哥，1969）。

32 See my “Extensão ou Comunicação?” in Introducción a la Acción Cultural (Santiago, 1969).

33 有关该机构的活动，请参阅玛丽·科尔 (Mary Cole)，《城市的夏天》 (纽约，1968 年)。

33 Regarding the activities of this institution, see Mary Cole, Summer in the City (New York, 1968).

34 参见路易斯·阿尔都塞，《为马克思而奋斗》（巴黎，1967 年），其中他用了整整一章来讨论“末日终结的辩证法”。

34 See Louis Althusser, Pour Marx (Paris, 1967), in which he dedicates an entire chapter to “la dialectique de la surdétermination.”

35 然而，这个过程并不像机械思想家天真地认为的那样突然发生。

35 This process, however, does not occur suddenly, as mechanistic thinkers naïvely assume.

36 阿尔都塞，上文引文。

36 Althusser, op. cit.

37 关于这个问题，阿尔都塞评论道：“在最后终止的辩证法中，重新激活是不可想象的。”阿尔都塞，同前。引，第。 116.

37 On this matter, Althusser comments “Cette reactivation serait proprement inconcevable dans une dialectique dépourvue de surdétermination.” Althusser, op. cit., p. 116.

38 上一章引用了格瓦拉关于这个问题的思想。赫尔曼·古兹曼这样评价卡米洛·托雷斯：“……他奉献了一切。无论何时，他都保持着对人民的忠诚——作为一名牧师、一名基督徒和一名革命者。”译自赫尔曼·古兹曼的《卡米洛——游击队的医生》（波哥大，1967 年），第 5 页。

38 The thoughts of Guevara on this subject are cited in the preceding chapter. German Guzman says of Camilo Torres: “. . . he gave everything. At all times he ­maintained a vital posture of commitment to the people—as a priest, as a Christian, and as a revolutionary.” Translated from German Guzman, Camilo—El Cura Guer­rillero (Bogatá, 1967), p. 5.

39 “阶级必然性”是一回事，“阶级意识”又是另一回事。

39 “Class necessity” is one thing; “class consciousness” is another.

40 1966 年，一位智力和道德素质都很高的智利牧师访问了累西腓，他告诉我：“当我和一位伯南布坎同事去看望几个住在棚屋里、贫困得难以形容的家庭时，我问他们，他们怎么能忍受这样的生活，他们的回答总是一样的：‘我能做什么？这是上帝的旨意，我必须接受。’”

40 A Chilean priest of high intellectual and moral caliber visiting Recife in 1966 told me: “When a Pernambucan colleague and I went to see several families living in shanties [mocambos] in indescribable poverty, I asked them how they could bear to live like that, and the answer was always the same: ‘What can I do? It is the will of God and I must accept it’. ”

41 关于这一点，参见埃里希·弗洛姆《人文主义精神分析在马克思主义理论中的应用》，载《社会主义人文主义》 （纽约，1966 年）；以及鲁本·奥斯本《马克思主义与精神分析》（伦敦，1965 年）。

41 On this point, see Erich Fromm, “The Application of Humanist Psychoanaly­sis to Marxist Theory,” in Socialist Humanism (New York, 1966); and Reuben Os­born, Marxism and Psychoanalysis (London, 1965).

42 切·格瓦拉，《革命者的秘密文件：切·格瓦拉日记》（The Ramparts Edition，1968 年），第 105–106 页、第 120 页。

42 Che Guevara, The Secret Papers of a Revolutionary: The Diary of Che Guevara (The Ramparts Edition, 1968), pp. 105–106, 120.

43 参见马丁·布伯，《我与你》（纽约，1958 年）。

43 See Martin Buber, I and Thou (New York, 1958).

44 格瓦拉写信给埃尔帕托霍（El Patojo，一位离开古巴在自己的国家从事游击活动的危地马拉年轻人）：“不信任：一开始，不要相信自己的影子，永远不要相信友好的农民、告密者、向导或联络人。在一个地区完全解放之前，不要相信任何事或任何人。”切·格瓦拉，《革命战争篇章》（纽约，1968 年），第 102 页。

44 Guevara to El Patojo, a young Guatemalan leaving Cuba to engage in guer-rilla activity in his own country: “Mistrust: at the beginning, do not trust your own shadow, never trust friendly peasants, informers, guides, or contact men. Do not trust anything or anybody until a zone is completely liberated.” Che Guevara, ­Episodes of the Revolutionary War (New York, 1968), p. 102.

45 同上，第 56-57 页。重点已添加。

45 Ibid., pp. 56–57. Emphasis added.

46 关于当前思想中人类在“上帝之死”之后对自身死亡的防御，参见米克尔·杜夫雷纳 (Mikel Dufrenne) 的《为人类而战》( Pour L'Homme)（巴黎，1968 年）。

46 With regard to man’s defenses against his own death, following the “death of God,” in current thought, see Mikel Dufrenne, Pour L’Homme (Paris, 1968).

47 “许多 [农民] 卖身或卖身为奴以逃避 [饥饿]。贝洛奥里藏特的一家报纸发现有多达 50,000 名受害者（售价 1,500,000 美元），为了证明这一点，一名记者以 30 美元买下了一名男子和他的妻子。‘我见过许多好人饿死，’这名奴隶解释道；‘这就是为什么我不介意被卖掉。’ 1959 年，一名奴隶贩子在圣保罗被捕，他承认与圣保罗牧场主、咖啡种植园和建筑项目有联系，以出售他的商品——除了被卖到妓院的少女。”约翰·杰拉西，《大恐惧》（纽约，1963 年）。

47 “Many [peasants] sell themselves or members of their families into slavery to escape [starvation]. One Belo Horizonte newspaper discovered as many as 50,000 victims (sold for $1,500,000), and one reporter, to prove it, bought a man and his wife for $30. ‘I have seen many a good man starve,’ explained the slave; ‘that is why I did not mind being sold.’ When one slave dealer was arrested in São Paulo in 1959, he admitted having contacts with São Paulo ranchers, coffee plantations, and construction projects for his commodity—except teenage girls who were sold to brothels.” John Gerassi, The Great Fear (New York, 1963).

48 医学博士。 Chenu，Temoignage Chrétien， 1964 年 4 月，André Moine 引用，载于《Christianos y Marxistas después del Concilio》（布宜诺艾利斯，1965 年），第 14 页。 167.

48 M.-D. Chenu, Temoignage Chrétien, April 1964, as cited by André Moine, in Christianos y Marxistas después del Concilio (Bueno Aires, 1965), p. 167.

49 对于一个人来说，要获得对自己作为受压迫者的地位的批判意识，就需要承认自己的现实是一个压迫性的现实。正是出于这个原因，它需要达到“对社会本质的理解”，这对卢卡奇来说是“un facteur de puissance de tout prime order, pouquoi c'est même sans doute l'arme purement et simplement devisive”。 。 ”。乔治·卢卡奇 (Georg Lukács)，《Histoire et Conscience de Classe》（巴黎，1960 年），第 14 页。 93.

49 For someone to achieve critical consciousness of his status as an oppressed man requires recognition of his reality as an oppressive reality. For this very reason, it requires reaching the “compréhension de l’essence de la societé,” which is for Lukács “un facteur de puissance de tout premier ordre, pouquoi c’est même sans doute l’arme purement et simplement dévisive . . .” Georg Lukács, Histoire et Con­science de Classe (Paris, 1960), p. 93.

50 作为一个过程，真实的见证若不能立即产生结果，就不能被判定为绝对失败。屠杀提拉登特斯的人可以把他的尸体分成四份，但他们无法抹去他的见证。

50 Regarded as process, authentic witness which does not bear immediate fruit cannot be judged an absolute failure. The men who butchered Tiradentes could ­quarter his body, but they could not erase his witness.

51 古巴一所大学医学院院长奥兰多·阿吉雷·奥尔蒂斯博士曾告诉我：“革命涉及三个‘P’：palavra、povo、e pólvora（词语、人民和火药）。火药的爆炸澄清了人们对其具体处境的认识，并通过行动追求解放。”观察这位革命医生如何强调这个词在本文中的含义是有趣的：作为行动和反思，作为实践。

51 Dr. Orlando Aguirre Ortiz, Director of a Medical School at a Cuban uni­versity, once told me: “The revolution involves three “P’s”: palavra, povo, e pólvora [word, people, and gunpowder]. The explosion of the gunpowder clears the people’s perception of their concrete situation, in pursuit, through action, of their libera­tion.” It was interesting to observe how this revolutionary physician stressed the word in the sense it has been used in this essay: as action and reflection, as praxis.

52 如果客观情况是压迫或放纵，这种关系就会产生冲突。

52 This relationship will be conflictive if the objective situation is one of oppres­sion or of license.

53 使结构成为社会结构（因而是历史文化结构）的，既不是绝对意义上的永恒，也不是绝对意义上的变化，而是两者之间的辩证关系。归根结底，社会结构中持久的既不是永恒，也不是变化，而是永恒与变化的辩证法本身。

53 What makes a structure a social structure (and thus historical-cultural) is ­neither permanence nor change, taken absolutely, but the dialectical relations be­tween the two. In the last analysis, what endures in the social structure is neither permanence nor change; it is the permanence-change dialectic itself.

54 列宁严厉批评了俄国社会民主党强调无产阶级的经济要求作为革命斗争工具的倾向，他称这种做法为“经济自发性”。《该怎么办？》《论政治与革命》选集（纽约，1968 年）。

54 Lenin severely attacked the tendency of the Russian Social Democratic Party to emphasize economic demands of the proletariat as an instrument of the revolu­tionary struggle, a practice he termed “economic spontaneity.” “What is to be Done?” in On Politics and Revolution, Selected Writings (New York, 1968).

“奋斗不息”：《被压迫者教育学》后记

“A luta continua”: Afterword to Pedagogy of the Oppressed

Ira Shor，美国纽约市立大学史坦顿岛学院

Ira Shor, College of Staten Island, CUNY, USA

现在我不再是“群众”的一部分，我是“人民”，我可以要求我的权利。

Now I am no longer part of the “masses,” I am “people” and I can demand my rights.

Francisca Andrade，Angicos 弗雷雷恩识字圈的学生，1963 年

（Kirkendall，40 岁）

Francisca Andrade, student in a Freirean literacy circle in Angicos, 1963

(Kirkendall, 40)

1963 年 4 月 2 日，安吉科斯扫盲圈举行了最后一次会议，出席的不仅有保罗·弗莱雷，还有共和国自由派总统若昂·古拉特。弗莱雷告诉总统，“今天，有一群人可以做决定，一群人正在奋起反抗，一群人已经开始意识到自己的命运，并开始不可逆转地参与巴西的历史进程。”（柯肯德尔，40 岁）出席仪式的另一位要人是温贝托·卡斯特洛·布兰科将军，一年后，他推翻了古拉特，粉碎了保罗的国家计划，并将保罗投入监狱，从而扭转了民主。

The Angicos literacy circle celebrated its final meeting April 2, 1963, with not only Paulo Freire in attendance but also the liberal President of the Republic, Joao Goulart. Freire told the President, there “exists today a people who decides, a people that is rising up, a people that has begun to become aware of its destiny and has begun to take part in the Brazilian historical process irreversibly.”(Kirkendall, 40) At that ceremony, another dignitary attending was General Humberto Castelo Branco who, one year later almost to the day, would reverse democracy by overthrowing Goulart, crushing Paulo’s national program, and throwing Paulo in jail.

此后，巴西的灯光熄灭了太多年。也许我可以说，这本书诞生于黑暗之中，或者更确切地说，诞生于黑暗之中，或者更确切地说，诞生于希望和反抗压迫。作为巴西民主运动的一部分，弗莱雷的方法只用 40 小时的廉价教学就教会了文盲阅读和写作。一旦基本识字，贫穷的农民和工人终于可以在自上而下施加的长期沉默之后获得投票资格，从而大大扩大了自下而上的选民人数。如果成千上万的人弗莱雷文化圈如期开放，在那个可怕的 1964 年 4 月之后，数百万工人阶级文盲将能够很好地阅读和书写，从而登记为新选民，将政治权力拉到大多数人手中。为了阻止这种民主的可能性，寡头集团及其军队推翻了任命弗莱雷担任国家职务的民选古拉特政府。弗莱雷被审问和监禁，被迫离开这个国家。随后，他带着妻子埃尔扎和五个孩子在世界各地流浪，直到 1980 年，他的书在巴西被禁，在他政治生涯的黄金时期被驱逐出祖国。其他无法逃脱的人被监禁、殴打或追捕，因为将军们恢复了保守派精英不负责任的权力。在随后的岁月里，保罗充分利用了自己的生存优势，在欧洲和北美发表演讲，并为政府、非政府组织和当地项目提供咨询，成为当时最著名的教育家和社会正义的首要倡导者，并在政变的伤口尚不愈合时创作了《被压迫者教育学》：“提出问题的教育是革命性​​的未来……任何个人阻止其他人参与探究过程的情况都是暴力行为。”（65，66）

The lights went out in Brazil for too many years after that. Perhaps I can say that this book was born in the dark, or better, born against the dark, or better yet, born for hope and resistance against oppression. Part of an advancing democratic movement in Brazil, Freire’s method taught illiterates to read and write in only 40 hours of inexpensive instruction. Once basically literate, poor peasants and workers could finally qualify to vote after a very long silence imposed from the top down, vastly expanding the electorate from the bottom up. If thousands of Freirean culture circles had opened as planned after that terrible April 1964, millions of working-class illiterates would read and write well enough to register as new voters, pulling political power to the majority. To stop such a democratic possibility, the oligarchy and its army overthrew the elected Goulart administration which had appointed Freire to his national post. Interrogated and jailed, Freire was forced to leave the country. He then wandered the world with his wife Elza and five children until 1980, his books banned in Brazil, evicted from his homeland in the prime of his political life. Others who could not escape were imprisoned, beaten, or hounded as the generals restored a conservative elite to unaccountable power. In the years ahead, Paulo would use his survival well, addressing large crowds in Europe and North America as well as consulting with governments, NGOs, and local projects, becoming the most famous educator of his time as well as a foremost advocate for social justice, producing A Pedagogy of the Oppressed while the wounds of the coup were still fresh: “Problem-posing education is revolutionary futurity…Any situation in which some individuals prevent others from engaging in the process of inquiry is one of violence.”(65, 66)

很少有书籍能像它一样受到如此广泛的讨论、引用和摘录，并被用于教师教育、研究生和本科课程，甚至一些高中（正如 2012 年图森禁止这本书所表明的那样）。五十年后，如何解释《被压迫者教育学》的非凡吸引力？

Few books have been so widely debated, quoted, excerpted, and also used for teacher education, graduate and undergraduate courses, and in some high schools (as the banning of this book in Tucson in 2012 showed). Fifty years later, what can explain the extraordinary appeal of Pedagogy of the Oppressed?

保罗·弗莱雷在短短的四个章节中整合了一系列引人注目的关注点：

In four brief chapters, Paulo Freire integrated a remarkable array of concerns:

1. 以社会正义的名义质疑现状的批判教育学的理论与实践。

1. A theory and a practice for a critical pedagogy to question the status quo in the name of social justice.

2. 该理论和实践涉及“情境教学法”，可适应不同地方、不同利益相关者和不同条件。

2. The theory and practice involved a “situated pedagogy” which could be adapted for diverse places, different stakeholders, and varying conditions.

3. 这种情境教学法提供了丰富的实践词汇：对话式教学法、“问题探究”而非“灌输式教学法”、 “未经检验的可行性”、“极限情境和极限行为”、“文化圈”，“师生与生师”、“词汇世界”、“生成主题与生成词”、“编纂与破译”、良知觉醒或形成批判意识、“铰链主题”和“人类学的文化概念”、实践或行动/反思——循环地理论化实践并实践理论。

3. This situated pedagogy provided a rich lexicon of practice: a dialogue method of instruction, “problem-posing inquiry” instead of “banking pedagogy” memorization, “untested feasibility,” “limit-situations and limit-acts,” “the culture circle,” “the teacher-student with students-teachers,” “the vocabulary universe,” “the generative theme and the generative word,” “codification and de-codification,” conscientization or coming to critical consciousness, “hinged themes” and “the anthropological notion of culture,” praxis or action/reflection—cyclically theorizing practice and practicing theory.

4. 这套批判理论与实践的词汇是在保罗政变前 15 年在正规学校系统之外进行成人扫盲教育实验的过程中发展起来的；后来，它被改编为 K-12 和高等教育单位的词汇。

4. This lexicon for critical theory and practice evolved as Paulo experimented before the coup for fifteen years in adult literacy education outside formal school systems; later, it would be adapted for k-12 and higher education units.

5. 本书对批判实践的多样化环境持开放态度，与当时出现的具有平等、民主和社会正义倾向的多元文化、反种族主义和女权主义教育学和运动相交叉。

5. Open to diverse settings for critical practice, this book crossed paths with multicultural, anti-racist and feminist pedagogies and movements also emerging at that time with similar orientations toward equality, democracy, and social justice.

6. 本书的社会正义取向恰好出现在激进变革的群众运动成为全球现象的时期，正如米歇尔·福柯（Michel Foucault）所说，这是一个以“事物、制度、实践和言论具有巨大且不断增长的批判性”而闻名的时期（6），当时以学生为中心的方法和建构主义方法在教育界占据上风。

6. The social justice orientation of this book appeared just when mass movements for radical change became global phenomena, in a period famous for “the immense and proliferating criticizability of things, institutions and practices, and discourses,” as Michel Foucault put it,(6) and when student-centered approaches and constructivist methods were on the offensive in educational circles.

7. 弗莱雷的理论和实践以学生为中心，建构主义，批判不平等，他提出所有教育都是政治。没有任何一种教育学是中立的，因为所有教育学都以某种方式发展人类主体并产生意识，这取决于内容的意识形态、话语的社会关系和课程的学习过程。任何不质疑现状的教育学或课程都是默许或积极地认可现状。

7. Student-centered, constructivist, and critical of inequality, Freire’s theory and practice proposed all education as politics. No pedagogy can be neutral because all develop human subjects and produce consciousness one way or another, depending on the ideology of the contents, the social relations of discourse, and the learning process of the curriculum. Any pedagogy or curriculum which does not question the status quo tacitly or actively endorses it.

8. 这一学习过程提供了基于互惠伦理和专业责任的有吸引力的道德价值观，旨在教导人们如何创造一个不那么暴力和残酷的世界。弗莱雷对人性化和非人性的关注从第一页就引发了这种担忧。

8. This learning process offered appealing moral values based in ethics of mutuality and professional responsibility to teach for a world less violent and cruel. Freire’s preoccupation with humanization and de-humanization launched this concern on the very first page.

9. 最后，“第四章”是一封写给未来革命领袖的非凡书信，而不仅仅是给批判教育者的建议。它谴责那些谴责统治但却陷入独裁独白、劝诫、抽象的反对派领导人，官僚统治和宣传（在弗雷勒教室中是不允许的）。

9. Finally, “Chapter 4” is an extraordinary epistle to would-be revolutionary leaders, not merely advice for critical educators. It rebukes oppositional leaders who denounce domination but slide into authoritarian monologue, exhortation, abstractness, bureaucratic rule, and propagandizing (not permissible in Freirean classrooms).

这些观点有助于解释这本小书的长盛不衰和影响力。这本书并非以学术论文的形式写成，而是从弗莱雷对自己的实践和经验的反思中发展而来。弗莱雷在《序言》中写道：“单靠思考和研究并不能产生《被压迫者教育学》”。他报告说，这本书“植根于具体的情况，描述了我在教育工作过程中直接或间接观察到的劳动者（农民或城市人）和中产阶级的反应。”(19)

These points help account for the longevity and impact of this small book, which was not written as a scholastic treatise, but rather grew from Freire’s reflection on his practice and experiences. “Thought and study alone did not produce Pedagogy of the Oppressed,” Freire wrote in “The Preface.” This book, he reported, “is rooted in concrete situations and describes the reactions of laborers (peasant or urban) and of middle-class persons whom I have observed directly or indirectly during the course of my educative work.”(19)

保罗认为，在学校或社会运动中进行批判性教育对智力要求高，而且政治风险大。内部教育计划的运动面临着保罗称之为“当权者”的强大权威。在学校和大学里，教师和学生每天都在自我创造，但很大程度上是在外部和上层主导的条件下（“极限情况”，而批判性教育学则是针对这种“极限行为”）。保罗特别关注群众运动内部可能出现的批判性学习（“尚未掌权的权力”），但在 1989 年工人党赢得圣保罗市政府控制权后，他被任命为圣保罗 643 所学校的教育部长。对于保罗来说，在他的一生和工作中，这本著名著作的基本问题一直是：我们生活在什么样的世界里？为什么会这样？我们想要什么样的世界？我们如何从这里到达那里？

Paulo considered critical education in schools or in social movements intellectually demanding and politically risky. Move ments with internal education programs confront formidable authorities who Paulo called “the power now in power.” In schools and colleges, teachers and students make themselves each day but under terms largely dominated from outside and above (“limit-situations” against which critical pedagogy is a “limit-act”). Paulo was especially oriented to the critical learning possible inside mass movements(“the power not yet in power”), but found himself appointed Secretary of Education for Sao Paulo’s 643 schools when the Workers Party won control of that city administration in 1989. For Paulo, throughout his life and work, the essential questions of this famous book remained: What kind of world do we live in? Why is it like that? What kind of world do we want? How do we get there from here?

2017年4月，美国纽约

April 2017, New York, USA

参考

References

米歇尔·福柯，《社会必须被保卫》。Picador：纽约。David Macey 译，2003 年。

Foucault, Michel, “Society Must Be Defended”. Picador: New York. Translated by David Macey, 2003.

保罗·弗莱雷，《被压迫者教育学》。Continuum：纽约。译者：迈拉·伯格曼·拉莫斯。修订版，20 周年纪念版，1993 年。

Freire, Paulo, Pedagogy of the Oppressed. Continuum: New York. Translated by Myra Bergman Ramos. Rev. 20th Anniversary Edition, 1993.

Kirkendall, Andrew J.，《Paulo Freire 与冷战时期的文化政治》。北卡罗来纳大学出版社：教堂山，2010 年。

Kirkendall, Andrew J., Paulo Freire and the Cold War Politics of Literacy. UNC Press: Chapel Hill, 2010.

当代学者访谈

Interviews with Contemporary Scholars

玛丽娜·阿帕里西奥·巴贝兰

Marina Aparicio Barberán

西班牙保罗弗莱雷研究所

Paulo Freire Institute, Spain

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我是一名政治学家（拥有庞培法布拉大学的本科学位），我的专业是公共和社会政策分析与评估（拥有 UPF-约翰霍普金斯大学和瓦伦西亚-UVEG 的两个硕士学位）。我的研究领域是政策分析、政治和选举行为以及政治和议会精英分析。

I am a political scientist (with an undergraduate degree from Pompeu Fabra University), and I specialize in public and social policy analysis and evaluation (with two master’s degrees from UPF-John Hopkins and Valencia-UVEG). My research areas are policy analysis, political and electoral behavior, and political and parliamentary elites analysis.

您是如何第一次读到弗莱雷的《被压迫者教育学》的？

How did you come to read Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppressed for the first time?

我第一次读到《被压迫者教育学》是在 2006 年；我是 Pep Aparicio Guadas 领导的瓦伦西亚资源与持续教育中心 (CREC-Diputación de Valencia) 的参与者和合作成员 (1999/2013)。在这个中心，我负责出版任务，并承担与我的培训和领域相关的组织和教育职能。与此同时，我继续学习政治学，并参与社会运动中的各种活动。

My first time reading Pedagogy of the Oppressed was in 2006; I was a participant and collaborative member of the Centro de Recursos y Educación Contínua (CREC-Diputación de Valencia) directed by Pep Aparicio Guadas (1999/2013). In this center I conducted publishing tasks and took on organizational and educational functions related to my training and field. At the same time, I continued with my studies in political science, as well as various activities within social movements.

以前，我读过弗莱雷的其他一些作品，但我认为重要的是要注意这本书是如何吸引我的……弗莱雷的分析、文字和表达我们所有人都沉浸其中的不同现实的方式，他的具体化、他的思想、他的洞察力、他的连贯性……我们可以说，像《被压迫者教育学》 、《问题教育学》或《希望教育学》这样的书籍，是塑造阅读世界、书写世界和文字的视角或动力，并将这种视角付诸行动的关键。

Previously, I had read some of Freire’s other works, but I think it is important to note how this book enticed me . . . the analysis, the words and the way Freire articulates the different realities in which we all are immersed, his concretion, his ideas, his clairvoyance, his coherence. . . . We could say that books like Pedagogy of the Oppressed, Pedagogy of the Question, or Pedagogy of Hope have been the key in shaping a perspective or dynamic of reading the world, and also writing the world and the word, and in putting this perspective into action.

您认为保罗·弗莱雷会如何评价他的理论在今天的应用？

What do you think Paulo Freire would say about how his theories are used today?

从我的角度来看，弗莱雷的感受很复杂。一方面，看到他的“乌托邦”、实践和理论、他的生活方式和做事方式在参与主观性和/或意识过程的女性和男性手中在世界和社会中蓬勃发展，我感到很高兴。

From my perspective, Freire would have mixed feelings. On the one hand, the joy of seeing his “utopia”, practices and theories, his way of living and doing having mushroomed in the world and society at the hands of women and men involved in processes of subjectivity and/or awareness.

另一方面，弗莱雷看到他的许多概念在实际驯化中被错误地使用——在大学、政府和社会运动中——会感到有些沮丧。他也会感到有些困惑，因为他看到《被压迫者教育学》中提出的分析和论证有多少可以在当今时代使用。

On the other hand, Freire would have a certain desolation to see the fallacious use of many of his concepts in practical domestication—in universities, governments, and social movements. He also would have a certain perplexity, seeing how much of the analysis and how many of the arguments he included in Pedagogy of the Oppressed could be used in the present time.

您认为今天的弗里尔大学会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean University would look like today?

弗雷雷大学的核心是理论和实践干预的方法论行动，这将导致实践觉醒，促进大学参与和协作的文化，也就是说，我们将在大学里，通过对话和同行之间的持续提问，意识过程将导致解放过程的构建。因此，我们将能够解开我们所有人都内化的那些动力、行动、程序，以走向一个民主、灵活、开放、共同的社会，在那里，我们可以克服作为“主体”所参与的宗派主义，成为有思想的男人、女人和孩子（而不是被压迫的主体）。

A Freirean University would have at its core the methodological action of theoretical and practical intervention, which would lead to an awakened practice and promote a participatory and collaborative culture at the university, that is, we would be at a university where the process of awareness, through dialogue and continued questioning between peers, would lead to the construction of a process of liberation. Thus, we would be able to de-apprehend those dynamics, actions, procedures that we all have internalized in order to move toward a democratic, flexible, open, common society, where we could overcome the sectarianism we are involved in as a “subject” and become thinking men, women, and children (and not oppressed subjects).

如果学生通过阅读 《被压迫者教育学》只学到一件事，你希望那是什么？

If students took just one thing away from reading Pedagogy of the Oppressed what would you hope it would be?

我不能只选择一件事。我会选择对话方法和解放方法，问题构想政治、伦理和教育。我会选择对具体现实的批判性分析。但最重要的是，我会选择这样的主张：阅读世界先于阅读文字，世界和文字都在不断变化，我们始终是这些行动的主角。

I cannot be limited to picking just one thing. I would choose the dialogic method and emancipation method, the problem-conception of politics, ethics, and education. I would choose critical analysis of specific realities. But above all, I would choose the proposal that reading the world precedes reading the word, and both the world and the word are in constant transformation, and we are always main characters in these actions.

诺姆·乔姆斯基

Noam Chomsky

美国麻省理工学院

Massachusetts Institute of Technology, USA

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

语言学、认知科学、哲学。

Linguistics, cognitive science, philosophy.

您认为保罗·弗莱雷会如何评价他的理论在今天的应用？

What do you think Paulo Freire would say about how his theories are used today?

我认为他肯定会对当前的应试教学理论感到震惊。

I think he would be generally appalled by the current teach-to-test doctrines.

您认为今天的弗里勒大学会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean university would look like today?

教学应摒弃将教育视为将水倒入容器中的观念（用启蒙运动中的一句话来说，即弗莱雷的“银行模式”），而应鼓励学生在师生合作的环境中积极寻求理解。在很大程度上，科学教学也是如此，有时在最好的情况下也是如此。

Instruction should reject the notion of education as pouring water into a vessel (in a phrase used in the Enlightenment, Freire’s “banking model”), in favor of engaging students in an active quest for understanding in a faculty-student cooperative environment. To a significant extent something like that is true of science teaching, at its best, sometimes elsewhere.

如果学生通过阅读 《被压迫者教育学》只学到一件事，你希望那是什么？

If students took just one thing away from reading Pedagogy of the Oppressed what would you hope it would be?

他们应该认识到，教育应该是一个自我发现的过程，是一个发展自身能力、以开放和独立的心态追求兴趣和关怀的过程，所有这些都需要与他人合作。

They should recognize that education should be a process of self-discovery, of developing one’s own capacities and pursuing interests and concerns with an open and independent mind, all in cooperation with others.

古斯塔沃·E·菲什曼

Gustavo E. Fischman

美国亚利桑那州立大学

Arizona State University, USA

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我是亚利桑那州立大学玛丽·卢·富尔顿教师学院的教育政策教授，也是 edXchange（知识动员计划）的主任。20 世纪 80 年代初，我在阿根廷开始从事教育工作，成为一名大众教育家，当时我既没有接受过教育学或研究方面的正式培训。当时的大众教育与弗雷雷的理想密切相关，旨在采用非权威但有指导的教学方法，目标是实现社会解放。

I am a professor in educational policy and director of edXchange, the knowledge mobilization initiative at the Mary Lou Fulton Teachers College, Arizona State University. I started to work in education as a popular educator in the early 1980s in Argentina without any formal training in either pedagogy or research. Popular education at that time was closely related to Freirean ideals and was oriented to work in a nonauthoritarian but guided pedagogical approach with the goal of social liberation.

您是如何第一次读到弗莱雷的《被压迫者教育学》的？

How did you come to read Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppressed for the first time?

我第一次听说《被压迫者教育学》时，并不是在邀请我去读，而是在命令我不要去读。1977 年，我 16 岁，在布宜诺斯艾利斯的一所职业学校学习工业化学。我并不特别热衷于政治，但和这个国家的其他人一样，我敏锐地意识到我们生活在一个残酷的独裁统治之下。回想起当时我感到多么困惑，我仍感到愤怒。当时，我高中的校长按照教育部的指导方针张贴通知，宣布只要拥有“不道德和危险读物”清单上的任何一本书，就足以证明其“同情恐怖主义”，并有理由被学校开除。我记得，我当时非常好奇，为什么一本关于教育的书能被列入这一长串“危险”书籍名单。

The first time I heard anything about Pedagogy of the Oppressed was not an invitation to read it, but an order to ignore it. In 1977, I was a 16-year-old studying industrial chemistry in a vocational school in Buenos Aires. I was not particularly politicized, but like everyone else in the country, I was acutely aware that we were living under a brutal dictatorship. It still makes me angry recalling how baffled I felt when the principal at my high school posted notes—following the guidelines of the ministry of education—announcing that the simple possession of any of the books on the list of “immoral and dangerous readings” was evidence of “terrorist sympathies” and reason enough to be expelled from the school. I remember that I became very curious that a book about education made it into this long list of “dangerous” books.

七年后，也就是 1984 年 9 月，我参加了一个大众教育团体，在布宜诺斯艾利斯的一个贫民窟里做成人扫盲项目的志愿者，我的搭档告诉我国际成人教育理事会 (ICAE) 正在寻找志愿者来组织 1985 年的年会。主讲人是保罗·弗莱雷，这是他自阿根廷被禁以来第一次返回阿根廷。我立即自愿加入组织会议的团队，并得到了一本二手的《被压迫者教育学》，开始非正式地学习弗莱雷的所有相关知识。

Seven years later, and in September 1984, I was a member of a popular education group, volunteering in a shanty town in Buenos Aires for an adult literacy project, when my partner told me the International Council of Adult Education (ICAE) was looking for volunteers to organize their 1985 annual meeting. The keynote speaker was Paulo Freire, who was returning to Argentina for the first time since his books were banned in the country. I immediately volunteered to be part of the team that was organizing the meeting, and I got a used copy of Pedagogy of the Oppressed and began my informal education of all things Freirean.

您认为今天的弗里勒大学会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean university would look like today?

遵循弗莱雷“简单而不简单”的格言，弗莱雷大学应该具备三个关键的定义特征。首先，它应该被构建为一种致力于自由、公平、包容和团结原则的解放教育学。解放教育学将涉及好奇、严谨和实用的教学、服务和研究议程。其次，学生、教师和管理人员应该像他们的社会一样多样化。多样性有两种不同但相关的意义：服务于社会的不同部门和所有社会群体，以及思想和取向的多样性。第三，弗莱雷大学将被组织为民主参与治理的实验室。

Following Freire’s dictum of being simple without being simplistic, a Freirean university should have three key defining characteristics. First, it should be structured to implement a pedagogy of liberation committed to the principles of freedom, equity, inclusivity, and solidarity. A pedagogy of liberation will engage in curious, rigorous, and usable teaching, service, and research agendas. Second, the students, faculty, and administration should be as diverse as their societies. Diversity in two different but related senses: serving diverse sectors and all social groups of a society as well as diversity of ideas and orientations. Third, a Freirean university will be organized as a laboratory of democratic participatory governing.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对教育学产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on pedagogy?

我认为弗雷雷著作的最大影响在于，它证明了民主教育的短暂体验——在单个教室、在校内或校外、与儿童或成人一起——都值得追求。这些体验教会我们，作为教育者和学习者，我们不仅要对自己抱有更高的期望，还要将个人和社会行动与平等和团结的目标联系起来。

I think the biggest impact of Freire’s work is that it has demonstrated how even short-lived experiences of democratic schooling—in a single classroom, in or outside schools, with children or adults—are worth pursuing. These experiences teach us to not only expect more from ourselves as educators and learners but also link individual and social actions with the goals of equality and solidarity.

拉蒙·弗莱查

Ramón Flecha

西班牙巴塞罗那大学

University of Barcelona, Spain

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我致力于科学研究，寻求智力和人类的卓越，重点是确定解决不同社会领域不平等问题的行动：种族和少数民族群体；性别问题，特别是在男性研究领域；教育；以及经济，特别关注成功克服收入不平等的组织等。换句话说，我从来没有对不平等本身的分析感兴趣，因为我认为这种分析只会使进行分析的人受益。相反，我对积极克服不平等的人类行为的分析很感兴趣，这是弗莱雷非常欣赏的。

I am devoted to scientific research in search of both intellectual and human excellence, focusing on the identification of actions that tackle inequalities in different social fields: ethnic and minority groups; gender issues, especially in the field of masculinity studies; education; and economy, specifically focusing on organizations that are successful in overcoming income inequalities, etc. In other words, I have never been interested in the analysis of inequality by itself because I think such analysis benefits only the people who develop it. Rather, I am interested in the analysis of human actions that are actively overcoming inequalities, something that Freire appreciated very much.

您认为保罗·弗莱雷会如何评价他的理论在今天的应用？

What do you think Paulo Freire would say about how his theories are used today?

我不知道弗莱雷会怎么想，但我可以说弗莱雷有很强的直觉，总是走在时代的前面。1969 年，他通过《被压迫者教育学》发展了一种对话行动理论，而这一理论直到 12 年后，即 1981 年，哈贝马斯的交往行动理论才进入社会科学领域。弗莱雷所定义的对话行动或对话视角是当今社会科学的趋势，包括经济学、社会学、人类学和政治学领域。我认为，弗莱雷会很高兴看到当今的社会科学如何与他在 20 世纪 60 年代预见的对话视角保持一致。

I do not know what Freire would think, but what I can say is that Freire had great intuition and was always ahead of his time. In 1969, with Pedagogy of the Oppressed, he had already developed a theory of dialogic action, which did not arrive in the social sciences until 1981, 12 years later, with Habermas’s Theory of Communicative Action. What Freire defined as dialogic action, or dialogic perspective, is the current trend in social sciences, in the field of economics, sociology, anthropology, and political science. I think Freire would be satisfied to see how the social sciences today are in line with the dialogic perspective that he foresaw in the 1960s.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对研究产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on research?

我认为弗莱雷的工作对研究产生了极为积极的影响。对话视角有助于表明，有必要与研究对象展开对话。然而，这种对话的意义，即对话对弗莱雷的意义，往往没有得到很好的理解。研究应该与研究的最终用户进行真正的对话。尽管研究对象可能是一个每天从事 8 小时家庭清洁工作的人，但研究人员的报酬是阅读和研究科学知识。不幸的是，有些人只理解了“去与研究对象对话”这一部分，而没有做其他工作，没有像弗莱雷那样努力工作，没有阅读适用的社会科学文献，以便他们能够在与最终用户的对话中运用这些知识。

I think the impact of Freire’s work on research has been extremely positive. The dialogic perspective helped show that it is necessary to open a dialogue with the people who are the object of study. What happens is that the meaning of this dialogue, what dialogue meant to Freire, has often not been well understood. Research should be truly dialogic with the end-users of a given study. Although the subject may be a person working 8 hours a day in domestic cleaning, the researcher is being paid to read and study the scientific knowledge. Unfortunately, some people have understood only the “go and dialogue with the subjects” part, without doing the rest of their job, without working hard like Freire did, without reading the applicable social sciences literature so that they can use that knowledge in the dialogue with the end-users.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对教育学产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on pedagogy?

坦白说，弗莱雷的著作在全世界产生了令人印象深刻的影响。弗莱雷可能是教育领域最具影响力的学者。问题是，这种影响并不总是能影响到教育实践。例如，在大学里，许多人宣称自己是弗莱雷主义者，但他们并没有帮助改变学校的实际情况或教育实践，使其符合弗莱雷的指导方针。

Honestly, Freire’s work has had an impressive impact worldwide. Freire is possibly the most influential scholar in education. The problem is that this influence has not always reached educational practice. For example, in universities, many people declare themselves as being Freirean, but they are not helping transform the actual conditions of the schools or the educational practices to be in line with Freirean guidelines.

如果学生通过阅读 《被压迫者教育学》只学到一件事，你希望那是什么？

If students took just one thing away from reading Pedagogy of the Oppressed what would you hope it would be?

我尤其希望学生们能够优先考虑大多数教育体系所忽视的一点，即所有儿童接受教育的权利。很多时候，决策是基于与改善所有儿童的教育成果相去甚远的理由做出的。教育专业的学生必须接受这种道德和人道承诺；这将是他们真正的专业任务。

I especially wish students would prioritize something that is forgotten in most educational systems, which is the right to education for all children. Very often, decisions are made based on reasons that are very far from the improvement of educational outcomes of all children. It is critical that students in education embrace this ethical and human commitment; this will be their real professional task.

罗纳德·戴维·格拉斯

Ronald David Glass

美国加州大学圣克鲁斯分校

University of California, Santa Cruz, USA

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我是一位激进的教育哲学家，我的工作源于争取正义的斗争。我领导着加州大学公平加州合作研究中心，我们与受害社区合作解决经济、就业、教育、住房、食品系统、公共卫生和环境等问题。我还领导了一个研究社会科学研究中的道德问题的项目。

I am a radical philosopher of education whose work emanates from and within struggles for justice. I direct the UC Center for Collaborative Research for an Equitable California, and we partner with aggrieved communities to address issues in the economy, employment, education, housing, food systems, public health, and the environment. I also head a project that investigates the ethical issues in social science research.

您认为保罗·弗莱雷会如何评价他的理论在今天的应用？

What do you think Paulo Freire would say about how his theories are used today?

1984 年，我有幸与保罗·弗莱雷 (Paulo Freire) 进行了深入交流，当时他与我同住一个月，并参与了成人教育发展项目的社会正义运动建设活动。我们详细讨论了他的理论在不同国家的不同领域是如何被采用的。他同意我的观点，即美国学校中许多以弗莱雷的理论为基础的“批判性教育学”实际上是对他思想激进基础的驯化，尽管它建立了一种更人性化的学校教育形式。教育作为一种自由实践，必然会与改变世界的实际努力和斗争相结合，也改变我们自己的内在自我（因为世界的压迫存在于我们身上，也存在于日常生活的结构和过程中）。但弗莱雷并不是一个纯粹主义者，无论是理论还是实践。他致力于在可以创造的任何开放空间中做任何可以做的事情，所以他会很高兴全世界的人们都能找到他的理论在他们各自的特定背景下以各自的方式发挥作用，推动了争取正义的斗争向前发展。

I had the great good fortune and honor of working in depth with Paulo Freire in 1984, when he lived with me for a month and collaborated in the social justice movement-building activities of the Adult Education Development Project. We discussed at length how his theory was being taken up in different sectors in different countries. He agreed with me that much of the “critical pedagogy” that takes place in US schools and claims Freire’s theory as its basis is in truth a domestication of the radical foundation of his ideas, even as it establishes a more humane form of schooling. Education as a practice of freedom is necessarily geared into actual efforts and struggles to transform the world, and to transform our own inner selves as well (since the oppressions of the world reside in us as well as in the structures and processes of everyday life). But Freire was not a purist, in terms of either theory or practice. He was committed to doing whatever could be done in whatever open spaces could be created, so he would be happy that people the world over have found his theory useful in their own ways, in their own particular context, to move the struggle for justice forward.

您认为今天的弗里勒大学会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean university would look like today?

一所以弗莱雷理论为基础的大学将致力于解决最紧迫的社会、经济和政治不平等问题。它将从最受屈辱的群体的需求中确定其研究议程的方向。它将承认知识主张和知识生产的伦理和政治层面。它将尊重多种认知方式。它将承认学者及其学科和大学本身都受到压迫和剥削的历史和意识形态的污染。它更关心的不是对专家的资格认证，而是激发好奇心、严谨的批判性探究习惯和为正义而奋斗的终身承诺。

A university based in Freire’s theory would be organized to address the most pressing social, economic, and political inequities. It would take direction for its research agenda from the needs of the most aggrieved communities. It would recognize the ethical and political dimensions of knowledge claims and knowledge production. It would honor multiple modalities of knowing. It would acknowledge that scholars and their disciplines and universities are themselves tainted by histories and ideologies of oppression and exploitation. It would be less concerned with credentialing experts than it would be concerned with animating curiosity, habits of disciplined critical inquiry, and a lifetime commitment to the struggle for justice.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对教育学产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on pedagogy?

我认为，在美国，弗莱雷的著作对学校教学的影响有限。我认为他的理论主要被用作一种道德或政治标志，表明教师有意尊重学生的背景经历。这通常是通过（通常有些肤浅的）对《被压迫者教育学》第 2 章的参与来实现的，该章对灌输式教育和对话式或问题式教育进行了著名的对比。这种驯化的批判性教学法当然更人性化，为学生的发言和兴趣提供了更多的空间，并与公立学校的主流教学话语和实践形成了对比。然而，这只是该理论的一个非常有限的体现。有些教师，例如社会正义教师组织的教师，已经发展出更强有力的理论体现，并正在寻找将课堂学习与寻求影响社区变革的更大运动联系起来的方法。弗莱雷的理论已在运动建设中被用作教学，在这里它找到了更强大的表达形式，特别是在拉丁美洲。

I think, in the United States, Freire’s work has had limited impact on pedagogy in schools. I see his theory primarily invoked as an ethical or political marker, as an indication of a teacher’s intent to honor the background experiences of students. This is usually done through an (often somewhat superficial) engagement with Chapter 2 of ­Pedagogy of the Oppressed and its famous contrast between banking and dialogical or problem-posing education. This domesticated critical pedagogy certainly is more humane, provides more space for student voice and interests, and offers a counterposition to the dominant discourse and practice of pedagogy in public schools. However, this is a very limited embodiment of the theory. It is the case that some teachers, such as those organized in Teachers for Social Justice, have developed more robust embodiments of the theory, and are looking for ways to link classroom learning to larger movements seeking to effect change in the community. Freire’s theory has been used pedagogically within movement building, and here it has found much stronger forms of expression, particularly in Latin America.

瓦莱丽·金洛克

Valerie Kinloch

美国匹兹堡大学

University of Pittsburgh, USA

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我是匹兹堡大学教育学院的 Renée and Richard Goldman 院长，我与同事合作开展重要的地方、国家和全球教育计划。在被任命为院长之前，我是俄亥俄州立大学的读写研究教授和副院长，在那里我推动了教育多样性和包容性、国际教育伙伴关系以及学校和社区参与方面的举措。我的研究考察了学校内外年轻人和成年人的读写能力和社区参与。我是种族、地点、读写能力和多样性出版物的作者，目前正在从事相关研究和参与计划。

I am the Renée and Richard Goldman Dean of the School of Education at the University of Pittsburgh, where I collaborate with colleagues on important local, national, and global educational initiatives. Before being named dean, I was professor of Literacy Studies and associate dean at Ohio State University, where I facilitated initiatives on diversity and inclusion in education, international educational partnerships, and school and community engagement. My research examines the literacies and community engagements of young people and adults inside and outside schools. I am the author of publications on race, place, literacy, and diversity, and I am currently working on related research and engagement initiatives.

您是如何第一次读到弗莱雷的《被压迫者教育学》的？

How did you come to read Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppressed for the first time?

我在约翰逊·C·史密斯大学读英语专业本科时“发现”了弗莱雷的《被压迫者教育学》。我记得我曾无数次与朋友和一些教授谈论黑人文学、黑人生活、压迫以及语言和读写能力的力量，这促使我继续我的旅程，阅读黑人作家和学者的各种文本。在其中一篇文本中，我提出了“阅读文字和世界”的想法，当我搜索这个短语的含义时，保罗·弗莱雷的名字和书就出现了。于是，我读了《被压迫者教育学》，爱上了他对批判意识以及教师、学生和世界之间应该发生的联系的讨论。

I “discovered” Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppressed when I was an undergraduate student majoring in English at Johnson C. Smith University. I recall having countless conversations with my friends and some of my professors about black literature, black lives, oppression, and the power of language and literacy, and I was moved to continue on my journey to read various texts by black authors and scholars. In one of those texts, the idea of “reading the word and the world” was presented to me, and when I searched for the meaning of the phrase, Paulo Freire’s name and book came up. So, I read Pedagogy of the Oppressed and fell in love with his discussion of critical consciousness and connections that should happen among teachers, students, and the world.

您认为今天的弗里勒大学会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean university would look like today?

我认为它将包括开放的空间，让人们与他人交流，分析世界上正在发生的事件，研究如何对抗压迫和不平等，消除种族主义、阶级主义、性别歧视、不平等和资本主义。它将是免费的！对所有人开放。它将以创造和加强我们与批判意识、与他人合作、为必要的社会政治变革而努力以及超越自我思考相关的立场、倾向和意识形态的需求为指导。它将是一个人性化、文化丰富的学术空间。

I think it would include open spaces for people to engage with others, to analyze events going on in the world, to examine ways to combat oppression and inequity, to dismantle racism, classism, sexism, inequality, and capitalism. It would be free! Open to everyone. It would be guided by the need to create and enhance our stances, dispositions, and ideologies related to critical consciousness, collaborating with others, working for necessary sociopolitical change, and thinking beyond the self. It would be a humanizing, culturally rich academic space.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对研究产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on research?

时至今日，弗莱雷仍在敦促学者们思考身份和地点在教育讨论中需要以何种复杂方式加以细致处理；他鼓励我们采取批判性视角，尤其是在与社区环境中的其他人合作时，因为我们试图解决有关不平等的普遍问题。他还将研究置于日常生活的范围内——人们的日常现实、生活、生活条件、挣扎和希望——以使研究能够为与我们一起工作和在研究中写作的人所接受。因此，研究不仅仅是发表文章和书籍，而是要写出新的生存方式，从根本上改变世界，使之变得更好。

To this day, Freire continues to push scholars to consider the complicated ways identities and locations need to be nuanced in discussions about education; he encourages us to take a critical perspective, especially when collaborating with other people in community contexts, as we attempt to address pervasive questions about inequality. He also situates research within the reach of the everyday—the everyday realities, lives, lived conditions, struggles, and hope of people—to make research accessible to who we are working with and writing with/about in our research. Thus, research is not singularly about publishing articles and books, but about writing new ways of being into existence that can, fundamentally, change the world for the better.

如果学生通过阅读 《被压迫者教育学》只学到一件事，你希望那是什么？

If students took just one thing away from reading Pedagogy of the Oppressed what would you hope it would be?

我希望是这样的：弗莱雷（1971）坚持认为，我们应该努力消除压迫制度，“以便学生能够成为‘为自己而存在的人’”，而不是强迫学生“‘融入’压迫结构”（第 55 页）。我认为他对改变压迫系统的关注指向了所有系统——学校、大学和我们在特定环境中生活的政治系统。这也表明我们需要团结一致，共同革命和改变世界。

I hope it would be this: Freire’s (1971) insistence that we work to eradicate systems of oppression “so that [students] can become ‘beings for themselves’” as opposed to students being forced to “‘integrate’ into the structure of oppression” (p. 55). I believe his focus on transforming systems of oppression points to all systems—schools, universities, and political systems that we live under in our specific contexts. It also speaks to the need for us to work in solidarity to revolutionize and transform the world.

彼得·梅奥

Peter Mayo

马耳他大学，马耳他

University of Malta, Malta

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我在马耳他长大，在那里做了几年兼职记者，之后在加拿大阿尔伯塔大学和安大略教育学院/多伦多大学攻读研究生，然后从事教学工作，最后从事学术工作。我的专业是教育社会学，侧重于成人教育，还参与了大学外联项目，开发了以问题和纪念活动为基础的项目，这些项目能够激发社区成员的想象力，从而扎根于大众的意识。

I was brought up in Malta where I worked as a part-time journalist for a few years, then took up teaching and eventually the academic life after having pursued postgraduate studies at the University of Alberta and OISE/University of Toronto in Canada. I specialize in Sociology of Education with a focus on Adult Education and have also been involved in university outreach developing projects that have their basis in issues and commemorations that capture community members’ imagination and are therefore rooted in popular consciousness.

您是如何第一次读到弗莱雷的《被压迫者教育学》的？

How did you come to read Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppressed for the first time?

在我刚开始在艾伯塔省埃德蒙顿进行研究生学习时，我有机会阅读《被压迫者教育学》，这本书确实让我大开眼界。它似乎包含了许多见解和元素，让我能够理解我之前在马耳他的教学背景。这些包括下属地位、殖民遗产、相对贫困、阶级问题（包括语言问题）和种族主义问题（当时我们学校有非裔马耳他学生，而马耳他社会远没有像近代那样成为多民族社会）。

The occasion for reading Pedagogy of the Oppressed presented itself at the start of my graduate studies in Edmonton, Alberta and the book certainly proved a revelation to me. It seemed to contain many of the insights and elements necessary for me to understand the context in which my previous teaching in Malta had taken place. These included subalterneity, colonial legacies, relative poverty, class issues (including language issues), and issues concerning racism (there were African-Maltese students in our school at a time when Maltese society was nowhere near the multiethnic society it has become in recent times).

您认为今天的弗里勒大学会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean university would look like today?

它将把学校及其提供的教育视为公共物品，而不是消费品。它将社区参与是重中之重。学习的起点是学生的生存状况，知识来源于社区内研究和出现的主题综合体。授课的传播模式将被共同研究所取代，讲师、学生和社区成员参与其中，讨论以激发“认识论好奇心”的方式提出的问题，并成为集体探究的对象。

It would be one wherein the institution and the education it provides are conceived of as public goods, not consumption goods. It would be one where engagement with the community would be given central importance. It would be one where the starting point for learning is the students’ existential situation with knowledge deriving from thematic complexes researched within and emerging from the community. It would be one in which the transmission model of lecturing is replaced by co-investigation, involving lecturers, students and community members, debating issues which are raised in a manner that arouses “epistemological curiosity” and becomes the object of collective enquiry.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对研究产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on research?

弗雷雷对研究的最大影响体现在参与式行动研究方法中，这是一种集体研究形式，在这种研究中，社区成员得到帮助，研究影响他们自己和周围生活的问题。我认为，弗雷雷在研究伦理方面有很多值得我们借鉴的地方，以及那些生活和问题被研究的人在多大程度上真正参与了研究议程和研究过程的确定。他们将从整个研究过程及其结果的共同所有权中受益。这一研究过程和结果应该有助于改善他们的生活方式。这是一种致力于价值的努力，它肯定了研究的选择和目的，符合知识和研究并非中立的观点。简而言之，这种研究不仅是为了解释世界，而且主要是为改变世界做出贡献。

The greatest Freirean impact on research can be felt in that approach known as Participatory Action Research, a collective form of research where community members are assisted in researching issues that affect their own and surrounding lives. I would argue that Freire has a lot to tell us about the ethics of research and the extent to which those whose lives and issues are being examined are genuinely involved in determining the research agenda and research process. They would benefit from co-ownership of the entire research process and its outcomes. This research process and outcome should serve to improve their ways of life. It is a value-committed effort which affirms the choice and purposes of research in line with the view that knowledge and research are not neutral. In short it is research geared not simply to interpret the world but primarily to contribute toward changing it.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对教育学产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on pedagogy?

弗莱雷激励了许多人摆脱等级森严的教学模式，转而采用更加民主的方法，这种方法建立在教师的民主权威之上，不会沦为独裁主义。他还激励了教育工作者承认教育和知识的政治性，避免任何中立的伪装，最重要的是，他强调学习的集体维度，以及需要从学习者的生存状况出发，克服他们的各种差异，走向更高层次的学习和知识。

Freire has inspired many to move away from a hierarchical, magisterial mode of teaching and learning to a more democratic approach, an approach built on the teacher’s democratic authority which does not degenerate into authoritarianism. He has also inspired educators to recognize the politics of education and knowledge, to eschew any pretense of neutrality, and most important of all, he has emphasized the collective dimensions of learning and the need to start from the learners’ existential situations, with all their differences, and move to higher orders of learning and knowledge.

彼得·麦克拉伦

Peter McLaren

美国查普曼大学

Chapman University, USA

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我曾在多伦多的简芬奇走廊担任小学教师，这是加拿大一个以高犯罪率而闻名的公共住房区。我因成功教授工薪阶层移民而赢得了来之不易的声誉。

I served as an elementary school teacher in Toronto’s Jane-Finch Corridor, a public housing district in Canada known for its high rate of crime. I earned a hard-won reputation for successfully teaching working class immigrants.

随后，我申请并被多伦多大学录取攻读教育学博士学位。在此期间，我出版了自己在小学任教期间写的日记。我将这本书命名为《走廊里的哭声》，1980 年，它成为加拿大的畅销书。在完成了艰苦的全国巡回图书活动后，我开始自我批评，因为《走廊里的哭声》严重缺乏理论框架，无法帮助读者理解我课堂上学生所经历的暴力和疏离。几十年来，进步和激进的教育家们都对全国范围内严肃对待教育改革的努力感到不满，他们用一种低劣的借口来严肃地挑战教育在资本主义国家权力和特权不对称关系的再生产中所扮演的角色，我担心我的书不足以加深对资本主义学校教育的理解。为了弥补教育官员刻意的冷漠以及我理论重心不够发达的问题，我开始阅读跨学科书籍，将我早期对乔叟、贝奥武甫、莎士比亚和布莱克的兴趣转向知识社会学、人类学、批判理论和符号学。我花时间旁听米歇尔·福柯、翁贝托·埃科、埃内斯托·拉克劳和其他来访知识分子的课程。我终于在 1984 年获得了博士学位，但仍然觉得还有很多东西要学。

I subsequently applied for and was accepted into a PhD program in education at the University of Toronto, during which time I published the diary I had kept as an elementary school teacher. I called it Cries from the Corridor and it became a Canadian best-seller in 1980. After I had finished a grueling national book tour, I was already growing self-critical about the fact that Cries from the Corridor was woefully absent of a theoretical framework that could help readers understand the violence and alienation experienced by students in my classroom. Progressive and radial educators alike had for decades winced in gut churning unison at the tellingly restrained efforts to take seriously educational reform throughout the country, establishing a bog-standard evasion for challenging seriously the role that education plays in the reproduction of the asymmetrical relations of power and privilege of the capitalist state and I feared that my book was not sufficiently helpful in deepening an understanding of capitalist schooling. To remedy both the calculated indifference of educational officials as well as my insufficiently developed theoretical center of gravity, I began to read across disciplines, shifting my early interest in Chaucer, Beowulf, Shakespeare and Blake towards an incorporation of the sociology of knowledge, anthropology, critical theory, and semiotics. I took the time to audit courses with Michel Foucault, Umberto Eco, Ernesto Laclau and other visiting intellectuals. I finally graduated with my doctorate in 1984, still feeling that there was so much to learn.

我的博士论文以书籍形式出版，书名为《学校教育作为一种仪式表演》，令我兴奋不已的是，亨利·吉鲁教授同意为我写序言。亨利成为了我的导师，并邀请我到俄亥俄州迈阿密大学与他一起担任教授。亨利把我介绍给他最好的朋友之一唐纳多·马塞多，从他那里我了解到了很多关于保罗·弗莱雷及其作品的知识。亨利安排我在 1985 年与保罗见面，我很惊讶——不，很震惊——得知保罗已经熟悉了我的作品。事实上，他称我为他的“知识表亲”，是他教育家庭的一员。在随后的几年里，他慷慨地为我的两本书写了序言，并为第三本书写了推荐信。在随后的几年里，直到他去世，他一直对我和我正在进行的在北美——后来主要是拉丁美洲和亚洲——背景下发展批判性教育学的项目表现出深切的关怀。

My doctoral dissertation was published as a book, Schooling as a Ritual Performance, and to my great excitement Professor Henry Giroux agreed to write the Preface. Henry became a mentor to me and invited me to join him at Miami University of Ohio as a fellow professor. Henry introduced me to one of his best friends, Donaldo Macedo, from whom I learned a great deal about Paulo Freire and his work. Henry arranged for me to meet Paulo in 1985 and I was surprised—no, shocked—to learn that Paulo was already familiar with my work. In fact, he would refer to me as his “intellectual cousin” and a part of his pedagogical family. In the ensuing years he was gracious enough to write prefaces for two of my books and an endorsement for a third. In subsequent years until his death he exhibited a soulful kindness toward me and my ongoing project of developing critical pedagogy in North American—and later primarily Latin American and Asian—contexts.

您是如何第一次读到弗莱雷的《受压迫者教育学》的？

How did you come to read Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppres sed for the first time?

我在多伦多读博士时读过《被压迫者教育学》。这本书不在我的必读书目中，但我的左翼朋友说这是必读之作，所以我和当时正在阅读的其他教育家、社会和政治理论家一起读了这本书。保罗的作品与我作为学生和教育家的生活经历息息相关，这一点非常突出。它帮助我加深了对实践的理解，以及参与社会斗争的必要性，然后我又回到理论和哲学著作中去澄清问题，加深我对这些经历的理解。

I read Pedagogy of the Oppressed while a doctoral student in Toronto. It was not on any required reading lists in my classes but friends of mine on the left pronounced it as a must-read work so I read it in conjunction with other educators and social and political theorists that I was reading at the time. Paulo’s work stood out for its relevance to my own life experiences both as a student and as an educator, dramatically so. It helped to sharpen my understanding of praxis, and the necessity for engaging in social struggles and then returning to theoretical and philosophical works for clarification and for deepening my understanding of those experiences.

您认为保罗·弗莱雷会如何评价他的理论在当今的运用？

What do you think Paulo Freire would say about how his theories are used today?

我认为，保罗，尽管非常谦逊，也会感激他的作品对如此多领域产生了如此强大的影响，并成为治疗普遍存在的社会和政治健忘症以及有动机的遗忘症的强大解毒剂。围绕着所有社会的根本暴力。但我也相信，他会批判那些自称是弗雷雷式的教育方法，这些方法驯化了他的工作，从其基础中吸取了一种批判资本主义的激进政治，当然可以称之为社会主义。

I think Paulo, in all of his great humility, would be appreciative that his work has made such a powerful impact on so many fields and that it has become such a powerful antidote to prevailing forms of social and polictical amnesia and to the motivated forget fulness that surrounds the foundational violence of all societies. But I also believe that he would be critical of approaches in education that claimed to be Freirean but which domesticated his work, leeching from its foundations a radical politics that was critical of capitalism and which could certainly be called socialist.

您认为如今的弗雷勒大学将会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean university would look like today?

北美背景下的弗雷雷大学将以消除与性、年龄、物种、性别、白人至上主义和权力殖民性相关的经济不平等和社会压迫关系为中心，所有这些都以不同的方式与资本的不平等所有权和资本主义价值生产本身以及伴随而来的剥削、异化和抽象逻辑相关。资本的不平等所有权不能通过新古典经济学概念模型中的更高增长率来补救，而只能通过社会主义替代方案超越资本主义。弗雷雷大学将致力于重建公共部门、使工作场所民主化、建立致力于参与和直接民主模式的社区委员会、消除种族、阶级和性别对立、创造一种超越私有财产的革命批判人文主义，并致力于创建由积极参与的学习者和自由结社的劳动者组成的社区，致力于为真正的全球公共利益而工作。

A Freirean university in the North American context would be centered around the elimination of economic inequality and social relations of oppression related to sexuality, age, species, gender, white supremacy, and the coloniality of power, all of which are related in different ways to the unequal ownership of capital and to capitalist value production itself and the exploitation, alienation, and logic of abstraction that accompanies it. The unequal ownership of capital cannot be remedied by higher growth rates within the conceptual models of neoclassical economics but only by transcending capitalism through a socialist alternative. The Freirean University will be about rebuilding public sectors, democratizing the workplace, establishing communal councils that are committed to models of participatory and direct democracy, eliminating race, class and gender antagonisms, creating a revolutionary critical humanism that transcends private property and that is committed to creating communities of engaged learners and Freely associated laborers dedicated to working in the interests of a truly global commons.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对研究产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on research?

弗莱雷的作品对批判教育学领域的起源和持续发展产生了极为重大的影响。批判教育学由与弗莱雷的作品和更普遍的批判社会理论相关的一套理论构成，这些理论强调实践。批判教育学领域最近扩大了其范围，包括革命性批判教育学，这是通过发展一种批判教育学来恢复弗莱雷的马克思主义认识论根源的尝试。实践哲学主要受到马克思、黑格尔和人文主义哲学家的著作的推动。弗莱雷的研究涉及神学、读写能力、作文研究、文学研究、应用语言学、社会学、人类学和政治哲学等领域。他的著作对如此多的研究领域进行了交叉研究，证明了其跨学科范围，为真正的去殖民化的希望和自我教育以及社会转型服务。

Freire’s work has had a strikingly significant impact on the genesis and ongoing development of the field of critical pedagogy. Critical pedagogy is constituted by a body of theory associated with Freire’s work and critical social theory more generally that emphasizes praxis. The field of critical pedagogy has recently expanded its purview to include revolutionary critical pedagogy, an attempt to reclaim Freire’s Marxist epistemological roots through the development of a philosophy of praxis driven primarily by the work of Marx Hegel and humanist philosophers. Freire’s research has been felt in the fields of theology, literacy, composition studies, literary studies, applied linguistics, sociology, anthropology, and political philosophy. That his work has cross-fertilized so many areas of research is a testament to its transdisciplinary reach in the service of a truly decolonial pedagogy of hope and self and social transformation.

如果学生通过阅读 《被压迫者教育学》只学到一件事，你希望那是什么？

If students took just one thing away from reading Pedagogy of the Oppressed what would you hope it would be?

他们不仅仅从阅读保罗·弗莱雷的作品中得到一点收获，而且还会意识到他们的日常生活始终具有教育意义，而这些教育意义反过来也是政治意义，它挑战了我们对穷人、贫困者和一无所有者的义务，提高了我们的人类学和认识论的清晰度，挑战了我们建设一个更美好世界、摆脱不必要的异化和人类苦难的承诺。

It would be that they would never just take one thing away from reading Paulo Freire but realize that their everyday lives always have pedagogical dimensions to them, and those pedagogical dimensions are, in turn and at one and the same time, political dimensions that challenge our obligation to the poor, the immiserated, and the dispossessed, that sharpen our antological and epistemological clarity and that challenge our commitment to building a better world, free from unnecessary alienation and human suffering.

玛戈·冈泽·雷伊

Margo Okazawa-Rey

美国旧金山州立大学、美国菲尔丁研究生大学

San Francisco State University, USA and Fielding Graduate University, USA

请告诉我们您的背景和当前的专业领域。

Please tell us about your background and current areas of expertise.

我的主要工作领域——教学、研究和行动——关注军国主义、武装冲突和针对妇女的暴力行为。我研究了军国主义、经济全球化与生活和工作在美国军事基地周围的韩国当地和移民妇女的影响之间的联系。我与尼日尔三角洲地区、加纳、塞拉利昂和利比里亚的女性活动家一起举办了女权主义活动家研究方法培训课程。我在社区环境中使用通俗教育来举办反种族主义和多元文化研讨会，并在本科和研究生课程中加以运用。

My primary areas of work—teaching, research, and activism—focus on militarism, armed conflict, and violence against women. I have examined the connections between militarism, economic globalization, and impacts on local and migrant women in South Korea who live and work around US military bases. I have conducted feminist activist research methodology training sessions with women activists in the Niger Delta region, Ghana, Sierra Leone, and Liberia. I use popular education in community settings to conduct antiracist and multicultural workshops and in my undergraduate and graduate courses.

您是如何第一次读到弗莱雷的《被压迫者教育学》的？

How did you come to read Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppressed for the first time?

20 世纪 70 年代末，美国波士顿的一小群女权主义活动家开始一起阅读和学习《被压迫者教育学》，努力理解和创造激进的方法论，以实践、理解和教授女权主义口号“个人即政治”。还有什么比从弗莱雷那里学到的思想更好的方法呢？我们之前没有意识到，女权主义意识提升团体是基于弗莱雷的作品，或者至少在不知不觉中与他的作品有关。他的文字很浮夸，我们有时会受到“他”、“他”和“男人”等男性主义语言的挑战。尽管如此，我们还是坚持了下来——这对我们有很大的好处。

In the late 1970s, a small group of feminist activists in Boston, USA began to read and learn from Pedagogy of the Oppressed together, striving to understand and create radical methodologies for living, understanding, and teaching the feminist slogan, “the personal is political.” What better way than through ideas we learned from Freire? We did not realize before that the feminist consciousness-raising groups were based on, or at least unknowingly related to, his work. The writing was turgid and we were sometimes challenged by masculinist language of “he,” “him,” and “men.” Nonetheless, we carried on—to our enormous benefit.

您认为保罗·弗莱雷会如何评价他的理论在今天的应用？

What do you think Paulo Freire would say about how his theories are used today?

20 世纪 80 年代，我有幸与弗莱雷亲自会面，他的朴实无华和朴实无华令我印象深刻。因此，我相信，他一定会惊喜地发现，他的作品被世界各地的众多教育工作者广泛使用。他还会对一些关键思想的扭曲和贬低深感担忧和沮丧，比如从学生的经验出发——阅读世界以阅读文字——到“以学习者为中心”等技术官僚概念，这些概念的意思是“你们学生可以对学习的内容发表一些意见，但我们老师仍然控制着课程。”也许更重要的是，在面向小学、中学和大学的公共教育中，随着学习和教学环境日益机械化，弗莱雷一贯阐述和重新阐述的教育解放目的已被抛在一边。

I had the honor of meeting Freire in person in the 1980s and was struck by his unpretentiousness, his simplicity. So, I believe he would be surprised, pleasantly, by the extensive use of his work by a range of educators around the world. He also would be seriously concerned and dismayed by the distortion and debasement of key ideas like starting from students’ experiences—reading the world to read the word—to technocratic concepts like “learner-centered” that have come to mean “you students can have some say in what you learn but we teachers still control the curriculum.” Perhaps more important, the liberatory purpose of education that Freire so consistently articulated and rearticulated has been left to one side on the way to increasingly mechanized learning and teaching contexts in public education for primary, secondary, and tertiary students.

弗莱雷会真正高兴地看到，他的作品能够在与他开始的地方相似的地方得到传播——世界各地的农村地区，包括像美国这样的“发达”国家——那里的农民和工人阶级，无论有没有读写能力，都在学习分析、理解和改变压迫和边缘化他们的条件。

Freire would delight truly at the uptake of his work in places similar to where he began—rural areas of the world including in “developed” countries like the United States—where peasants and working-class folk with and without literacy skills are learning to analyze, understand, and change the conditions that oppress and marginalize them.

您认为今天的弗里勒大学会是什么样子？

What do you think a Freirean university would look like today?

如今，“弗雷雷大学”一词将成为一个矛盾词。无论大学名称如何变化，席卷大多数大学的新自由主义和保守主义力量都将造成目前同样的伤害。能够忠实地应用和推进弗雷雷著作的最激进的教育环境将是非正式环境，我称之为“自由空间”，包括激进运动，以及大学等正式环境，在那里，我们可以一起学习和教学，面对如此沉重和可怕地塑造我们生活的物质和社会条件，并认识到我们共同的命运、被压迫者和压迫者、支配者和从属者、发声者和沉默者和被压制者。

“Freirean University” would be an oxymoron today. The forces of neoliberalism and conservatism that have engulfed most universities would result in the same harm being inflicted currently, irrespective of a name change. The most radical educational settings that could faithfully apply and advance Freire’s work would be in informal settings, what I refer to as “free spaces,” including activist movements, and within formal settings like universities, where we could learn and teach together as we face material and social conditions that are so heavily and horrifically shaping our lives and recognize our shared destinies, oppressed and oppressor, dominant and subordinate, the vocal and the silent and silenced.

您能否描述一下您认为弗莱雷的作品对研究产生了怎样的影响以及影响程度如何？

Can you describe how, and to what extent, you think Freire’s work has had an impact on research?

我最熟悉的解放方法论——女权主义和非殖民化——植根于弗雷雷、女权主义和本土认识论和研究方法。我亲身体验了保罗·弗雷雷的理论如何在两者中得到创造性和令人信服的应用。

Liberatory methodologies that I am most familiar with—feminist and decolonizing—are rooted in Freirean, feminist, and indigenous epistemologies and research methods. I have experienced how Paulo Freire’s theories have been applied creatively and convincingly in both.

英文原版前言（1970 年）

Foreword to the Original English Edition (1970)

理查德·肖尔

Richard Shaull

多年来，巴西教育家保罗·弗莱雷的思想和工作从巴西东北部传遍了整个大陆，不仅在教育领域，而且在国家发展的整个斗争中都产生了深远的影响。就在拉丁美洲被剥夺继承权的群众从传统的昏睡状态中觉醒并渴望以主体身份参与国家发展的时候，保罗·弗莱雷完善了一种教授文盲的方法，这种方法对这一进程做出了非凡的贡献。事实上，那些在学习阅读和写作时对自我有了新的认识并开始批判性地审视自己所处的社会状况的人，往往会主动采取行动来改变剥夺他们参与机会的社会。教育再次成为一种颠覆性的力量。

Over the years, the thought and work of the Brazilian educator Paulo Freire have spread from the North East of Brazil to an entire ­continent, and have made a profound impact not only in the field of ­education but also in the overall struggle for national ­development. At the precise moment when the disinherited masses in Latin ­America are awakening from their traditional lethargy and are anxious to participate, as Subjects, in the development of their coun-tries, Paulo Freire has perfected a method for teaching illiterates that has contributed, in an extraordinary way, to that process. In fact, those who, in learning to read and write, come to a new awareness of selfhood and begin to look critically at the social situation in which they find themselves, often take the initiative in acting to transform the society that has denied them this opportunity of participation. Education is once again a subversive force.

在这个国家，我们逐渐意识到保罗·弗莱雷的作品，但到目前为止，我们主要从它对第三世界文盲成人教育的贡献来考虑它。然而，如果我们仔细观察，我们就会发现，他的方法论和教育哲学对我们和对拉丁美洲的被剥夺权利者同样重要。他们争取成为自由主体并参与社会变革的斗争，在许多方面不仅与这个国家的黑人和墨西哥裔美国人的斗争相似，也与中产阶级年轻人的斗争相似。发展中国家的斗争的尖锐性和激烈性很可能为我们提供新的见解、新的榜样，以及面对自身处境的新希望。因此，我认为《被压迫者教育学》英文版的出版是一件大事。

In this country, we are gradually becoming aware of the work of Paulo Freire, but thus far we have thought of it primarily in terms of its contribution to the education of illiterate adults in the Third World. If, however, we take a closer look, we may discover that his methodology as well as his educational philosophy are as ­important for us as for the dispossessed in Latin America. Their struggle to become free Subjects and to participate in the transformation of their society is similar, in many ways, to the struggle not only of blacks and Mexican-Americans but also of middle-class young people in this country. And the sharpness and intensity of that struggle in the developing world may well provide us with new insight, new models, and a new hope as we face our own situation. For this ­reason, I consider the publication of Pedagogy of the Oppressed in an English edition to be something of an event.

保罗·弗莱雷的思想代表着一种创造性思维和敏感的良知对他周围被压迫者所遭受的极度痛苦和苦难的回应。弗莱雷 1921 年出生于累西腓，这里是第三世界最贫困和欠发达地区之一的中心，他很快就被迫直接体验到这种现实。随着 1929 年美国经济危机开始影响巴西，弗莱雷中产阶级家庭的不稳定局面开始瓦解，他发现自己也与“地球上的可怜人”一样处于困境之中。这对他的一生产生了深远的影响，他开始体会饥饿的痛苦，并因为饥饿导致的无精打采而在学校落后；这也促使他在 11 岁时发誓要将自己的一生献给与饥饿作斗争，以便其他孩子不必经历他当时所经历的痛苦。

Paulo Freire’s thought represents the response of a creative mind and sensitive conscience to the extraordinary misery and suffering of the oppressed around him. Born in 1921 in Recife, the center of one of the most extreme situations of poverty and underdevelopment in the Third World, he was soon forced to experience that reality directly. As the economic crisis in 1929 in the United States began to affect Brazil, the precarious stability of Freire’s middle-class fam-ily gave way and he found himself sharing the plight of the “wretched of the earth.” This had a profound influence on his life as he came to know the gnawing pangs of hunger and fell behind in school because of the listlessness it produced; it also led him to make a vow, at age eleven, to dedicate his life to the struggle against ­hunger, so that other children would not have to know the agony he was then experiencing.

他早年与穷人的生活分享也使他发现了他所描述的被剥夺者“沉默文化”。他逐渐意识到，他们的无知和冷漠是整个经济、社会和政治统治状况以及家长制的直接产物，他们是这些统治的受害者。他们没有得到鼓励和装备去了解和应对他们世界的具体现实，而是被“淹没”在一种几乎不可能产生批判意识和反应的境地中。他清楚地认识到，整个教育体系是维持这种沉默文化的主要工具之一。

His early sharing of the life of the poor also led him to the discov­ery of what he describes as the “culture of silence” of the dispossessed. He came to realize that their ignorance and lethargy were the direct product of the whole situation of economic, social, and political domination—and of the paternalism—of which they were victims. Rather than being encouraged and equipped to know and respond to the concrete realities of their world, they were kept ­“submerged” in a situation in which such critical awareness and response were practically impossible. And it became clear to him that the whole educational system was one of the major instruments for the maintenance of this culture of silence.

弗莱雷以一种非常存在主义的方式面对这个问题，于是他把注意力转向教育领域并开始研究它。多年来，他一直致力于研究和反思，在教育哲学方面产生了一些非常新颖和富有创意的东西。从直接参与解放男女、创造新世界的斗争开始，他接触到了许多人的思想和经验。他从不同背景、不同哲学立场的人们身上汲取思想，用他的话来说，就是“萨特和穆尼埃、埃里希·弗洛姆和路易·阿尔都塞、奥尔特加·加塞特和毛泽东、马丁·路德·金和切·格瓦拉、乌纳穆诺和马尔库塞”。他借鉴这些人的见解，形成了自己独有的、针对拉丁美洲具体现实的教育观点。

Confronted by this problem in a very existential way, Freire turned his attention to the field of education and began to work on it. Over the years, he has engaged in a process of study and reflection that has produced something quite new and creative in educa­-tional philosophy. From a situation of direct engagement in the struggle to liberate men and women for the creation of a new world, he has reached out to the thought and experience of those in many different situations and of diverse philosophical positions: in his words, to “Sartre and Mounier, Erich Fromm and Louis Althusser, Ortega y Gasset and Mao, Martin Luther King and Che Guevara, Unamuno and Marcuse.” He has made use of the insights of these men to develop a perspective on education which is authentically his own and which seeks to respond to the concrete realities of Latin America.

弗莱雷的教育哲学思想最早体现在 1959 年他在累西腓大学的博士论文中，后来他在同一所大学担任教育史与哲学教授，并在同一个城市进行早期的文盲教学实验中也体现了这一点。他开发的方法被天主教徒和其他人士广泛用于巴西东北部的扫盲运动，并被认为对旧秩序构成了威胁，以至于弗莱雷在 1964 年军事政变后立即被捕入狱。70 天后，弗莱雷获释，并被鼓励离开该国，前往智利，在那里他花了五年时间与联合国教科文组织和智利土地改革研究所合作开展成人教育项目。随后，他担任哈佛大学教育学院的顾问，并与一些在农村和城市地区从事新教育实验的团体密切合作。他目前担任日内瓦世界基督教会联合会教育办公室的特别顾问。
